Abstract of Dissertation Presented to the Graduate School

of the University of Florida in Partial Fulfillment of the

Requirements for the Degree of Doctor of Philosophy

GIAN VITTORIO ROSSI’S 1637 EUDEMIAE LIBRI VIII:

TRANSLATED WITH AN INTRODUCTION AND NOTES

By

Jennifer Karen Nelson

May 2019

Chair: Konstantinos Kapparis

Major: Classical Studies

Gian Vittorio Rossi, who wrote under the pseudonym Ianus Nicius Erythraeus,

lived from 1577 to 1647. An active participant in the intellectual and artistic community

orbiting in Rome around Pope Urban VIII and the powerful Barberini family, his prolific

literary output encompassed many genres, including letters, dialogues, orations,

biographies, poetry, and fiction. A superlative Latinist, Rossi unleashed his biting wit

and deep knowledge of Classical literature against perceived societal wrongs. Set in the

fictional time and place of first-century AD Rome, Eudemiae libri VIII is a satirical novel

that criticizes Rossi’s own society for its system of patronage and favors that he saw as

rewarding wealth and opulence over skill and hard work. An understudied figure,

Rossi’s involvement with one of Rome’s premier literary academies, his relationships

with intellectuals both in Italy and all over Europe, and his literary output, which was

almost exclusively in Latin, provide a unique and different insider perspective on

Baroque Rome, a period known mostly for its painting, sculpture, architecture, and

literature in the vernacular.

8

CHAPTER 1

INTRODUCTION

Gian Vittorio Rossi and Eudemiae libri VIII

Gian Vittorio Rossi had an ax to grind. His Eudemiae libri VIII tells the story of

Flavius Vopiscus Niger and Paulus Aemilius Verus, who escape from Rome in the

aftermath of the Conspiracy of Sejanus and become shipwrecked on Eudemia, an

island located off the coast of Mauritania. They are rescued by a fellow Roman named

Gallonius, who becomes their guide. The two travelers discover a society of Latin

speakers that is governed by a class of people called dynastae, administered by

incompetent senators (called poliarchi) and magistrates, where petty rivalries thrive,

hard work and skill are trumped by personal relationships and favors, and where, as

Luisella Giachino puts it, everything revolves around “la sinistra onnipresenza e

onnipotenza del denaro” (“the sinister omnipresence and omnipotence of money”).1

Writing under the pseudonym Ianus Nicius Erythraeus, Rossi brought to bear his vast

knowledge of ancient authors, his acerbic wit, and his mastery of Latin to weave a tale

that, despite its fictional time and place, is a mordent critique of his own society: Rome

under the reign of Pope Urban VIII and the powerful Barberini family.

It is clear both from his own writings and from contemporary assessments of his

talent that Rossi was well read, witty, and, above all, an excellent Latinist. He was a

founding member of the Accademia degli Umoristi, an influential literary academy that

attracted intellectuals from all over Europe and was frequented by Rome’s high society,

including Maffeo Barberini, later Pope Urban VIII. Rossi hoped that his education, skills,

1 Giachino 2002: 199. All translations are mine unless otherwise indicated.

9

and connections would lead to a fruitful career in the Roman Curia, but this never came

to fruition. After a life of professional frustration, spent on the margins of Rome’s elite

society, Rossi retired to a private life of reading and writing.

Among the literary products of his retirement years was Eudemia, described by

Luigi Gerboni as a “sfogo di vecchi rancori” (“a venting of old grudges”).2 The 1637

publication date of Eudemiae libri VIII places it squarely within what Jennifer Morrish

calls the “golden age of the neo-Latin novel.”3 As Mark T. Riley explains, examples of

extended Latin prose fiction in the vein of Apuleius’s Metamorphoses or Petronius’s

Satyricon were rare until the early seventeenth century, when John Barclay published

Euphormionis Lusinini Satyricon (Parisiis: Huby, 1605).4 Following Barclay’s satire,

2 Gerboni 1899: 108.

3 Morrish 2003: 238. While Eudemia is frequently classified under the broad category of novel (IJsewijn

1995: 91; IJsewijn and Sacré 1998: 255; Giachino 2002: 187; Riley 2015: 196; Marsh 2015: 404), it is

also described using various generic subcategories: satirical novel (Tilg 2017: 332); roman à clef (Drujon

1966: 1052-7; Gryphius 1710: 491-6; Kytzler 1982: 204; De Smet 1996: 76-7; Hofman 1999: 11);

Menippean satire (De Smet 1996: 76; ibid. 2015: 204; IJsewijn 1988: 237; ibid. 1995: 91); and utopia (Tilg

2017: 332; De Smet 1996: 76; Kytzler 1982: 204; Gott and Begley 1902: 361). The utopian genre merits

further comment. Whereas Thomas More’s 1516 Utopia narrates a voyage to an ideal land, the voyage

narrated in Eudemia is from a corrupt land to an even more corrupt land. The protagonists flee Rome in

the aftermath of the attempted overthrow of the emperor Tiberius, whose craven reputation was

immortalized by such authors as Tacitus and Suetonius. Even in comparison to Rome under Tiberius,

however, the island of Eudemia finds itself on the losing side in terms of wantonness, causing the narrator

at one point to exclaim, “Vah . . . Qui cultus! Quae luxuries! At Romae nemo senator, nemo consul, ac ne

Tiberius quidem . . . hujus opulentiae luxu decoratur” (“What elegance! What luxury! In Rome no senator,

consul, or even Tiberius himself, adorns himself with the trappings of such wealth!”). This is why Kytzler

(1982: 204) places the work on the periphery of the utopian genre. This nonutopian aspect of Eudemia

has often been misunderstood. According to Gerboni (1899: 133-4), both Gabriel Naudé and Burkhard

Struve considered Eudemia a utopian novel. In fact, Gerboni cites a letter from Naudé to Rossi (Epistolae

1667: 699), in which the French humanist makes a direct comparison between Eudemia and More’s

Utopia: “tuo forsan vel Mori suo exemplo ductus Eudemiam aliquam, Utopiamve fingere voluit.” He also

cites a passage from Naudé’s Additions et Corrections au Naudaeana et Patiniana (1703: 147) in which

Naudé describes Eudemia as a “république bien policée” (“a well-run republic”). Additionally, in the

bibliography following his translation of Samuel Gott’s Nova Solyma, Walter Begley (1902: 361) lists

Eudemia under the category “Utopian Romance of an Ideal City or State.”

4 Barclay, Riley, and Huber 2004: 3. For an overview of ancient prose fiction see Hägg 1983 and Hofman

1999. For an overview of early modern prose fiction (both in general and as it relates to Rossi’s literary

models) see Fleming 1973: xiv-xxvi; IJsewijn and Sacré 1998: 74, 255-56; Morrish 2003: 237-48; Porter

10

which, like Petronius’s Satyricon, was “full of lively incident and satirical descriptions of

contemporary people and institutions,”5 Rossi unleashed his arsenal of learning and wit

against his contemporaries with full awareness of his ancient and modern generic

predecessors.

Eudemiae libri VIII is at once an entertaining tour de force of Classical erudition

and an intimately personal introduction to his own circle. As Giachino explains,

Eudemia’s plot is secondary to “quello che oggi chiameremmo il ‘gossip,’ il martellante e

vischioso pettegolezzo che anima e coinvolge tutti i personaggi”6 (“what today we would

call ‘gossip,’ the incessant and vicious scuttlebutt that animates and involves all of the

characters”). Rossi becomes our guide—our Gallonius—as he introduces us to his

friends, lets us in on the debates of the day, and airs his grievances with a society that

admired him but never completely embraced him.

State of Scholarship on Eudemia

Despite his prolific literary output, his active correspondence with friends in high

places, the reputation he enjoyed as a Latinist among his contemporaries, and his

continued fame in Northern Europe, particularly in Germany, for more than a century

after his death,7 Gian Vittorio Rossi remains a largely unexplored figure in Italian

literature. Luigi Gerboni, the nineteenth-century scholar who wrote the most extensive

biography of Rossi, lamented that this Roman author had been all but ignored even by

2014; De Smet 2015: 199-214; Riley 2015: 183-97; Glomski and Moreau 2016; Marsh 2017: 308-21;

Relihan 2017: 340-57; Tilg 2017: 322-39.

5 Barclay, Riley, and Huber 2004: 3.

6 Giachino 2002: 199.

7 Gerboni 1899: 2.

11

Italian scholars: “la critica nostra l’ha dimenticata, o meglio non l’ha mai conosciuta”

(“our literary critics have forgotten him, or rather, they have never known him”)8;

likewise, Benedetto Croce remarked that, unfortunately, nobody showed any interest in

Rossi’s works (“ora nessuno lo cerca”).9 The most recent and thorough analysis of

Eudemia is Luisella Giachino’s 2002 article, “Cicero libertinus: La satira della Roma

barberiniana nell’Eudemia dell’Eritreo,” in which she offers a detailed summary of the

work and discusses its major themes. Giachino also authored the recent entry for Rossi

in Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani.10

Though the literature specifically on Gian Vittorio Rossi and his works is slight,

interest in neo-Latin literature in general has happily been increasing. In the 1970s

Jozef IJsewijn observed that, with regards to scholarly work on neo-Latin authors of the

sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, “almost everything remains to be done.”11 Thirty

years later, the scholarly status of neo-Latin authors had not changed much when

Jennifer Morrish remarked that they were “little known today and not much read”

because, among other things, most of the texts are available only in their original Latin

and do not exist in modern editions.”12 More recently, there has been significant

progress in creating new editions of neo-Latin texts, notably the I Tatti Renaissance

Library (Harvard University Press), the Bibliotheca Latinitatis Novae’s “Neo-Latin Texts

and Translation” series (Leuven University Press), the NeoLatina series (Tübingen:

8 Ibid.: 2.

9 Croce and Fabrizi 2003: 136.

10 DBI Volume 88 (2017): http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/gian-vittorio-rossi_(Dizionario-Biografico)

11 IJsewijn 1976: 43.

12 Morrish 2003: 237.

12

Narr-Verlag), and the Bloomsbury Neo-Latin Series. Besides IJsewijn and Morrish,

authors such as Christopher Celenza, Ingrid De Smet, David Marsh, David Porter, Joel

Relihan, Mark T. Riley, Dirk Sacré, and Stephan Tilg, as well as new reference works

such as Brill’s Encyclopedia of the Neo-Latin World, the Oxford Handbook of Neo-Latin,

and the Guide to Neo-Latin Literature from Cambridge University Press, have been

instrumental in bringing ever greater scholarly attention to neo-Latin literature. Gian

Vittorio Rossi, however, has still largely been ignored, his works usually mentioned only

in passing as part of a larger list of neo-Latin authors and texts.13

Factors that contributed to Rossi’s near obscurity include the fact that he was

writing in Latin at a time when vernacular languages were ascending in Europe as the

principal vehicle for literary expression and exchange of ideas; none of his work was

ever translated into any language for a broader reading public;14 and, in the case of

Eudemia, readers over the centuries may have lost interest in the satire because it was

too tied to Rossi’s own circle of acquaintances thus “los[ing] referential power over

time,” as Dustin Griffin explains.15

13 IJsewijn mentions Eudemia briefly in the chapter on long novels in his Companion to Neo-Latin Studies.

In his article titled “Latin Literature in 17th-century Rome,” IJsewijn discusses the author and his work

within the artistic and intellectual milieu of Rome under the Urban VIII Barberini. The Oxford Handbook of

Neo-Latin mentions Rossi four times, briefly: In the chapter titled “Fiction,” Riley describes Eudemia as “a

satire on seventeenth-century Rome written in beautiful Latin” (196); in the chapter titled “Satire,” De

Smet identifies it as a Menippean satire that paints “a detailed, if rather disjointed, portrait of Rome under

the papacy of Urban VIII” (206); and Marsh, in the chapter titled “Italy,” makes this perplexing statement:

“Emblematically, in the mid-seventeenth century, Gian Vittorio Rossi chose to set his Latin novel Eudemia

(1645) in the age of Tiberius, and therefore could describe none of the baroque splendor or modern

mores of contemporary Rome” (404).

14 Croce and Fabrizi 2003: 143.

15 Griffin 1994: 122.

13

Rossi’s works deserve further scholarly attention both on their own merits and

because they provide a window into the dynamic cultural period in which he lived. Rossi

was an insider witness to seventeenth-century Rome, a period Jozef IJsewijn

characterized as “a thriving center of Latin literature on an international scale.”16 His

literary output was prolific and encompassed many genres, including letters, dialogues,

orations, biographies, poetry, and, of course, fiction. Last but not least, his works are

highly enjoyable to read because his personality—at times witty, incisive, pious, and

caustic—comes through on almost every page.

Life of Gian Vittorio Rossi

Gian Vittorio Rossi was born in 1577 in Rome to a family that he describes as

noble but not wealthy: “[P]otes . . . breviter respondere me esse bono genere ortum,

bonis prognatum, modicis facultatibus” (“The short answer is that I come from a good

family and am descended from noble people of modest means”).17 He had a younger

brother, Andrea, and a younger sister whom he never mentions by name.18 Rossi was

educated at the Jesuit Collegio Romano (now the Pontifical Gregorian University),

where he was a pupil of such teachers as Bernardino Stefoni and Francesco Benci, the

16 IJsewijn 1995: 78.

17 Dialog. sept. XIII (Prefatory letter, addressed to Vaius Vaius). See also Gerboni 1899: 7-8. The most

thorough source of information on Rossi’s life and works is Gerboni’s Un umanista nel secento, Giano

Nicio Eritreo (Città di Castello: S. Lapi, 1899). Gerboni draws his information primarily from Rossi’s

published letters (Epistolae ad diversos, vols. 1 & 2 and Epistolae ad Tyrrhenum, vols. 1 & 2) as well as

his book of dialogues (Dialogi septendecim), in particular the thirteenth dialogue, in which Rossi gives a

first-person account of his life. In addition, a few vignettes in Eudemia are thought to be inspired by

events in Rossi’s own life. Another source is Johann Christian Fischer’s “Vita Ioannis Victorii Rossi sive

Iani Nicii Erythraei,” which he includes in his Epistolae ad Tyrrhenum et ad diversos, though Gerboni

criticizes Fischer’s overly encomiastic portrayal of Rossi, remarking that Fischer’s view of the Roman

author reflects the high regard that German and other Northern European scholars had for Rossi in the

seventeenth and eighteenth centuries.

18 Gerboni 1899: 8.

14

latter a student of the French humanist Marc Antoine Muret, one of the greatest Latinists

of the Renaissance. When Rossi was seventeen years old his father died, and his

family was placed in a precarious financial state exacerbated by his brother Andrea’s

penchant for making bad business investments and defaulting on loans, which resulted

in the loss of the family’s good name among creditors.19 Finding himself, as the eldest

son, in the position of head of household, Rossi studied law with the hope that such a

degree would lead to an administrative position within the papal court. He completed his

degree in Roman and canon law in 1596 at the age of nineteen.

Rossi’s professional future seemed bright at first when, upon finishing his degree,

he caught the attention of an individual whom he does not name but describes as “longe

doctissimus atque clarissimus insigni magistratu praeditus” (“the most learned and

famous by far and occupying an important judicial office”), and he was offered a position

coveted by many young professionals “propter honorem atque utilitatem” (“because it

was honorable and well paid”).20 Rossi held this post for little more than a year, when

this patron died suddenly, leaving him without employment. He soon entered an

apprenticeship in contract law under the renowned lawyer Lepido Piccolomini, but this

mentor died after only a few years.21

19 The last trace we have of Andrea is in Palermo in 1603-4, where he was in the service of the Cardinal

of Monreale in Sicily (Gerboni 1899: 12).

20 Rossi never provides this individual’s name. This and the other details of his early career that follow are

described in his 1632 letter to Guilelmus Moonsius (Ep. ad div. 1.IV.II).

21 Ep. ad div. 1.IV.II; see also Gerboni 1899: 14.

15

Following Piccolomini’s death, and after several attempts to enter into the service

of one cardinal or another,22 Rossi became generally disillusioned with the law. He

withdrew to a house on the Janiculum Hill and devoted himself to humanistic studies.23

In one of his autobiographical dialogues he explicitly expressed, in the persona of an

interlocutor named Nicius, his preference for ancient Roman authors over the jurists and

Roman law glossators such as Accursius and Bartolus of Saxoferrato, whose writings

would have been an integral part of his legal studies: “multoque libentius Plautum,

Terentium, Ciceronem, Caesarem sumebam in manus quam Accursium, Bartolum,

ceterosque auctores” (“I much preferred reading the works of Plautus, Terence, Cicero,

and Caesar to those of Accursius, Bartolus, and authors of their ilk”).24

During the early 1600s, when Rossi was turning away from the law to focus on

the liberal arts, he began attending meetings of the Accademia degli Umoristi

(Academia Humoristarum), a literary society frequented by the most celebrated writers,

scholars, and artists in Rome.25 The academy originated as a loose association of

22 Employment under Domenico Pinelli and Ludovico de Torres, the younger (archbishop of Monreale in

Palermo) were two possibilities that never came to fruition (Gerboni 1899: 17).

23 This refuge from the city center would become a recurring image in his works. For example, a poem

appended to a 1643 letter to Fabio Chigi (Ep. ad Tyrr. 1.XLIII) includes these lines: “Est mihi Janiculi

domus alto in vertice collis / Quamvis parva, tamen qua non formosior ulla” (“I have a house at the top of

Janiculum Hill that, though small, is more beautiful than anything”).

24 Dialog. sept. XIII.

25 The origin story of the Accademia degli Umoristi is told more or less consistently in both contemporary

and modern sources: In 1600, during the period of Carnival, a group of literary-minded friends of the

nobleman Paolo Mancini gathered at Palazzo Mancini, his home located in the Via del Corso in Rome, on

the occasion of his wedding to Vittoria Capozzi. They entertained themselves by improvising and reciting

comedies, sonnets, and speeches on various diverting topics. The group decided to keep meeting every

eight days to continue this literary activity, and they came to be known as the Belli Humori. When the

group formally incorporated in 1608, they adopted the name Accademia degli Umoristi (Maylender and

Rava 1976, vol. 5: 370-4; Russo 1979: 47-61; Alemanno 1995: 97-9).

16

writers, but it incorporated in 1608, at which point formal rules were established,26 and

an official emblem was adopted depicting the sun partially obscured by precipitating

clouds, accompanied by the Lucretian motto “redit agmine dulci.”27 The name of the

academy, the Umoristi (humorists), stems from their main activity, which was, at least

initially, writing and performing comic plays in the style of ancient playwrights such as

Plautus and Terence. Over time the Umoristi added more poetry and prose to their

repertoire. The academy boasted many well-known Italian poets as its Principe, or

head, including Alessandro Tassoni (elected in 1606),28 Gian Battista Guarini (elected in

1611), and Giambattista Marino (elected in 1623).

Membership in the Umoristi was not limited to Rome’s elite; in fact, the rules

stated that membership was open to any persons who were “ritenute degne per nobilità

di sangue, per letteratura non mediocre, o per eccellenza di qualche artefitio spettabile”

(“considered worthy based on their nobility of blood, their superior literary abilities, or for

excellence in any respectable art form”).29 That being said, from its very beginning the

academy did attract members of Rome’s most important families such as the Colonna

and the Barberini. One of its most prominent members was that most famous Barberini,

Maffeo—Jesuit educated and a recognized neo-Latin poet—who in 1623 became Pope

Urban VIII. It was thanks to Urban VIII and the powerful Barberini family that the

26 The academy’s rules can be found in an appendix to Russo 1979: 58-61. Signatories to the rules

(including Rossi) are listed in Maylender and Rava 1976, vol. 5: 375-80.

27 Gerboni 1899: 16; Maylender and Rava 1976, vol. 5: 375-80.

28 The Accademia degli Umoristi, along with many of its members who also appear in Rossi’s

Pinacotheca and under pseudonyms in his Eudemia, are mentioned in Tassoni’s mock-epic poem La

secchia rapita (XV.41): Gaspare Salviani, Paolo Mancini, Virginio Cesarini, Enrico Falconio, Carlo Mazzei

(also known as Carlo a Sant’Antonio di Padova), and Pietro Sforza Pallavicino.

29 Alemanno 1995: 99.

17

Umoristi, along with the scientific Accademia dei Lincei and the Jesuit Collegio Romano,

became a driving cultural force in the seventeenth century, not just in Rome, but

throughout Europe.30 Historian Marc Fumaroli refers to Urban VIII as “Cicero pontifex

maximus” (Pope Cicero), explaining that neo-Latin literature experienced its second

great Renaissance under his influence.31

Through his participation in the Umoristi, Rossi came in contact with, as Gerboni

puts it, “il fior della cittadinanza” (“the flower of Rome’s citizenry”) and gained respect for

his literary and linguistic abilities.32 The writers, scholars, and intellectuals he met

through the academy became the basis for many of the biographical profiles included in

his Pinacotheca imaginum illustrium, but also fodder for the characters in his satire

Eudemia. This includes, most prominently, a description of an academy meeting in

Book Three where Eudemia’s intellectual elites gather to recite their poetry. It is also

because of his participation in the Umoristi that Rossi became acquainted with Fabio

Chigi (later Pope Alexander VII), who would become his most important friend and

correspondent, as well as being an instrumental factor in his eventual publishing

success.

In a 1646 letter to the Dutch scholar Guilelmus Moonsius, Rossi credited his

reputation as a Latinist for the fact that, around 1607, he was offered a position in the

Roman Curia, explaining that Marcello Vestrio, Secretary of Latin Briefs under Pope

30 Ibid.: 99-100.

31 Fumaroli 1978: 797-835. The academy itself continued until 1717, but its major cultural impact was felt

during Urban VIII’s papacy (1623 to 1644), the period during which Rossi was an active member

(Alemanno 1995: 99-100).

32 Gerboni 1899: 16.

18

Paul V, had been impressed after hearing Rossi declaim at an academy meeting.33 In

the same letter, Rossi informed Moonsius that (by his own estimation) he made quite a

name for himself in that job, remarking that “quicquid paulo limatius elegantiusque ex

Vestrii domo prodibat, illud omnes meo praesertim ingenio industriaque perfectum

elaboratumque existimabant esse” (“whenever anything more polished or elegant was

issued by Vestrio’s office, everyone reckoned that it had been executed and worked on

largely thanks to my ingenuity and effort”). This job lasted only eight months, however,

before Vestrio took ill and died.

Around 1608, Rossi received a firm job offer as secretary to Cardinal Giovanni

Mellini, who had been appointed papal legate to Germany, but that would have meant

relocating to another country and away from his beloved Rome. As it turned out, he got

as far as the town of Caprarola (about forty miles north of Rome), came down with a

fever, and had to be sent home. He never was able to secure a permanent position

within the Church. Rossi blamed his difficulty in securing permanent employment on the

fact that individuals in positions of power purposefully kept him out because they were

jealous of, and intimidated by, his superior abilities.34

Rossi’s longest period of employment lasted from 1610 to 1623, when he served

as the private secretary to Cardinal Alessandro Damasceni Peretti di Montalto.35 Rossi

33 Ibid.: 19; see also Ep. ad div. 1.IV.II.

34 Ibid.; see also Ep. ad div. 1.IV.II.

Rossi began working for the cardinal in 1610, disputing the 1608 date given by Jean Pierre Niceron

characterized this as a low point in his life, during which he spent more than a decade

doing a thankless job for a thankless employer. In a 1637 letter to Ugo Ubaldini, for

example, Rossi describes Peretti as “inhumanissimus” (“extremely heartless”) because

he not only had to pay for medical care out of his own pocket when he fell ill while in

Peretti’s employ, but Peretti never even asked after him to see if he needed anything.36

In Eudemia Peretti makes a memorable appearance as a nobleman named Plusius, an

inattentive, unappreciative, and miserly boss to a long-suffering and overworked

secretary named Nicius Rufus.37

After Peretti’s death in 1623, Rossi retreated into private life, moving to a house

in the Monte Mario neighborhood in the early 1630s where he spent the rest of his days.

There is no evidence of his having steady employment after that, though Gerboni

assumes that he enjoyed some level of financial stability, since he was able to donate

funds for the construction of a small church on Monte Mario dedicated to Santa Maria

della Febbre, which he left as a bequest to the monastery of Sant’Onofrio (it still exists

today as the Chiesa della Madonna del Rosario).38 In addition, sometime before 1630

he had purchased an honorary office with the title Commissioner of the Aqua Marrana,

1605, while he was still employed elsewhere, or his statement about working for eighteen or twenty years

was rhetorical and simply meant “a long time.”

36 Ep. ad div. 2.II.V; see also Gerboni 1899: 26.

37 Rossi’s true feelings toward his noble employer are difficult to ascertain. On the one hand, he

composed a laudatory poem (included in Ep. ad div. 1.IV.XXVI) titled “In obitum Alexandri Peretti

Cardinalis Montalti” (“On the occasion of the death of Cardinal Alessandro Peretti di Montalto”), in which

he refers to Peretti as “Ille insignis Alexander et inclytus / qua sol surgit et occidit” (“that remarkable and

renowned Alexander on whom the sun rose and set”). On the other hand, Rossi repurposed this very

same poem in Book Four of Eudemia, where it is recited at the funeral procession of a nobleman named

Alexander, at the conclusion of which the narrator tempers his praise by commenting that the nobleman

had actually won the love of the populace more because of his philanthropy than because he boasted any

great learning or notable accomplishments.

20

which came with no responsibilities but yielded a modest annual income of 98.85

scudi.39 This financial independence allowed Rossi to spend the remainder of his life

focused on writing and publishing.

As evidenced in his published letters, Rossi was an active participant in the Res

publica litterarum (Republic of Letters), the pan-European intellectual community that

fostered humanistic studies and the exchange of ideas via epistolary correspondence.

He cultivated friendships with fellow humanists in such places as Italy, France,

Germany, the Netherlands, and Belgium. In his personal life, however, Rossi chose to

remain alone, never marrying or having children. Gerboni points to one of his dialogues

for a clue as to why, citing an interlocutor named Iucundus who, when asked why he

never married, explains that the main two reasons were fear of losing his freedom to a

carping wife, and fear that she would give birth to children who were bow-legged,

knock-kneed, squinty-eyed, buck-toothed, and ill-behaved.40 Gerboni concedes that

39 Gerboni 1899: 41-2; De Gregori 1942: 268. The Aqua Marrana was a medieval aqueduct that brought

water from the Alban Hills to the Lateran section of town. Regarding his title, which he calls a “nudus

honor,” Rossi writes this: “Ego autem ad meum officium quod attinet nunquam scivi quaenam esset haec

aqua Marana, unde orietur, qua flueret, quid utilitatis ex ea Populus Romanus acciperet” (“Regarding my

title, I have never known what the Aqua Marrana was, where it originated, where it flowed, and what use it

was to the Roman people” Ep. ad Tyrr. 2.LXVII). Such purely honorary titles were a mechanism for raising

money for the public coffers. Citizens could purchase fanciful titles like Commissario dell’Acqua Marrana,

Guardiano della Meta Sudante, Revisore delle Mura della Città di Roma, Custode dei Trofei di Mario, and

in return they would receive an annual payout much like a municipal bond coupon. This system continued

until 1811, when it was abolished by imperial decree (De Gregori 1942: 268-9). Rossi stopped receiving

payouts for his title around 1645, and in 1647 he protested by penning, in jest, an oration titled Pro

pecunia mea addressed to the Senatus Populusque Romanus (S.P.Q.R.) and appealing to the Patres

Conscripti (senators), making the case that he deserved this income because of the honor his

publications, with their elegant Latin, brought to the city (this oration, the twenty-second in his work

Orationes viginti duae, is a clear reference to Cicero’s Pro domo sua). Rossi fought to have his stipend

reinstated on other fronts as well, including complaining to Fabio Chigi in a number of letters (e.g., Ep. ad

Tyrr. 2.LI and 2.LIII) claiming that his impecunious state was preventing him from sending congratulations

to Camillo Pamphili (nephew of Pope Innocent X) and Olimpia Aldobrandini on the occasion of their

wedding (Ep. ad Tyrr. 2.LV). Some combination of his complaining and public pressure apparently

succeeded, since he managed to obtain at least a partial reimbursement for the missed payments shortly

before his death (Ep. ad Tyrr. 2.LXVII; Gerboni 1899: 42-4; De Gregori 1942: 272-3).

40 Gerboni 1899: 29 citing Dial. XVII.5.

21

these assertions were made primarily for humorous and rhetorical effect, and he

surmises that the real reason was probably that the majority of educated laymen

aspiring to a career in the Roman Curia tended not to marry, surrounded as they were

by clerics.41 On the other hand, Rossi also never entered the priesthood, which Gerboni

ascribes to a similar fear of losing his liberty, and also to the fact that he ultimately did

not feel a strong spiritual calling to such a life.42 Rossi died on November 13, 1647, at

the age of seventy.

Intellectual and Artistic Milieu of Seventeenth-Century Rome

Rossi’s active literary life largely coincided with the period known as the Baroque.

Though there is no consensus regarding the precise dates that demarcate this era,43 the

Baroque period in Italy more or less coincides with the seventeenth century (seicento).44

The Baroque aesthetic was characterized by meraviglia (wonder or marvel) and

comprised elements intended to act on the emotions of the reader or viewer: the

supernatural or fantastic (favoloso), a surprising and pleasing style achieved via clever

metaphor and ornament (concetti or concettismo), and the application of wit (arguzia)

that allows the reader or viewer to “[glimpse] the truth of things in a unique way.”45 As

Peter Rietbergen explains, the Baroque aesthetic was all-encompassing; it was not just

41 Ibid.: 29.

42 Ibid.: 30-1.

43 Cherchi 1997: 301. Art historians generally define the period as spanning from the late sixteenth

century (the end of Mannerism) to the late seventeenth century (the beginning of Rococo) (Battistini 2000:

14-5; Galluzzi 2005: 16). Historians of literature have traditionally set the parameters of the Baroque

period as beginning with the death of the poet Torquato Tasso in 1595 and ending with the foundation of

the Accademia dell’Arcadia in 1690 (Maravall 1986: 3-4; Cherchi 1997: 301).

44 Galluzzi 2005: 24.

45 Mirollo 1963: 166; see also Cherchi 1997: 304.

22

an artistic style but “a style of living wherein all elements of life were fundamentally

united” to create a sense of wonder.46 The author who is best known for representing

the Baroque literary aesthetic of meraviglia is Giambattista Marino, though he had

already passed away by the time the Baroque era reached its apex under Pope Urban

VIII.47

The Baroque aesthetic was a response to a critical historical moment for the

Roman Catholic Church. During the post-Tridentine Catholic reform movement, or the

Counter-Reformation, the Church sought to reassert its power and to reestablish Rome

as the physical and spiritual center of the Catholic world.48 The consolidation and

maintenance of temporal and spiritual power required the participation of the populace.

The Baroque aesthetic—embodied in theater performances, music, public recitations,

architecture, monuments, and highly visible displays of wealth—served to overwhelm

and delight the reader or viewer, while at the same time leading him or her to embrace

what the Roman Catholic Church deemed correct spiritual teaching (delectare et

docere).49

One of the central drivers of culture in Baroque Rome was the Jesuit order,

whose Collegio Romano was the principal institution for secondary education. The

Jesuit curriculum was based on principles of what Fumaroli terms “Christian humanism,”

a fusion of the disciplined rules found in Cicero and Quintilian and the meditative and

46 Battistini 2000: 12; Rietbergen 2006: 11.

47 Galluzzi 2005: 17.

48 Rietbergen 2006: 13. Battistini (2000: 22) describes the Baroque period in Italy as the manifestation of

a profound anthropological crisis that produced upheavals and imbalances resulting in the progressive

shift of the political center of gravity from Italy and the Mediterranean to northern Europe.

49 Rietbergen 2006: 11, 137.

23

contemplative approach to spirituality as found in the Exercitia spiritualia of Igantius of

Loyola.50 Under the Jesuit-educated, humanist pope Urban VIII and his nephew,

Cardinal Francesco Barberini, Rome experienced a cultural “renovatio” that Fumaroli

describes as a second Roman Renaissance.51 During this period Rome became a

beacon for intellectuals and artists from all over Europe, who flocked to Rome in order

to be part of this flourishing activity in literature, art, and science. Many of them were

members of the Academia degli Umoristi, which became an important arbiter of style

(optimus stylus) during this period.52

Baroque literature has often been judged negatively as extravagant, decadent,

and representing, as one author described, “the nadir of Italian literature.”53 Scholars

who resist this assessment do so from different vantages. IJsewijn, for example, argues

that such a characterization tends to reflect only vernacular works, and that any

adequate assessment of the literary output of seicento Rome must also take into

consideration Latin works written during the period. In his view, “many of the flaws

which critics usually find in the Italian writings of the age, such as bad taste and

extravagance, are markedly absent from the best of their Latin counterparts.”54

50 Fumaroli 1978: 801, 803.

51 Rietbergen 2006: 11; Fumaroli 1978: 801.

52 Fumaroli 1978: 812-3.

53 Cherchi 1997: 301; Galluzzi 2005: 22, 25. The negative assessment of the Baroque period began with

literary critics in the Arcadian period of the late seventeenth century, continued through the eighteenth

century Romantics, and was supported by the influential critics Francesco De Sanctis in the nineteenth

century and Benedetto Croce in the twentieth century (Asor Rosa 1974: 3; Fumaroli 1978: 802).

54 IJsewijn 1995: 82. IJsewijn’s assertion that the Baroque era embraces “bad taste and extravagance” is

also incomplete and itself falls into the literary critical tradition that viewed vernacular Baroque literature in

a negative light. Drawing a distinction between measured literature in Latin and extravagant literature in

Italian risks doing a disservice to the complexity of both. A case in point is Giambattista Marino, who has

been held up by literary critics as the epitome of the exaggerated Baroque style embodying “everything

bad in the Baroque world” (Cherchi 1997: 301). Marino, however, actually shunned gratuitous virtuosity

24

Fumaroli, on the other hand, argues that the very distinction between Baroque and

Classical aesthetic is exaggerated and unnecessary, and that both the rigorous

standards of Ciceronianism and individual (even eccentric) Baroque style are

manifestations of the limitless ways one can express one’s relationship with the

immutable logos of the Catholic Church, which was forced to become more flexible and

open to different means of expression after the Reformation.55

Rossi was certainly aware of these aesthetic debates. Classical authors provided

him a touchstone that guided his style and often put him at odds with the more

experimental trends embraced by his contemporaries. As Gerboni demonstrates, Rossi

expressed a clear preference for Ciceronian Latin over the sort of style he described as

“novum . . . atque sublime” (“new and sublime”),56 criticizing those who rejected the

“verba pura atque dilucida, sententias apertas” (“pure, clear words and manifest

meanings”) of Cicero, in favor of overwrought meraviglia, as privileging form over

substance: “semper tumidi, semper inflati, alas pandunt, montium vertices appetunt,

nubes et inania captunt” (“turgid and swollen, they spread their wings and reach for the

mountaintops, only to grasp clouds and emptiness”).57

and advocated moderation, distinguishing in his 1614 Dicerie sacre between “l’eccellente” and “il goffo”

(“excellence” and “gaudiness”) in art (Galluzzi 2005: 41). Moreover, Marino was a member of the

Accademia degli Umoristi and was even elected its Principe in 1623.

55 Fumaroli 1978: 828-30.

56 Ep. ad div. 1.IV.13, as quoted also in Gerboni 1899: 101-2. Among the other sources Gerboni cites

where Rossi expresses his preference for ancient authors, especially Cicero, over what Gerboni (1899:

102, n. 1-2) calls the “nuova scuola,” are: Ep. ad div. 1.V.10, 1.VII.1, 1.VII.3; Ep. ad div. 2.IX.7, 2.IX.8.

57 Ep. ad div. 1.VII.1, addressed to Girolamo Aleandro the younger, as quoted in Gerboni 1899: 102.

Rossi repurposes this letter as his dedicatory letter in Eudemia to Girolamo Aleandro.

25

It is not only with his letters that Rossi inveighs against this new style. Eudemia

also serves as his vehicle for criticizing writers who turn their back on ancient authors.

In Book Three, for example, he includes poems on such subjects as a honey apple,

Julius Caesar’s beard, and a pomegranate, and the narrator mentions someone who

composed a laudatory poem to a gnat. These compositions and references serve to

poke fun at the Baroque proliferation of paradoxical encomia, poems in praise of

everyday objects.58 In addition, in Books Four and Nine, the two Romans meet people

who, respectively, express indignation at being compared to ancient authors and insist

on their own superiority. One of them declares: “sane pudeat me Virgilianis similes

versus efficere” (“I would be embarrassed to compose verses that are anything like

Virgil’s”); while the other one insists that the writings of ancient authors must be

measured against his own: “scriptores veteres . . . ad sui judicium acuminis revocare ac

de diuturna regni possessione . . . est conatus dejicere” (“he attempted to measure

ancient authors . . . against the criterion of his own acumen and dislodge them from

their long-standing supremacy”). Thus Rossi’s novel, aside from being a social critique,

is also an artistic one—to the detriment of his own contemporaries.

To reiterate Reitbergen’s assessment, the Baroque aesthetic was an all-

encompassing lifestyle that included “banquets and behavior and books.”59 Rossi’s

Eudemia parades this all-encompassing aesthetic before his readers’ eyes. Writing in

Ciceronian Latin, he lays bare a society, fashioned and fostered by the powerful

Barberini family and their circle, that cultivated literary and artistic showmanship,

58 Cherchi 1997: 304.

59 Rietbergen 2006: 11.

26

opulent displays of wealth, sumptuous banquets, luxurious dress, and enormous villas

complete with fountains and spectacular gardens, all fueled and supported by a corrupt

system of patronage and favors.

Gian Vittorio Rossi: Works

Published Works

Rossi’s first publications date to the early 1600s: Orationes novem (Luigi Zanetti,

1603); Oratio de Christi domini ascensu (Guglielmo Facciotti, 1604); and De diuturna

aegrotatione toleranda oratio (Carlo Vullietti, 1605). Printed in Rome, and under his real

name Ioannes Victorius Roscius, they were publications of orations he gave in various

venues, including in meetings of the Accademia degli Umoristi.60 Rossi’s most active

period of publishing did not begin until 1643—when Rossi was well into his sixties—and

it came about thanks to his relationship with Fabio Chigi. By the early 1640s, Chigi had

taken an active interest in Rossi61 and had connected him with Barthold Nihus, a

German convert to Catholicism who was the editor for the Amsterdam-based printer

Joan Blaeu.62 Rossi’s delight at finally finding a publishing house he was happy with is

evident from a 1643 letter to Nihus: “Iucundum mihi est in primis, reperiri typographum,

qui meorum librorum aliquid imprimendum, suscipere velit” (“I am especially glad to

60 These orations would eventually be collected together, augmented by others, and published by Blaeu

in 1649 under the title Orationes viginti duae.

61 The letters in Rossi’s published correspondence with Chigi (Ep. ad Tyrr.) date from 1641 to 1647

(Gerboni 1899: 36).

62 Blaeu issued books on Catholic subjects or by Catholic authors with the imprint of Jost Kalkhoven in

Cologne (and sometimes under the names Johann Kinckius and Cornelius ab Egmondt). Dutch printers

did this either to protect their Calvinist identity or, more likely, to avoid “needlessly disturbing relations with

foreign rulers” (Frijhoff and Spies 2004: 266), thus protecting the market for Catholic books in the south

(Clemens 1992: 90).

27

have found a printer who wants take on the publication of some of my books”).63 This

collaboration resulted in the publication of more than fifteen titles, from 1643 to 1649.64

The work for which Rossi is perhaps best known is Pinacotheca imaginum

illustrium, which Blaeu published in three volumes over five years.65 It is often cited for

its lively biographies of around 160 figures, including cardinals, poets, theologians,

scientists, philosophers, and artists, who lived between the second half of the sixteenth

and the first half of the seventeenth century. In his chapter on Rossi’s Pinacotheca

included in his survey of seventeenth-century Italian literature, Benedetto Croce writes

that the work depicts characters that are “disordinati, squilibrati, pazzeschi” (“messy,

unbalanced, and mad”), and in a manner that underscores their psychological

quirkiness.66 New editions of Pinacotheca continued to be published into the eighteenth

century, the final one in 1729. Other works that remained popular and continued to

enjoy new editions into the first half of the eighteenth century were Epistolae ad

diversos, Epistolae ad Tyrrhenum, Orationes viginti duae, Exempla virtutum et vitiorum,

63 Ep. ad div. 1.VI.VIII.

64 Rossi died in 1647 but he had a hand in the preparation of the works that Blaeu published after his

death. Any works published after 1649, beginning with the 1676 imprint of Exempla virtutum et vitiorum,

were new editions prepared using the existing editions as the exemplar but without the involvement of the

original collaborators (Berthold Nihus died in 1657 and Fabio Chigi was elevated to the papacy in 1655).

The continued interest in Rossi by German scholars and publishers is evidenced by the almost

exclusively German editions of his works, with the addition of many notes and prefatory materials, that

continued to be prepared and published through the late 1740s.

under the name Jost Kalkhoven in 1645, and a third volume, Pinacotheca tertia, was printed in 1648, also

under the name Jost Kalkhoven.

Unpublished or Lost Works

Rossi wrote a number of works that are now lost. Among his sacred dramatic

works was a play titled Tobia, which, according to Leone Allacci, was published in 1629

in Viterbo.67 Rossi’s unpublished sacred plays include Esau et Iacob, Christi Domini

praesepis, Filius profusus ac perditus, and Susanna. His play Magdalena flens ad

sepulchrum Christi, set to music by the composer Virgilio Mazzocchi, was performed

multiple times, including in a private performance before cardinals Francesco Barberini,

Ippolito Aldobrandini, Roberto Ubaldini, and the Polish ambassador to Rome,68 but the

text has not survived. Another musical performance consisted of a sacred play about

Ignatius Loyola set to music by the castrato and composer Loreto Vittori.69 Other lost

short works are Vita Iuvenalis Ancinae Saluciarum Episcopi, Vita Sancti Isidori, Vita

B[eati] Stanislae Kostka, Canonis missae interpretatio, De officio ac dignitate

sacerdotis, Totius missae sacrificii explicatio, and Confessiones propriae, modeled after

St. Augustine’s Confessions.70

67 Tobia is the only one of Rossi’s plays that is listed in Drammaturgia di Leone Allacci: divisa in sette

indici (Roma: Per il Mascardi, 1666). The entry reads, “Tobia, ridotto in atti recitabili da Gio: Vittorio de

Rossi insieme con le rime sue spirituali, in Viterbo appresso Agostino Discepoli 1629 in 4.v.” (317-18).

See also Gerboni 1899: 39; Giachino 2002: 186; Rossi’s entry in DBI. Both Gerboni and Giachino write

that Tobia was published in 1623, which differs from the 1629 date provided by Allacci.

probably Jerzy Ossoliński.

70 For a list of lost works see Gerboni 1899: 74 and Giachino 2002: 186. These lost works are also listed

under the entry for “Ioannes Victorius Roscius” in the second volume of Prospero Mandosio’s Bibliotheca

romana (1682-92: 251-5). Mandosio (1643-1724) was a member of the Accademia degli Umoristi.

Eudemia

Rossi began writing Eudemia in the 1620s after he had retreated to private life

upon the death of Cardinal Peretti-Montalto.71 By 1631, as indicated in a letter to

Giovanni Zaratino Castellini, Rossi was actively in search of someone to dedicate his

book to: “[Satyram] ego possim epistola, quae tuas veras laudas contineat, eidem

praefixa, tuo nomini inscriptam emittere, et quantum mihi ingenii vires ferunt, tibi decus

mihi ipsi laudem acquirere” (“I could publish [my satire] with a dedicatory letter to you

and, to the best of my ability, gain honor for you and praise for myself”).72 We know that

Castellini declined this offer because Rossi wrote to him again three years later,

informing him that the bookseller Giovanni Battista Tamantini, whom he refers to by the

pseudonym Thaumantinus,73 was supposedly going to help him get his as-yet-still-

71 Gerboni 1899: 107-8; Giachino 2002: 187.

72 Ep. ad div. 1.III.XV.

73 Giovanni Battista Tamantini was also known as Giovanni Battista Brugiotti. Gerboni (1899: 108, n. 3;

130) identifies Thaumantinus (also called “Thaumantius” and “Thaumas” in Eudemia) as a certain

“Hermannus” because Rossi mentions a bookseller by this name in his letters (e.g., Ep. ad div. 1.VII.XXVI

and Ep. ad Tyrr. 1.XXIII). I have concluded that the pseudonym “Thaumantinus” is more likely a reference

to Tamantini—given the similarity of his real name to the pseudonym—and that Rossi is referring in these

instances to two different booksellers: “Thaumantinus” is Tamantini and “Hermannus” is the bookseller

Hermann Scheus (I thank Daniel Stolzenberg of the University of California at Davis for the identification

of the latter). My identification of “Thaumantinus” as Tamantini is bolstered by an account given by the

Italian author Angelico Aprosio (1677: 196), as mentioned in Gryphius (1710: 491), indicating that Rossi

and Tamantini were indeed acquainted: “Ma già che habbiamo fatto mentione dell’Eudemia, non sarebbe

gran fatto che, prima di compiere questo libro, mi risolvessi di pubblicarne la chiave, che in parte

dall’autore era stata communicata a Giovan Battista Tamantini che governava la libraria del Sole” (“As

long as I have mentioned Eudemia, it would not be a great effort on my part, before finishing my book, to

publish a key, which was partially communicated by the author to Giovanni Battista Tamantini, who ran

the bookstore at the [sign of the] Sun”). As far as I can tell, the key was never published. Further

corroboration that “Thaumantinus” and “Hermannus” are two different people (Tamantini and Scheus,

respectively) is that they were collaborators in real life. In 1624, the bookseller Andrea Brugiotti, who had

his shop in Piazza Pasquino at the sign of the Sun, entrusted the running of his bookstore to Hermann

Scheus and to his nephew Giovanni Battista Tamantini (Franchi and Sartori 1994, vol. 1: 92-93, incl. 92,

n. 7). In 1627 or 1628 Brugiotti sold his business to Tamantini, and Scheus opened his own shop in

Piazza Pasquino at the sign of the Queen (“sub signo Reginae” or “all’insegna della Regina”) (Romani

1973: 78; Borraccini Verducci et al. 2013: 193). Both Gerboni (1899: 130) and Giachino (2002: 197)

maintain that the person behind the pseudonym “Thaumantinus” was Rossi’s editor in real life. While it is

certainly possible that Scheus and/or Tamantini helped arrange for the 1637 publication of Rossi’s book

30

unpublished novel printed in Venice: “bibliopola illi in animo est Venetias imprimendam

eam mittere (“the bookseller has in mind to send it to Venice for printing”).74 No

Venetian edition ever materialized. Instead, looking back in a 1646 letter to Kaspar

Schoppe, Rossi explained the circumstances by which Eudemiae libri VIII finally came

to be published by the Elzevier press in Leiden:

Venit die quodam ad me bibliopola, amicus meus, cum Argedine Io[annis]

Barclaji, cuius ego libri inspiciendi eram oppidus. Ac ioci causa: “Habeo,

inquam, ego quoque librum . . . huic non longe dissimilem.” Tum ille:

“Cedo mihi eum, ait ut legam.” Confestim tradidi, eo animo ut numquam

repeterem. At vis biennium intercesserat ab hoc sermone, cum illo habito,

cum mihi libenter, quem in malam rem abisse credideram, Lugduni

Batavorum impressus ostenditur.75

One day my friend the bookseller76 came to me with John Barclay’s

Argenis, which I was eager to take a look at. Jokingly, I said to him: “I also

have a book that is not too different from this.” Then he said: “Give it to

me, I want to read it.” I gave it to him straight away, thinking that I would

never see it again. But hardly two years had passed from that meeting

with him when he showed me the book—which I thought had met a bad

end—having been published in Leiden.

Eudemiae libri VIII was the first work published under his pseudonym, Ianus Nicius

Erythraeus.77

After its publication in Leiden, Eudemia libri VIII circulated in Northern Europe

where it likely came to the attention of Fabio Chigi, who had been named Papal Nuncio

to Cologne in 1639. Chigi already knew Rossi from the Academia degli Umoristi, which

he began to frequent when he moved from Siena to Rome in 1626 to embark on his

ecclesiastical career.78 An early biography of Chigi, also a neo-Latin poet, indicates that

the bishop was always eager to read things that were new, unique, and interesting—

and it probably did not hurt that Chigi himself appears in Book Three of Eudemia as a

noble young man named Tyrrhenus attending a meeting of a literary academy.79 Chigi’s

introduction of Rossi to Joan Blaeu and his editor Barthold Nihus resulted in the 1645

publication of Eudemiae libri decem, the second, expanded edition of Eudemia.80 Title

pages for both the 1637 and 1645 editions are found in Appendix B.
