We arrived at the vast and elegant forum surrounded by churches, temples, and

colonnades. High above the forum we could see a water clock with this epigram:

When the heavy water inside the clepsydra sinks down, so too does the

day come to an end, cast down from the vault of heaven. Alas, if our years

pass by like that falling water, the fate of our ripe old age arrives all too

quickly. If life perceives its demise when it has only just begun, will the

brief time that is granted us be wasted and slip away? Virtue is the only

thing that remains unchanging in the face of quickly passing years;

everything else rushes past under the pressure of its own weight.

Because it was the hottest time of year, many noblemen—even many who do not need

to sing for their supper—were being carried about on horses and in carriages and were

moving slowly about the crowded streets of the city, the copiously flowing fountains, and

the broad piazzas, in order, I reckon, to find some cool relief. But it was the splendor of

certain individuals that particularly caught our eye. They were being ferried about in

carriages that were resplendent with much gold and purple, and they seemed to

confound and throw everything into disorder wherever they went.22 Their servants

moved the crowds aside, driving away any horses, mules, or carts that were getting in

their way. What is more, everyone stood in respect before them as if they were gods

descended from the heavens, moved out of their way, doffed their hats, sank down to

their knees, and brought their horses and carriages to a halt. When Gallonius saw us

admiring this sight, as if gripped by such splendor, he said: “Don’t be astonished; those

are the dynasts I was telling you about. Do you see the honor that is bestowed on them

as if they were gods on earth?” “Goodness,” I exclaimed. “What elegance! What luxury!

22 John M. Hunt (2010: 698-9) explains that, since the late sixteenth century, carriages had become an

integral part of the elite lifestyle of wealthy Romans and were seen as “a major conveyor of honor,

prestige, magnificence, and a host of other noble traits”; status was further communicated by the

decoration of the carriages “gilded with silver and gold, covered in silk and velvet, and his horses dressed

in ribbons.”

295

In Rome no senator or consul is adorned with the trappings of such wealth—not even

Tiberius himself, lord of all. He barely exceeds the proper measure of a citizen in his

whole manner of living.”

In the meantime we had arrived at that important man’s palace. In front of his

palace we saw a courtyard and a splendid walkway. Entering rather confidently, we

stepped first into the peristyle. At the far side of the peristyle was a fountain worthy of

the dynast. A statue of Bacchus made of marble and sitting on a wine jug seemed to be

urinating into a pool below, and on its broad base was inscribed, in large letters, this

epigram:

You who see this statue of Bacchus placed here, urinating into this big

pool but filling it with clear water, ask that he bestow gifts worthy of the

god Bacchus and that he offer foaming young wine in place of his cold

stream. Then his bladder will be free, with no kidney stone to obstruct it,

so that, once water has been banished, wine will always be consumed.

Gallonius asked one of the servants to tell his master that he had responded to his

summons and had arrived, and then to ask him if he wanted anything. The servant

replied that every approach to the master was currently blocked because he was

feeding dinner (that he had prepared with his own hands) to his parrots, nightingales,

cats, monkeys, and dogs, which he loved more than his own eyes. Gallonius said to

him: “Tell him I’m here; otherwise I won’t delay him.” In the meantime, while the servant

left and came back, I saw many epitaphs affixed here and there on the walls. I asked

what their significance was. Someone responded: “These are epitaphs written in honor

of the deceased cats and dogs that the master loved, and for whom he celebrated last

296

rites while shedding many tears.”23 I began transcribing them in the notebook that I

always carried with me:

EPITAPH OF NICOLOSA THE CAT

If you are asking, I was Nicolosa, a good cat to whom a lizard I consumed

brought an undeserving death. Dying, I was ashamed to go softly while

lying on a bed or pouring out my weak limbs onto the hard ground. I fought

for a long time, not ceding to death without a struggle, but in vain. Alas, in

the end, perfidious death was stronger than I. Thus it is granted to me to

live forever always wandering about the house and the high rooftops. But

you, colorful lizards with your scaly backs, I will chase you out of the

sunny spots into the dank shadows.

EPITAPH OF RUSPOLUS THE PUPPY

Thus the invisible fates cut short the threads of your life, Ruspolus, love

and delight of your master. Lesbia did not mar her bright eyes as she

mourned the sad fate of her departed sparrow24 as much as your master

did when he sullied his face with flowing tears as he performed your last

rites. But let my mourning have an effect, for the dark Underworld has not

led you away but the bright stars in the sky hold you, so that, hereafter,

with the constellation of the dry dog star banished, summers will be milder

under your command.

I had begun copying down another epitaph to yet another cat when Gallonius

was summoned. We came running, went up the stairs, and were led into the room

where that first citizen was banqueting, lying on a bed that had ivory legs and was

covered with purple and gold. He was hemmed in on all sides by a throng of cats and

dogs, one of which was sitting on his shoulder, one around his neck, one was looking

around for food, one was snatching a choice morsel out of his hands with its paws bent

around it, one was barking, and one was lying peacefully at its master’s feet hoping for

some charity. When he noticed us approaching he looked at Gallonius and said: “Do

23 Girolamo Aleandro, the younger, dedicatee of Eudemia, published a volume of poems upon the death

of his dog titled In obitum Aldinae catellae lacrymae poeticae (Parisiis: Apud Nicolaum Buon, 1622). I

thank Mark T. Riley for bringing it to my attention, as well as for referring me to an example of a poem

dedicated to a dog in Argenis II.13.6 (Barclay, Riley, and Huber 2004: 330-1).

24 A reference to Lesbia’s dead sparrow in Catull. II and III. See also Eud. 1998 Lib. I n. 6.

297

you know why I ordered you to be brought here?” “Indeed, I do not,” replied Gallonius.

“But I hurried back here in compliance with your orders, and I now await your wish.” “I

will tell you what I want,” he said. “Today, while I was at leisure and being driven around

the city, I caught sight of two monkeys playing in the window of a private house near the

shrine of Vesta, and I remarked to myself that I had never seen more charming

specimens in my life. See to it that you bring them to me as a gift, either by entreaty or,

if it is not otherwise possible, for a price. Do not spare any effort or expense for I am

burning with an incredible desire to possess them.” “I understand,” said Gallonius. “I will

soon carry out your order and, however cunning and clever their owner may be that he

cannot easily be taken in by tricks, I can nevertheless satisfy your wish; I will contrive, I

will find a way, I will fabricate a ruse by which he will be nicely taken in.” “You have

made me a wonderful promise,” said Bibulus. “Your good deeds exhort me, by god, to

repay you with some sort of agreeable gift. But I cannot afford much and I am ashamed

of giving you too little.” Gallonius replied: “That is in keeping with your benevolence.”

“Off you go,” Bibulus said, “and give it your all.” Gallonius responded: “Is there anything

else my cunning can accomplish for you in addition to this?” “Not at this time,” replied

Bibulus.

And so we set off, we arrived at the front door, and there we saw a filthy, sick

man being carried in someone’s arms and placed in a sedan chair. As soon as

Gallonius saw him he said: “What’s all this, my Agrostes?25 (for that was the man’s

name). Why are you so pale? Why are your limbs so infirm?” “Because—poor me!—I

25 Vincenzo Gramigna (1580-1627). IJsewijn (Eud. 1998, Lib. I n. 8) does not identify the person behind

this pseudonym but he does point out that the name means a “rustic man” or “hunter” (from the Greek

αγρωστής). Rossi devotes a portrait to Gramigna in his Pinacotheca.

298

am suffering from quotidian fever,26 and I fear the worst unless god sees to it that I

recover from this illness, or that it at least doesn’t put me out of commission for many

months.” “I pray to Aesculapius and Salus for it not to be so. Cheer up, your fever will

soon pass, my eyebrow is twitching to that effect.27 But where did you contract such a

grave illness? And where are you off to so sick? You know that this nobleman, who

embraces even wild animals with such generosity, will bring you anything you need.”

Agrostes responded: “The unrelenting labor of writing, staying up all night, and running

back and forth in service of that man is the cause of my illness. But now, because I can

be of no use to him on account of my illness, I am being taken to the hospital that is

attached to the nearest Temple of Aesculapius. Alas—poor me!—what have I been

reduced to?”

While he was busy moaning, a young man named Fossio28 arrived just in the

nick of time. Holding his cloak while sweating and gasping for breath he exclaimed:

“What a shameful crime! Will this most learned man, this distinguished writer, the

greatest poet endowed with the best and most upright character, die in a public hospital

26 Malaria. The attribute “quotidian” refers to the periodicity of a malarial attack, meaning it peaks every

twenty-four hours. The name of the disease comes from the Italian mal’aria, meaning “bad air.” Before it

was discovered, in the late nineteenth century, that malaria was caused by parasites in the bloodstream

from mosquito vectors, people believed in a miasmatic cause of the disease. Located on swampy terrain,

Rome was known for its pestilential air, which was particularly acute in summer and fall and led to annual

outbreaks of malaria during these months (Salares 2002: 1-2, 7, 11).

27 This phrase from Plaut. Pseud. I.I.107 is from Plautus and Riley 1909-10.

28 Marco Antonio Foppa (1603-1673) was from a wealthy family originally from Bergamo. His literary

interests were mostly focused on editing works of Torquato Tasso. Vincenzo Gramigna apparently did

pass away in Foppa’s home, thus being spared the indignity of dying in a hospital. This is memorialized in

a 1627 letter from Rossi to Foppa: “Etenim, nisi humanitas ac liberalitas tua praesto fuisset, vir

doctissimus ac sapientissimus . . . vel in aliquo nosocomio, vel in publico, vel prope dixerim sub dio,

animam exhalasset” (“If it had not been for your humanity and generosity, that most learned and wise

man . . . would have breathed his last in some hospital, in public, or, I dare say, outside”; Ep. ad. div.

1.III.VIII).

299

like any old common person? Will this talent worthy of immortality, this paragon of virtue

and honesty itself, be without the sort of help that even the filthiest, most degenerate

men possess in spades? Are those men, those first citizens, who are obliged to you

because of your long familiarity and association, treating you so disgracefully and so

shamefully? While they may bring this sort of shame upon themselves, I cannot endure

that this great man not enjoy my devotion, service, or duty toward him. Go, get a move

on and carry him to my house. I will receive him under my roof, I will settle him in my

room, and even in my own bed. I will round up the most sought after doctors in the

entire city, and I will not tolerate him being without anything that might be beneficial for

alleviating his illness.”29 When Fossio had finished arranging this he followed on foot,

repeatedly cautioning the men carrying the sedan chair to step carefully and at an easy

pace, so Agrostes’s illness wouldn’t be aggravated by a sudden jolt.

We, on the other hand—because it was that time of day—hurried to Gallonius’s

house, since he had shortly before obtained permission for us to lodge there. We had

almost reached his house when a letter was delivered from a certain Hermagoras,30

recently elected into the dynast class, which contained the following:

FROM HERMAGORAS TO GALLONIUS, GREETINGS. The highest level of dignity,

to which I have recently ascended, demands that I prepare my house and

my household in such a distinguished and richly adorned manner, for my

wife and myself, that it is worthy of me and the position I now hold.

Because I am away from the city, however, I am compelled to commit this

responsibility to the charge of the bearer of this letter, in whom I have the

utmost trust of my affairs and to whom I believe my own reputation is dear.

For this reason I am asking you, on behalf of our friendship, to take up this

business and to find a spacious and grand house for me to rent, and to

assemble a staff of servants that is in keeping with my rank. However, as

29 Rossi’s aforementioned letter to Foppa describes this kind act of bringing Gramigna into his home, his

room, and even into his own bed (“tecto recipere, in tuo cubiculo, atque adeo in tuo lectulo collocare”).

30 Hermagoras (or Hermagora) was a famous Greek rhetorician from Rhodes.

300

to the type of people I would like, just so you know my opinion: I desire

good-looking ones, elegant and well dressed. And it does not matter if

they are immoral or dishonest, so long as they are suitable. And I will even

release you from concerning yourself with choosing one or two of them,

from among educated or learned men, who can draft my official letters or

legal decisions. Whatever is on offer of that kind of person is a complete

waste. Nowadays any old clerk or two-bit lawyer can handle these tasks

satisfactorily. Keep this in mind especially, that I desire only my chef to be

outstanding, someone who can cook to please even the dead. And I would

like you to strive in this matter with every force of your diligence and

industry. See to it that you are well.

After reading this letter Gallonius looked at me and said: “How does his character seem

to you?” “Outstanding indeed, and noble,” I responded. “And nothing but good can be

hoped from it.” While we were admiring the wisdom of that great man, who considers

the prestige of an entire household to be located solely in having a superior chef, a

carriage almost ran me over while I had my guard down and was distracted. But

someone grabbed me by the arm and pulled me out of the way removing me from

danger. Once I had recovered from fright, I asked what man was so powerful that he

could destroy everyone in his path with his carriage. Smiling, Gallonius replied: “You are

mistaken. It is a woman, not a man, who rides around in that carriage. That is

Pasicompsa,31 a dynast’s wife. She is a noblewoman famous for her style and beauty

and for her sexual desire and extravagance besides, much like Sallust’s Sempronia.32

From the cradle, as they say, she propositioned trusting and honorable men with lewd

31 Pasicompsa (from the Greek πᾶσ-κομψή, meaning “adorned” or “well-dressed”), is the name of a

prostitute (“Pasicompsa meretrix”) in Plaut. Merc. See also Eud. 1998, Lib. I n. 9.

32 Sallust’s description of Sempronia, whom he lists among Catiline’s conspirators, appears at Cat. 25.

Ronald Syme (1964: 134-5) suggests that the historical Sempronia was the daughter of Sempronius

Tuditanus. Her historical identification, however, is less important than what she represents in Sallust’s

narrative: in overstepping the bounds of female propriety by actively pursuing sexual encounters,

disregarding her reputation, and spending freely, she embodies the “lubido” and “luxuria” that is

supplanting “virtus” in Roman society and bringing about its disintegration. For more about Sempronia

see Boyd 1987: 185-6. See also Eud. 1998, Lib. I n. 10.

301

and forbidden love, so that she always had someone distinguished to whom she could

give herself in secret, unbeknownst to her husband. Now, however, having been

widowed from her husband, she indulges herself much more. As much as age has

subtracted from her beauty, to that same degree it has added to her libido. Since on

account of her looks (which are not getting any better) she does not easily fall in love

with those who feel the same way toward her, she holds a few sons of frugal and stingy

fathers in her sway with her riches, which are ample. Even now she is staving off the

destitution of someone or other’s adolescent son who lost his shirt at Janus’s

Exchange.33 There are some, however, who resist and reject her, considering her gifts

not to be worth all that much. As the story goes about one young man, whom she could

not stop sending poorly written letters to, he finally responded thus (I happen to have

one of his letters on me):

CLEOBULUS34 TO PASICOMPSA, I BID YOU TEARS AND BAD WISHES. Wicked

woman, why are you after me, violent and seized by frenzied passion to

your very core, even though, any minute now, you are already so close to

death, so close to your doleful funeral pyre. Like a savage heifer in a

grassy field driven mad by desire, you vainly hasten to bend a bull to your

will, whether he is open to your entreaties or unmoved by your demands.

Your disdain for your lovers and your charms are unbecoming to someone

who is repulsive due to old age; an old woman is busy with the spindle,

the duties of feminine yarn, and the well-worn kitchen. There, among the

cats and dogs, she cleverly tells stories. Since you are worn out from

frequent childbirth, give the sweet citharas, dancers, and tuneful lyres to

tender girls and boys, and keep your bad traits to yourself.

When Pasicompsa had finished reading the letter, her anger reached such a pitch that,

without a doubt, she appeared to everyone to be in a rage and to have lost her mind, to

33 Janus’s Exchange (the Janus medius or Middle Janus) refers to the place in the Forum where bankers

and speculators gathered for business (Platner and Ashby 1929).

34 Both manuscript keys I have consulted (Appendix A) identify Cleobulus as a certain man named

“Santi,” lover of the “duchessa Sforza.” Cleobulus is also a character in Barclay’s Argenis.

302

be threatening Cleobulus in absentia, yelling, and unable to contain her tears. But he

was not moved by her tears or threats any more than if he were made of stone or

wood.”

When he had finished speaking, we entered Gallonius’s house, and we were

welcomed graciously in all aspects, with Pasicompsa’s anger and extravagance

providing an opportunity for delightful conversation. Paulus Aemilius said: “Contempt for

old age fills a woman’s nose with bile. There is nothing more defiant than an immoral

woman. Once she has surrendered her modesty and decency, she will never get it

back, even with a team of four white horses. Wherever Ceres and Bacchus go, chastity

flees as fast as it can. A woman who is on fire with sexual desire is like a sea that no

rivers or streams can fill. The fever of luxury, like fire, is extinguished not by fueling

desire but by taking it away. Women’s insatiability can reduce her many young lovers to

exhaustion; she, however, imposes no limits on herself. If her fierce desire is raging

because of someone’s station or wealth, she will not be held back by any restraints of

duty, laws, or her own reputation. She believes she is allowed to do anything and that

nothing is off-limits. Speeches, chidings, and warnings may as well be stones to the

shameless woman, which may knock out her brains but never instill any good sense.

Any man who is a slave to his sexual desire is to be pitied! Whoever finds himself in

such chains should break free of those fetters, if he can. He who submits to love places

himself in heavy shackles. Chastity is often consistent with an unattractive body; a

debauched man is rarely good looking. The woman who confines her virtue within the

walls of honor should take care that it does not fly away. Honor is like a captive bird

that, when kept in an open cage, flies away never to be captured again. Chastity is a

303

woman’s only mark of honor; if she loses it, she cannot regain it again at any price.

Anyone who desires to obtain something positive from a woman who has lost her

chastity—her chief ornament—is taking the clothes off a naked man’s back.” After he

had finished recounting this and similar things, Paulus Aemilius went off to bed.

Book Two

Tossed about at sea by that endless storm and worn out from the previous day’s

journey, we fell into such a deep sleep that we did not wake up until the sun had risen

and filled everything with light. When we finally got up and left our room, Gallonius

invited us into the gardens of a certain dynast who, as he told it, had risen from the

deepest depths of squalor, both in life and in fortune, into a state of immense wealth. “It

is my understanding,” said Gallonius, “that a sick young man, who is very dear to me, is

being kept there; unless you think otherwise, I would like to go visit him. But you won’t

mind going because there are no gardens in this region that you would consider more

worth seeing.” We indicated our willingness to go and set off with him. While we were

en route, we asked Gallonius why everyone in Eudemia is white if Mauritanians are

black. He responded that, first of all, the island had been cut off for a long time from the

rest of Mauritania and, second, that the women, after intermingling with the Romans,

had given birth to children who looked like their fathers.

After traveling a distance of two miles in conversation about this and other

matters, we arrived at the gardens. We knocked at the gate, it opened, we entered.

When I gazed upon that beautiful sight, it seemed as if it was not just some ordinary

garden that appeared before me, but heaven itself—and even the very kingdom of Jove.

Once the gates opened, the entirety of all creation presented itself on display for our

viewing pleasure. The garden was so beautiful that it was not possible to imagine a

304

more splendid sight. The first thing you see as you enter is a flat expanse of land

surrounded by many walkways decorated by splendid fountains and adorned with

flowers of various kinds. This space houses a theater at the far end with stairways that

are constructed and composed of genuine marble. Many streams bubble up and flow

from each of the stairways and, much like a crowd of theatergoers, they appear to look

toward a fountain in the middle of the theater and to applaud a play with a soothing

murmur simulating favorable acclamation. Stairways made of stone ascend here and

there out of the theater toward an extraordinary artistic marvel: A level and square

expanse supports many trees planted in a quincunx35 formation and is surrounded by

an enclosure covered in royal laurel.36 Impossibly tall plane trees have pride of place in

the middle. Below their treetops stand many smaller trees on both sides, very different

to the planes in height but much the same in dignity and excellence; all royal laurels are

wonderfully beautiful, after all. In the middle under the very tallest plane trees stretches

a marble table that extends almost sixty feet in length and fifteen feet in width. Many

streams of water, flowing gently out and returning back in, divide the table lengthwise

from top to bottom leaving enough space on either side for dining and offering the

dinner guests welcome spring water and coolness. A fountain placed within view offers

delight, astonishing in its very artistry: A figure of Triton made out of marble sits on a

35 A geometric pattern consisting of five points arranged in the form of the letter X, with four of them

forming a square and a fifth at its center, like the five-dot side of dice.

36 Laurus regia (royal laurel) might be a sweet bay (or bay laurel), whose Latin name is laurus nobilis;

since I cannot be sure of the exact identification of this plant, however, I have kept my translation close to

the Latin. Pliny (HN XXXIX.129-30) writes of this plant: “[laurus] regia quae coepit Augusta appellari,

amplissima et arbore et folio, bacis gustatu quoque non asperis. aliqui negant eandem esse et suum

genus regiae faciunt longioribus foliis latioribusque” (“the royal laurel, which has begun to be called the

Augusta laurel, [is] a very large tree with a very large leaf and berries without any rough taste. Some say

that the royal laurel and the Augusta are not the same, and make out the royal to be a special kind, with

longer and broader leaves”; translation from Harvard Loeb edition).

305

crab, as if on horseback, and looks as though he is sounding a note with a horn that is

turned toward his mouth. You would swear you could hear him—such is the artist’s

precision that lends credence to the fiction—were it not for the fact that five streams,

flowing amply from his horn, disabuse your ears of that illusion. Next, between the

crab’s claws (which are capacious enough to hold a very large stream) a large quantity

of water is forced into a shell and poured back out again, through conduits that are

carved into it, into a pool below. This pool, in turn, drives the water through many more

channels into another much larger pool that is placed below that one. Once it fills

completely with water, that pool, following the example of the one above it, carries all

the excess water into a receptacle at ground level that is located in front of the

onlooker’s feet. Finally, two enormous figures representing rivers pour forth veritable

reservoirs of water from urns on each side of that pool complete with a final reward in

the form of ferns, moss, maidenhair ferns, and other sorts of verdant plant-life, which

the moisture below draws out around them. Now the most beautiful—and first and

foremost delightful—place, which demands that a viewer not pass by quickly but linger

and stop in contemplation, seems to beckon a guest to stop where he was about to

linger and to relish the ability to walk around safe from the harmful sun. Many columns

rise up on both sides of the fountain to create two colonnades, which many vine shoots

cover like a roof. Many branches encircle these colonnades on all sides twisting in on

each other, so that the sun’s rays can hardly penetrate through their dense shade. Your

eyes would never be satiated, captivated as they are by this sight and this beauty. They

would never seek out anything better or more perfect, were it not for the fact that the

aforementioned double stairway behind the fountain, built in the form of a triangle,

306

summons those onlookers—delighted for a long time but not fulfilled—to that place

where they can gaze upon the ultimate artistic undertaking.

First there are railings affixed to the front of the stairways—magnificent to

behold—and waters flowing out of various places adorn and embellish the fountain

standing before them. The stairways lead to a place that is full of grand and wonderful

objects. Here art, rivaling itself, is surpassed by itself; here Nature favors the enterprise

of art, its rival, for it is Nature who supplies the streams of water with great force and

abundance and employs them for exhibiting these astonishing works of art. Here

groves, not sprung up by chance but planted with design, extend within a broad field;

over here aviaries, supported by columns, encircle and enclose those groves. In the

portico and entrance of this most splendid place a chain carved out of stone extends

along a sloping surface, through which water flows toward the aforementioned crab with

such artistry that the water, twisted and coiled into many circles, seems to resemble the

links of a chain; in addition, the noise it emits as it flows makes it sound like chains on

account of its force and rapid motion. These chains, drawn out in a long line, connect to

the crab’s claws in such a way that you would think the crab was grabbing hold of them

and hanging on so as not to be carried away. Giant wooden arches, adorned with tightly

clinging ivy, rise up just above the chain into the likeness of a royal palace. You would

point to them as an exemplar for any ambitious artist coming after. These arches are

enclosed by four gabled shrines, along with a large and august temple without gables

that has a fountain in the middle. These look much like burial monuments, round and

wide at the bottom and narrow and pointed at the top; at the uppermost point they

produce water that sprays up out of a bowl. The result is that the whole work appears to

307

be made for the delight of the greatest kings, not just for the pleasure of the person who

commissioned it as an example for other gardens.

After we had thoroughly surveyed the gardens, we entered a villa that was ample

indeed and fully appointed (but was nothing compared to the gardens) where, in a

lovely, bright room beneath a silk canopy, lay a young man who was more corrupted by

luxury than consumed by some sort of illness. Gallonius said to him: “What is this

sickness?” “A fever,” he responded. Gallonius retorted: “Didn’t you just get over a fever

yesterday or the day before? Have you had anything to eat?” While he was saying this

in a loud voice a young woman entered the room, her hair flying everywhere. She

banged her head against the wall and cried: “Poor me, what is this? Why can’t I tackle

this sickness that is weakening you so? What will become of me if you succumb to what

befalls all men?”37 Clearly moved, he said: “Don’t fret about it, or that will add to my

sickness too! The very sight of you robs my illness of all its power.” In order to give him

some respite from his crying and wailing, the woman ordered him up a sumptuous lunch

and gathered many gifts together. Admiring the woman’s kindness, we could have

sworn we were witnessing a tried and true example of extraordinary love, and we asked

the person who was guarding the doors of the room what the relationship was between

the woman and the sick man, whether she was his sister, wife, neighbor, or relative.

“She is none of those,” he said. “She is, above all, a cunning, fawning, deceitful, greedy

whore named Nanna,38 who has been sleeping with him for four months. And he is so

Ragionamento della Nanna e della Antonia (1534) and Dialogo nel quale la Nanna insegna a la Pippa

l’arte puttanesca (1536). Additionally, tales of prostitutes after men’s money, playing lovers off of each
