firmly attached to this filthy love, as if nailed to it, that none of his friends’ reprimanding

or pleading can free him from it. From what I understand, unless he brings himself back

quickly within the bounds of reason (from which he is quite far removed), everything he

owns will disappear in short order, exiled to the whore’s house. And so you can better

understand the character and ways of this whore, listen to this skillful ruse that she used

to snare a merchant over the last few months.

“This merchant was hopelessly in love with her, and he bound her to himself as

his mistress with large sums of money, so she wouldn’t be with anyone else. But as

much as the poor man was burning with love, he was burning in equal amount with icy

jealousy. The shrewd whore Nanna, because she knew that the merchant had taken the

bait (as all people do when they believe someone loves them), worked at nothing harder

than to entrap that poor man and, most significantly, to divert his property to herself,

along with his heart. She used this young man here, whom I serve, to that end. Having

already been in love with her for some time, the young man began stopping by her

house. Because he was handsome, dapper, and charming, the merchant feared him

more than he might a snake. Nanna began to praise the young man’s beauty and to

offer him a lock of her hair; he (poor merchant!) became incensed and threatened the

young man with a knife, which he kept hidden under his cloak, if he took Nanna under

his wing. When the whore noticed that this idle merchant (who was more like a timid

little woman among men than a strong man among women) had a knife, she reckoned

other and employing magical incantations are reminiscent of the dialogue of Zoppino (attributed to

Aretino) where the interlocutors discuss “la vita [e la] geneologia di tutte le cortigiane di Roma” (“the life

and genealogy of all of the courtesans in Rome”). The full text and a translation of this work can be found

in Salkeld 2001: 68-116.

309

that she had hit the jackpot and said to herself: ‘I will be richer than Croesus if he pulls

that knife on me.’ She then sent someone over to the young man to tell him to come to

her house the following night at bedtime, and to knock on the door without hesitation.

“Evening came. Per the well-devised plan, the merchant came to the whore’s

house, dined, and got into an argument because he was complaining that she loved the

young man more than she loved him. She denied it (but only half-heartedly) and sowed

suspicion here and there. The merchant protested and became carried away with rage,

when (what do you know!) the young man conveniently showed up and knocked at the

door. The merchant, vexed by suspicion and fearing an ambush, threw himself out of

bed, flew to the window, and shouted: ‘What sort of hateful person pounds on

someone’s door at this hour of the night?’ ‘It’s me,’ replied the young man. ‘Open up at

once!’ When the merchant recognized the young man, he manifested all the fury in his

heart shouting: ‘Get out of here! And if you don’t hurry up, you’ll be carried away!’

Intending to appear more angry than intent on inflicting harm or punishment, he rushed

at Nanna with his knife drawn. As if anticipating what was going to happen, while he

was at the window complaining about the pounding at the door, she had secretly gotten

out of bed and had filled her right hand with red ink that she had obtained for this very

purpose. The merchant came at her like a madman shouting: ‘Really, you nasty

woman? You dare bring your little lover here, right in front of my eyes?’ And he struck

her right thigh and arm simultaneously with the flat part of his knife. Pressing on with her

tricks, Nanna immediately moved her hand toward her mouth and, at the same time,

tinged it with the red ink screaming: ‘Neighbors, fellow countrymen, please help me!

Come bring aid to a defenseless woman! This evil man has injured my face. What

310

should I do? Who should I turn to? Will I dare show my face, deformed in this way, to

everyone from here on out? I won’t do it—I’ll kill myself!’ This cry rose up out of the

young woman. The neighbors rushed over, broke down the door, and asked what on

earth was going on. Everyone was yelling and running back and forth.

“The poor merchant, who knew that no harm had come to the woman by his

hand, wondered at first why she was bleeding and then, fearing for himself, sought his

own safety by fleeing. Taking advantage of the night to hide himself, he ran into the

palace of a certain dynast, as if into a sanctuary. Reflecting upon the matter at leisure, it

was not completely clear to him how he had caused her wound. He said to himself: ‘As

far as I know, I struck her on her side and on her arm, not on her face, and—what is at

the heart of the matter—not with the edge of my knife but with the flat part. So how did

she get that wound? Or is she faking it? But I saw it with my own eyes. I believe it; after

all, one’s hand does not always go where it’s directed, even when it is intended to do

harm. In that moment I was angry. Rage is blind; it removes good sense and snatches

away reason. What will happen now?’ While he was caught up in these thoughts and

cares, his body trembling with a desire that was vying with fear, he decided to reconcile

himself with the woman using his friends as intermediaries—that is to say, to soften her

up with silver and not to spare any expense. He dispatched suitable men to meet with

her and gave them instructions.

“But that wicked Nanna, in order to keep up her ruse, had slathered her face with

ointments and swathed it with bandages. The men approached her, slowly at first; they

reminded her of the changeability of circumstances, and they praised warring parties

who disband when the opportunity to do so presents itself. The woman did not tolerate

311

their continuing on or pursuing the matter further but exclaimed suddenly: ‘Go on, get

out of here—don’t discuss these matters with me! He will be summoned before all of the

magistrates, I’ll make sure of it. I’ll soon destroy him, if I survive, because he caused me

to be forever disgraced by this mark he put on my face. I should pardon him? Oh

please—I’d rather die!’ ‘Don’t be so angry,’ they replied. ‘This is how things are when

chance more than reason is in control.’ ‘Then the judge will decide,’ declared the

woman. ‘I believe I have clearly made my case to him.’ When the men realized that that

particular line of reasoning had been closed off, they embarked on another. ‘Look,’ they

said, ‘the merchant is generous and averse to conflict. What do you want in exchange

for dropping this entire lawsuit and claim?’ At first she denied that the matter could be

settled with money, then (so the men would up the ante) she raged and made

exaggerated demands. To make a long story short, they got her to agree, with difficulty,

to be satisfied with fifty minae39 to be paid out immediately.

“But Nanna was not satisfied even with that offer. She wanted to ruin the

merchant even more, so she sent someone to him, who claimed it was within his power

to remove the disgraceful blemish caused by her disfigured face which the merchant

had inflicted upon her. The person explained that there was a certain doctor from

Campania who, with his remedies, was able to remove any trace of the wound; but the

merchant needed to pay him with silver, up front, in the amount of five minae. If the

merchant agreed to this, she would be inclined toward him with love and gratitude. The

doctor was a quack, a very practiced swindler, especially in the worthless art of selling

39 The mina was a Greek currency. A silver mina is worth 100 Attic drachmae or Roman denarii (L&S).

This currency often appears in Plautus’s plays.

312

snake oil. The poor merchant, who couldn’t bear his longing for Nanna and didn’t need

to be asked twice, handed over the money without delay, which the braggart

immediately shared with the woman. The merchant was present when Nanna was

healed, and this is how the cunning doctor deceived him: He had pressed strings, taken

from a lyre, on the spot where the whore was feigning her wound. Pressed against her

in just in the right place they looked much like the groove of a scar. In the presence of

the merchant, he smeared the groove with ointment and wrapped it carefully. He

secretly bandaged her up with the lyre strings in such a way, a little looser each day,

that it made the scar seem to disappear little by little. What should I say? Hardly eight

days had gone by before it had all completely disappeared. People had already been

talking about the conspicuous wound Nanna had received to her face when the news

got out about this mysterious doctor’s wondrous cure. He received such a stampede of

people bearing scars that he could not keep them at bay. The swindler did not waste

any time rushing to flee. Since he had already collected money from everyone as a

deposit, he stuffed himself with his takings and, on a certain day before daybreak and

without even giving the order to pack, he pulled up stakes.”

When the chamber servant had finished, he began to relate another of the

whore’s deceptions, but Gallonius interrupted him as he started speaking. As he was

walking away from the young man, Gallonius said to us: “You there, I need to hurry over

to Plusius’s palace40 where I have contracted out my services. The hour has almost

gone when I need to be there to carry out the tasks he hired me to do. His barber invited

40 Alessandro Damasceni Peretti di Montalto’s urban residence was the Palazzo della Cancelleria located

in the Parione neighborhood of Rome between the Campo de’ Fiori and the present Corso Vittorio

Emanuele II. Cardinal Peretti Montalto was famous for his lavish lifestyle (DBI).

313

me to lunch later and asked me to summon anyone else who was suitable, saying that

there would be room for two hangers-on. And so I will take the two of you along. You

will enjoy becoming acquainted with the fine customs of these urbane people, especially

in throwing parties.” “We are all yours,” I said. “Lead us wherever you want.” In short,

we arrived at the palace of that great man. Gallonius went to find out what in the world

his master was up to and whether he was already awake and out of bed. Someone

replied: “Plusius got up a long time ago. He jumped out of bed as soon as it was light

out, called for his barber, and spent two hours with him. But he so wore his poor barber

out with shaving him, bathing him, and putting makeup on his face, that he drove him to

exhaustion, or rather to destruction. After dismissing the barber, Plusius shut himself up

in a more private room with a tailor where he grabbed a drawing-compass in his hands

and tested, as was his habit, whether each of his buttons, which were sewn onto his

clothing with a needle, was equidistant from the others and whether his corselet or

waistcoat was fitting elegantly to his body. Two more hours were consumed in this

project. Then he employed a shoemaker, tormented him, and complained that the

leather his shoes were made out of was not soft enough, did not have any give, and

was tough and unforgiving. Besides that, he complained that the shoes themselves

were not suitable and didn’t look right on his feet. He got angry, yelled, and complained

that he had been born unlucky and that nothing good ever happened to him. But soon, I

hope, even the shoemaker will free his neck from those fetters, because Plusius has

ordered the priests be summoned and the incense and unmixed wine be prepared, in

order to make a sacrifice to Jupiter Optimus Maximus. When that is concluded, we

believe, lunch will commence.”

314

“It’s not a bad idea” said Gallonius, “for me to head to the foyer to await Plusius’s

instructions.” Gallonius led us in, and we each staked out a corner, crooked our necks,

and took in everything that was being said and everything that was going on. The first

question that arose among the dinner guests was which cooking method was most

suitable for chicken in the summer and in the winter. And the dispute was not minimal

because each person had a different preference. The man who was egging these

discussions on (while everyone else contradicted him) preferred fig-pecker birds to

thrush and quail to pheasant. And everyone eagerly ridiculed a certain member of the

group, who seemed to possess no sense in these matters, calling him lowborn and

unrefined. Worse, they said that he wasn’t even worthy of being considered a human

being. From this topic they devolved into slander, and they railed against the character

of women, accusing some of not preserving their modesty honorably, others of

prostituting and selling their bodies—with the full knowledge of their husbands—and still

others of selling their beautiful daughters’ bodies to various men for not insignificant

sums of money. They told many stories besides, identifying each of these women by

name. Since I had never heard of them, however, I immediately forgot them.

The fashion sense of these men was very elegant and stylish, albeit not very

manly, and there was hardly anyone present at the banquet who could not surpass a

new bride in terms of elegance and finery. It was truly ridiculous that, when two of them

started fighting with each other over a woman, one of them (in order to insult him, of

course) called the other a stinking goat, foul, perfidious, and obscene. The other one, in

order to avenge himself at having been provoked, heaped novel insults upon the first

man. Though he tried his best, he was not able to find a fiercer insult than berating him

315

for going around in an uncouth state, unadorned, and with a bad haircut. After we had

eagerly watched this exchange we learned later that nothing was considered a greater

disgrace among these people than not to lace one’s stockings with silk laces that

stretched all the way down to the ground, or to permit even the smallest wrinkle in one’s

collar; that no sin was considered greater than to endure one hair of one’s head or

beard growing longer than the others, and then not to trim with a razor whatever had the

gall to grow longer; that nothing was thought baser than to wear the same outfit for an

entire meal.

But Plusius’s unexpected arrival calmed any anger in these men and put them at

ease. The one who drew back the curtain said cheerfully: “Pencils down, everyone—our

teacher is here!” Crossing the anteroom while everyone walked ahead of him, he

approached the altar of Jove, assisted the person who was conducting the sacrifice,

came back, and demanded his luncheon, which Gallonius had made sure was furnished

with all the trimmings. After Plusius had eaten his fill, Gallonius came over to us and

said: “The man who invited me to lunch has ordered dining couches be set up in the

gardens near the city next to an abundantly flowing fountain. By Hercules, you will

surely take pleasure in the sight of that place. It is very beautiful on account of the

greenery of the trees, and very cool thanks to the abundance of flowing waters.”

To be brief, he took us there, and upon entering we were met with more water

than we could recall ever having seen. Indeed, the entire place was overflowing not with

fountains but with rain showers, not with streams but with rivers. Nature or engineering

(it is uncertain which) had carved six caves, pleasantly and delightfully wild and faced

with rough and rugged tufa, into the cliff on the hill, and this had been done in such a

316

way that the second set of three caves sat above the first. From these tufa rocks—

which clung both inside and outside of the caves and were covered with plants of

varying shades of green—powerful showers of water poured forth, filling the caves and

creating a wide lake in front of them. Walls, which were rough and covered with rocks to

match the wild ruggedness of the caves, rose up on either side of the hill to define the

limits of the site. Raging waters flowed continuously through the walls and behind them,

within the wide groves, were located marvelous tree-lined walkways. There we heard

the sound of many streams falling from a great height and we beheld this spectacle that

was created by fountains, groves, art, and, finally, by Nature herself. Next to that

beautiful fountain, so marvelous and so cool, we came upon dining couches that had

been set up and a laid table piled high with the kind of variety of sumptuous dishes that

is generally furnished by those wishing to entertain their friends in a splendid manner.

Then, suddenly, a great noise and din reached our ears. Our lunch hosts

informed us that the other invited guests had arrived. We were nine in number, but from

the ruckus you would have sworn there were a hundred of us invading that place. As

soon as the guests appeared they laid waste to everything (as invading forces do once

a city has been captured) devouring, stuffing themselves, draining jugs of wine, and

throwing everything into confusion with their battle cry. The man who had invited

everyone was nearing the point of anger, shouting that everyone needed to wash their

hands and take their places at the dining couches; and he succeeded, with great

difficulty, in getting them to agree to sit down. There were three couches, and we

reclined four to a couch. Gallonius was seated at the highest couch with me next to him,

317

Paulus Aemilius was seated at the middle couch, and everyone else at the low couch.41

While at the table we consumed as much wine as is collected during an entire vintage

season. If it were possible to count the stars in the sky, that is the number of cups of

wine that were brought to the table and drained. There were five men serving us who

were worn out from filling and fetching wine glasses. The banqueters let rip burps and

farts to accompany their great cries and effusive laughter. The only words we heard

were: “Cheers to me, cheers to you, cheers to our Plusius!” They appeared to be

pouring wine not into their stomachs but into drains, or into an abyss. Some delicious

dish would barely have been placed on the table before you would see it get snatched

up. There was an extremely refined man in our midst who was garlanding his cup with

bits of what he had been eating, as if they were roses, and whenever he filled it with

wine he would guzzle the whole lot down. We were loud, we laughed raucously, and we

applauded the glorious event with exclamations of approval. The feast went on almost

into the evening with no moderation or diminution of drinking. Then one of Plusius’s

servants arrived and announced to Gallonius that he should leave everyone and go

quickly over to the magistrate, and that he should explain to him, in Plusius’s words, that

the magistrate, on account of his high status, should release Toxillus42 and return him

unharmed. Toxillus had been found guilty and had been thrown in jail for plundering an

inheritance bequeathed to Venus, bearing false witness, and committing various other

nefarious acts contrary to what was lawful and right. We were thus drawn away from the

41 A Roman dining room (triclinium) consisted of group of three couches where guests would sit according

to their status. The host (or host family) reclined on the lowest couch (imus lectus), especially honored

guests reclined on the middle couch (medius lectus), and the high couch (summus lectus) was for low-

status guests.

42 Toxilus is the name of a slave in Plaut. Pers.

318

other revelers and we made our way to the tribunal of the magistrate, who was busy

with a certain important judicial investigation.

The magistrate’s attendants had dragged a young woman into court—not a bad

looking one—who they were saying was a prostitute. They were complaining that she

had caused them to be soundly beaten with cudgels and, so that we would believe

them, they showed us their arms and backs, which were black and blue with blows. The

magistrate asked who was so bold in his audacity as to trouble public officials with such

a remarkable wrongdoing on account of a single whore. One man responded, who was

perhaps better able to speak than the rest: “We were in the process of dragging a thief

off to jail, whom we had caught red-handed. When we were passing the place where

this witch lives, he freed himself from his chains, escaped our grasp, and ran into one of

the houses on her street. We chased after him and, because we couldn’t see where he

had gone, we searched every single house in that neighborhood. In brief, we arrived at

the whore’s house and knocked on the door. When nobody answered, we assailed the

door with our feet so hard that it broke. Still nothing. So we went upstairs and found the

woman lying on her bed. Then I said: ‘Why aren’t you saying anything? Why did you let

us break down your door? Was it so important to keep it closed?’ She remained silent.

Then I said: ‘Look how your mind holds firm, bent on not speaking. You villain. I will

drag words out of you, whether you like it or not.’ Enraged, I attacked her violently with a

switch. Compelled by the pain, she finally cried ‘Hey!’ And then an incredible thing

happened. Barely had she yelled ‘Hey,’ when you could feel blows of a cudgel attacking

us on our shoulders, heads, and arms, like a rain- or hailstorm—but there were no

319

cudgels in sight, and there was nobody hitting us! Petrified with fear and badly beaten,

we turned tail and ran quickly down the stairs seeking safety on foot.’”

The magistrate asked the men how they thought this had happened. They

answered him confidently that they thought they had experienced this because of

women’s magic and incantations. They said: “You can learn what happened from this

woman here, whom we brought before you as a witness to this matter.” She, as we

inferred from her appearance, was a two-bit whore, a dish for the whole village. Looking

at the magistrate she said: “If you can guarantee my protection, I will reveal the entire

matter as it is.” The woman, having been called upon by the magistrate, explained what

she knew: “Whenever our lovers leave us,” she began, “we prostitutes toss a piece of

bread and cheese out the window, and we cast a spell of certain curses on it in order to

summon them back. But if a black dog approaches the piece of bread to eat it, we

consider it to be a good and auspicious omen that the man we desire will soon appear.

In the meantime, though, until he comes (unless she is asking for trouble), the prostitute

must not utter a single word. If she dares to speak she will bring misfortune upon

herself. This good woman came to my house the day before, complaining because her

lover was deeply angry with her. She had taken another lover without his knowledge,

and, because of this, she had transferred her love and gifts to another man. She

begged and pleaded for my help and for me to show her how she could get him back.

Taking pity on her, so she wouldn’t return to the state from which she had risen

(doubtless on the verge of poverty), I offered her some bread and cheese that I had put

a spell on, and I told her to throw it down into the street. She took it, threw it down, and

a dog came and ate it. Then she closes the door, gets into bed, and waits for her lover

320

to come, since now the only thing left to happen was for him to arrive. Indeed, he would

have certainly come to her as she desired, if Fortune, who throws everything into

confusion, had not prohibited it.”

After the whore had recounted these things, she fell silent. Then the magistrate

ordered the other woman (who had been tied up) to speak. She brazenly responded

that she had never seen firewood given away so freely as it had been to her and the

lictors.43 The praetor asked who did this. She responded that she believed the deed had

been carried out by the spirits of the dead. To which the praetor said: “So you are a

witch.” The woman, crafty and trained to malice, replied: “Not at all, except that I am too

much the victim of the magic of other women. It is coming up on a year that I have been

harassed by ghosts on account of a certain witch’s jealously. It often happens that, after

being tormented with beatings meant to kill me, I am carried out of the house like a

corpse at the hands of my neighbors.” When he heard this, the magistrate ordered that

the neighbors be called as witnesses to the case. They came straight away, but

because of her ties to the neighborhood, and in order to curry the woman’s favor and to

save her from the peril of a conviction, the neighbors, after they had been sworn in,

gave the same testimony the prostitute had given in her own defense. The magistrate

was turned from severity to mercy, he absolved the woman (who was mad or crazed),

and, with the approval of his legal counsel, he suspended her hearing and ordered the

lictors to go hang. After the council was dismissed, the praetor withdrew from the

courtroom where he had been attending to the trial, and took himself off to his house.

43 That is, beaten (with a wooden cudgel) so soundly. For the source of this phrase see Chapter 2, n. 103.

321

In Eudemia, criminal proceedings are not carried out in the Forum, as is the

practice in Rome, but they take place in the magistrates’ homes. Gallonius demanded to

be taken to the magistrate, because he had something that he needed to tell him, on

Plusius’s orders. The chamber servants brought him to the magistrate, who, as soon as

he heard that an emissary from Plusius had arrived, immediately ordered him to be

admitted. He asked for chairs and invited Gallonius to sit down, which Gallonius, of

course, declined on account of his modesty. The magistrate insisted saying that he

would otherwise not listen to what Gallonius had to say. Gallonius acquiesced, settled

into a chair, and relayed his orders from Plusius, of which the most important was this:

that the defendant Toxillus, whom the magistrate was holding in prison, had been

accused of fraudulently plundering the inheritance of another; that the magistrate should

be sure to absolve him with his judicial decision; and that, because of this favor, he

would enter Plusius’s good graces. The magistrate responded that the prisoner was the

chief of villains, that he had committed a manifest, capital, and heinous crime, and he

said: “If there is a place for justice and laws, he ought to have been dragged off to his

punishment a long time ago and onto a cross. Since he is so important to Plusius,

however, I will find a justification for him to escape judgment unharmed. This matter

regards Venus’s property and, if some of it is taken, it is to be removed without penalty.

The gods are good and generous; even if they suffer an injury, they do not know how to

get angry at anyone.” In brief, the magistrate promised his aid even more earnestly than

was demanded of him. In order to move his thoughts from the sadness of this

conversation to cheerfulness, he began to ask how Plusius was doing, what sorts of

pleasures he spent his afternoons engaged in, how many glasses of wine he drank,

322

how capacious the tankard he drank out of was, and many other questions of this sort,

to which Gallonius responded very satisfactorily.

When evening fell, Gallonius got up to leave. The magistrate, out of a sense of

duty, accompanied Gallonius as far as the stairs reminding him repeatedly to pass

along his greetings to Plusius. At last, Gallonius, after being respectfully received and

dismissed, happily hit the road with us back home. He came to the front door of a

certain old friend, and, after exchanging salutations, he inquired how he was doing. The

friend replied: “There is a quarrel between the magistrate and the wealthy Asterius.44 I

am off to work things out between them.” “What is this I hear?” said Gallonius. “Asterius

is capable of getting angry? I always thought of him as being as calm as a sea that has

been allayed for the hatching of kingfisher chicks.”45 “To be sure, Asterius has returned

to his old self,” the friend replied. “Now the magistrate is the only one who is angry and

all worked up. Listen to this ridiculous story. Asterius had a disagreement with Robustus

Ursaceus46 before the centumvirs47 regarding a financial matter, and he bound him over

by bail to appear in court. The terms of the bail stipulated that Ursaceus present himself

44 There are various suggestions for who is behind this astral pseudonym. Giachino (2002: 201) proposes

Francesco Stelluti (1577-1652) an Italian scientist and founding member of the Accademia dei Lincei.

Both manuscript keys (referred to in Appendix A) propose Giovanni Battista de Asti (1566-1620) a Roman

Catholic prelate who served as Titular Bishop of Thagaste. Portraits in Rossi’s Pinacotheca suggest two

other possibilities: the poet Giulio Cesare Stella (1564-1624) or, more likely, Giovanni Battista Stella (d.

1621), who was an accomplished Latin writer both in poetry and prose, and who enjoyed a successful

legal and ecclesiastical career achieving the position of Referendary within the papal court and eventually

becoming the bishop of Bitonto in Apulia.

45 The kingfisher, or halcyon, was said to hatch its eggs in a period during the winter when the seas were

particularly calm, a tranquil period known as the “halcyon days.”

46 Possibly Fulvio Orsini (1529-1600) an Italian humanist, historian, and archaeologist, or Alessandro

Orsini (1592-1626) an Italian cardinal and patron of Galileo Galilei. Rossi devotes portraits to both in his

Pinacotheca, the latter in Pinacotheca altera.

47 A college of judges chosen annually to hear civil suits, in particular matters of inheritance.

323

in court on a certain day to hear the judges’ ruling. Ursaceus disregarded his court date,

and, because of this, the so-called scofflaw was convicted, and the judicial opinion was

ruled in Asterius’s favor. Ursaceus appealed the ruling to the magistrate, who

immediately declared that the judges had ruled incorrectly because Ursaceus had

promised, per the terms of his bail, only to present himself in court that day but not to

hear the judges’ ruling; and that for him to hear the judges’ ruling, he would have to be

compelled by a new order to appear. Asterius protested and explained that the force of

the order was achieved by its wording, which stated that Ursaceus present himself in

court to hear the ruling of the judges. The good magistrate declared that he would find

no wrongdoing because, in the written order, the words ‘hear the judges’ ruling’ were

not connected to the words ‘present himself,’ but were separated by punctuation.

Therefore, since the words ‘hear the judges’ ruling,’ taken individually, constituted a new

sentence, they indeed required a new order to appear. Shaken by such a blatant

wrongdoing, Asterius set his sights on revenge and, after a few days, he wrote a letter

to the magistrate with these words: ‘I entreat you, praetor sir, to come to my house

tomorrow; dine with me.’ The next day the praetor arrived at the appointed time.

Asterius said to him: ‘I thank you for coming, but dinner is not until tomorrow.’ ‘What’s

this?’ said the magistrate, ‘You did not invite me today?’ ‘No,’ replied Asterius. ‘But I can

show you your letter in which you invited me to dinner today.’ ‘Let me see the letter,’

said Asterius, and he read the letter he was holding in his hand. ‘There is no error on

my part, since I wrote the letter thus: I put a punctuation mark after the words ‘I entreat

you to come to my house tomorrow’; because the other word ‘dine’ is the beginning of a

new sentence, it indicates a different day. So you have to wait for a separate invitation.’

324

Angered, the magistrate said ‘Will you make fun of a magistrate in this way? You will

hardly get away with this without being punished.’ ‘I have caused you no injury, this is

entirely your doing. This is an example of a ruling you yourself made where you

determined that it should be punctuated this way. But every law proclaims that the same

rule that anyone maintains against another should also be applied to himself.’ The

praetor, having been played in this way (which really steamed him), returned home

without any dinner.”

We laughed at the magistrate’s dull acumen. Then I said: “Is there such a

shortage of prudent men in Eudemia that you need to entrust these sorts of duties to

dullards like him?” Gallonius replied: “It is not surprising, since in this Republic it is not

virtue or good deeds that win magistracies and honors, but chance and favors. Thus,

since the learned and illustrious are overlooked, governing power is allotted to ignorant

and insignificant men.” When we were done we set off, Gallonius to reconcile Asterius

and the magistrate and we to alleviate the sound of our growling stomachs with food

and drink.

Book Three

The sun had already risen joyfully from the ocean and brightened the land by

diffusing its light across the entire sky, when Gallonius received the news that two

young men were at the door urgently calling for him. We accompanied him as he went

outside. When he asked what they wanted they replied: “You must hurry to your good

friend Democritus’s house and make sure, either by comforting him, advising him, or by

taking some sort of action, to free him from the illness that has vehemently taken hold of

him. He didn’t eat anything yesterday evening, and he didn’t get a moment’s rest last

night. When asked what the matter was he didn’t dare say; he just sighed and wept.

325

Perhaps, in the name of your mutual friendship, you can get him to tell you why he is so

sick.” To which Gallonius replied: “Tell Democritus we will be there soon.” But Gallonius

thought it best to call a doctor and bring him over to the sick man’s house. So we

arrived at the home of a certain Aristarchus,48 who (as Gallonius informed us) was

renowned among doctors, and we caught him contemplating his appearance in the

mirror. As soon as he saw Gallonius he said: “How does my face look to you?” “Most

pleasing and handsome indeed,” replied Gallonius. “And what about my physique? See

how firm, nimble, and full of energy it is? Is there any woman worthy of this body?”

“None,” replied Gallonius. “But put that aside for the moment and listen to why we are

here. We have come to take you to a sick man, who has almost been undone by an

illness of his mind, so you can heal him.” “That would be easy enough,” replied

Aristarchus, “but I don’t have time right now, since I promised my services to the head

flamen49 of Father Liber who has been suffering from stomach problems.” “If that is the

situation,” responded Gallonius, “I would be causing harm to the welfare of the Republic

if I disturbed you. Goodbye.”

After we took our leave, we asked Gallonius whether or not it was reasonable for

someone, in order to cure a sick person, to go to the trouble of summoning a doctor

whose own mind could hardly be cured by three Antikyras.50 Gallonius smiled and said:

“The state of stupidity in which that man dwells is indeed amusing and absurd. Though

48 Pompeio Caimo (1568-1631) was an Italian doctor who, starting in 1602, served as the personal

physician of Rossi’s patron Cardinal Alessandro Damasceni Peretti di Montalto. Rossi devotes a portrait

to Caimo in his Pinacotheca.

49 Flamen: a priest of one particular diety.

50 Antikyra: a town on the coast of Phocis (a region of ancient Greece) famous for hellebore, a plant that

was supposed to cure madness.

326

he is so irregular and so ugly in appearance—as you saw—that he is more monster

than man, he nevertheless boasts that he is more handsome than Adonis and Paris,

and he says that women everywhere willingly pursue him. Forgetting that he is an old

man, he doesn’t consider any youthful activities to be off-limits to him. He loves, drinks,

sings, dances, and although he is gray-haired, knock-kneed, hunchbacked, big-

mouthed, stocky, dark, and has bad breath, he (amazingly) bests many excellent young

men in the contest of love—his only weapon being money, which, along with his other

assets, improves both his social standing and his looks. This mark of folly is

compensated by dint of his many great virtues. He is an eminent philosopher, physician,

poet, and orator, and if he visited this sick person, whom we are on our way to see, he

would immediately diagnose what kind of illness he has and would prescribe a fitting

cure for it.”

While we were discussing these things and laughing, we arrived at the sick

man’s house. When we entered, we saw him looking pale, gloomy, and deep in thought.

Gallonius asked him why he was so confounded and pale. “Because,” he replied, “I am

consumed by an extraordinary, unparalleled, and bitter grief in my soul.” Gallonius

asked whether he had committed some serious crime for which he feared receiving

judgment and punishment. He said he had not. Gallonius asked whether he had

incurred a debt so large that he couldn’t pay it off. He denied this as well. Gallonius

pressed on, inquiring whether he had cosigned a loan for another person, or whether he

had suffered a loss of his family’s estate because of fire, shipwreck, or catastrophe. “It is

nothing of the sort,” he responded. “Out with it,” said Gallonius. “What is causing you

such misery?” “It’s simply that I feel like old age is already upon me and, as a

327

consequence, that death is drawing near. This worry has penetrated so deeply into my

thoughts that I cannot shake it. It’s pressing so hard on my mind that I can find no

relief.” Then Gallonius exclaimed: “Off with you to where you deserve to go with that

absurd foolishness of yours! Certainly, if there were a king of all idiots who ever existed

anywhere on earth, in my opinion nobody would surpass you.” The man took exception

to this: “To be sure, it is now you, sir, who are driving me mad. Do you think it’s insane

to ponder the troubles of old age and to tremble at the inevitability of death that

follows?” Gallonius replied: “Tell me, what do you accomplish by worrying and fretting?

Does it enable you to avoid old age and death? You don’t delay old age, even the

slightest bit, by tormenting and torturing yourself and by making yourself the most

miserable of all miserable men; rather you bring old age and death on sooner. So why

do you insist on being miserable when there is no point to it? Why don’t you put aside

this worry that is tormenting you and happily grasp the gifts of the present moment?”

“How can I be happy while thinking about my death?” he protested. “Woe is me,

whenever I think about the time that will soon be upon me when I am at death’s door.”

“What if death takes you before you reach old age?” asked Gallonius. “Who can ever be

sure that he will live until the evening?” “You’re right,” the man said. “Indeed, if death

can hear me, let him come free my mind of this anguish.”

Gallonius exclaimed: “This man deserves to be shackled with heavy chains! You

want what you fear, yet you hope that the thing that is causing you worry will bring an

end to your worries. First, explain to me whether you consider death to be good or bad.

If it’s good, why are you anxious? If it’s bad, why do you think that it will bring about the

end of bad things? A thing cannot be counted as bad if it puts an end to bad things. As

328

God is my witness, how I pity your foolishness. Since you were bound to go insane, at

least a type of insanity befell you that is happy, witty, and cheerful. You should therefore

seek out happiness for yourself and prepare entertainments for us, instead of creating

trouble for the both of us, as you are currently doing.” Then the man said: “What? Are

you making fun of me? Are you the only one who is so sound of mind that you lack just

about any trace of foolishness? You are mistaken. There is no intelligence so great that

it doesn’t leave room for some measure of foolishness.” Gallonius answered him saying:

“I concede the point to you. Moreover, I do not regret my own foolishness (whatever sort

it is that I am now engaged in), since I observe that others are trapped in a sort of

foolishness that is even more wretched and troublesome. But if you insist on being

foolish, I don’t see what limit or end there will be to your foolishness. Although time

heals other illnesses, the sickness that is connected to your getting older will grow

greater by the day; and as much as is added to your years, that same amount will also

be added to your pointless distress.” Then the man said: “Leave me to my misery and

don’t add any more troubles to those my illness is already causing.” Gallonius

responded: “Since we have troubled you with our interruption, we will do as you wish.

We will take our leave. But I caution you not to send for me in the future, because you

will have summoned me in vain. And since you delight in misery, I pray to god that you

will always be miserable.”

Without saying another word, Gallonius rushed outside and turned his attention

to showing us the important sites of the city such as sacred temples, theaters,

colonnades, marketplaces, gymnasiums, and private homes. One of these homes was

large and stately and displayed the following words out front carved in large letters:

329

The master of this house bestows no benefit, favor, or money on those

who work here, other than their pay. Let this be stated in advance lest they

later complain that they have been deceived.

To which I remarked: “I praise the frank and open nature of a man who doesn’t tolerate

anyone, who might be seized by some vain hope, wasting his energy at his house.”

Gallonius replied: “You would be even more convinced of that if you knew how well he

keeps his promises. Although, as you see, he openly reveals his true self, nevertheless

it is incredible to recount how many rich people from noble households seek this house

out whenever word gets around that his household staff is in need of additional

members. The dynasts are so revered here that everyone thinks it an honor to dedicate

himself to their service, even without such a hope. Everyone believes, however, that

both fortune and prosperity conspire against whomever either will or fate pushes to join

their household.”

A wail and a cry interrupted him as he was speaking and, when we turned

around, we saw a rag seller in the Forum of Cupid selling his cheap wares to the crowd:

This poor man fills the air with dreadful sounding complaints and rends his

bare chest with his fierce hand; his son weeps, as do his daughters with

their sad brother; his excited dog barks at the top of its lungs. It seems as

if fierce Brennus himself has cruelly set fire to Roman houses51 or that

Troy and the ancient riches of Priam’s father, King of Troy, has been

overcome by the trickery and the sword of the Greeks and the Dolopes.52

Then, because there has been entirely too much disturbance, the entire

neighborhood protests and rushes to offer help the afflicted man asking:

‘Where are the thieves? Where is the horrible mob, the robbers who

51 Brennus was the chieftain of a Gallic tribe who led an army of Gauls to sack Rome. They captured

most of the city and held it for several months setting many buildings on fire.

52 In the accounts of the Fall of Troy, Virgil is the only author who mentions the Dolopes, which he does

four times in book two of the Aeneid (Paschalis 1997: 99).

330

plundered your home?’ What did they find that ignited such chaos in the

old man? A quarter of an as,53 which a boy thief carried off.

The rag seller’s wife was not among the crowd of mourners. They said that she

had confined and locked herself up in her home with some shopkeeper whom she, with

her husband’s knowledge, had attached to herself as a bodyguard and companion; and

that she had done so because of some apprehension or other, or certain pointless

fears, which she was afraid would take hold of her while her husband was tied up with

his business commitments in the public square. Because of this, she feared nothing

more than being alone. But the shopkeeper, aroused by the rag seller’s cries, was

agitated indeed and was reluctantly torn away from the woman’s side. He ran to the

forum to protect his colleague’s belongings and his own life, just as he had been

protecting his colleague’s wife. He arrived, pushed himself into the crowd, inquired

about the cause of the disturbance, and discovered that this whole crowd of people had

formed because a thief had made off with a quarter of an as. Therefore, freed from a

great worry, he fished a drachma out of his pouch and gave it to the rag seller. Happy

that his quarter had been replaced by a drachma, the rag seller returned to his

interrupted work, and the shopkeeper returned to guarding the fearful wife.

The rag seller had another rival too, a young man who was still under his father’s

legal control. This young man was desperately in love with the same woman, but his

father’s stinginess and the lex quinavicenaria54 ensured that he had nothing to offer her.

He had no other option than to feast his eyes on her, follow her, and betake himself

repeatedly to the temples of the gods. And it didn’t so much annoy him that the woman

53 as: a copper coin of negligible value.

54 Under Roman law, sons could not legally enter into contracts until twenty-five years of age.

331

wasn’t his, as much as it irked him that she belonged to another. If given the choice, he

would have opted to live his entire life without her rather than to suffer her spending a

single day with another man. For this reason, beset simultaneously by love and

jealously, he kept trying to lead the shopkeeper to suspect his rival, the rag seller, of

adultery. He used these words preferring to present himself as righteous rather than

hateful:

What strange and laughable naiveté is this, husband, to place your wife

and her lover together? When evening beckons you home, don’t you see

the traces of this stranger in your bed? Everyone is talking about it. Don’t

you hear the gossip, don’t you see that everyone’s eyes are turned toward

your shameful actions? Only a stupid and gutless lover would allow

convenient meeting times to slip away in vain. The Trojan guest laid claim

to the daughter of Tyndareus55 while her husband hurried to set sail for

Crete with favorable winds. But if your wife’s beauty frightens you, entrust

her to me. Only then, my good man, will you be safe. You will be able to

set out for whatever faraway lands you wish, and you shall fear no

treachery. My head will sooner leave this neck of mine than violate your

sacred marriage. It is not beneath me to keep perpetual watch outside

your dear doorway; I am not reluctant to get into a fight. Whether the

freezing air resounds with the swift North winds, or a sudden rainstorm

pours down copious water, I am not unwilling to bear the harsh

inconveniences of winter, nor am I unwilling to lay my tired body upon the

bare ground. My drawn sword will guard my side, and its concern will not

be lessened by long-lasting toil. Wherever my feet take me, I will follow

her, whether she expresses a wish to visit the temples of the Gods, or

whether she desires to return home.

The rag seller didn’t tolerate him speaking any longer, but said: “With a single

action, I will put an end to the efforts of two people: you talking, and me listening. I don’t

put any more stock in your fancy words and promises than I do in bird feathers or

dandelion seeds.56 They won’t make me even one penny richer. I don’t need anyone

55 Helen of Troy.

56 The Latin is pappos volantes; L&S translates pappus as the “wooly, hairy seed of certain plants.” I

chose to translate this as “dandelion seeds” because of the image evoked when the seeds are blown on

and fly away.

332

guarding my wife’s flank from foreign invaders because my house is full of such guards.

But I do need someone to bring those guards money and rations. And, as you know,

when the person you are trying to make me jealous of comes to my house, he never

comes empty-handed. He brings bags of money, piles of wheat, meats, cheeses, and

sacks of olives with him. Therefore, as long as he is useful to me, I’d rather he stay. You

can go look for someone else to guard—I dismiss guards like you.” While he was

making fun of the young man, he turned his back on him.

Gallonius then said: “I think we should go home because after lunch I plan to

take you to the house of a certain nobleman where, every fortnight, many learned men

gather to practice and show off their talents. But, in regard to that nobleman, do not

suppose that there is anyone more perfect than he in terms of physical or mental

qualities. As a boy (and he was by far the most handsome of his generation) he sought

out friendships with scholars, and, once obtained, he maintained them faithfully. He was

so devoted to the intellectual practice of those learned men that he saw fit to convene

and establish out of that group an organization called an academy.57 Since there is no

organization that can maintain itself without a leader, a single person was put in charge

of that academy, who was connected to it like the head is to the limbs on a body.

According to their ancient custom, these intellectuals are bound, even today, to convene

at this nobleman’s house, where you will also see his two sons who are outstanding in

age, intelligence, and looks, but even more illustrious in their wisdom and uprightness.

Their father did not raise them according to the habits that are currently in vogue, but

according to the best and most venerable traditional education, meaning that the boys

57 A reference to the Academia Humoristarum, or Accademia degli Umoristi.

333

are never found partaking in any of the vices that are typically associated with

adolescence. Indeed, their entire education is lauded as exemplary and worthy of a

nobleman who, at leisure from more difficult tasks such as work, does not give himself

over to listlessness and pleasures, but devotes himself instead to these most delightful

studies, as if entering a garden, and to this most noble form of diversion. On the days

that they convene their gathering of learned men, each of the participants comes up to

the podium and recites, before the other academy members who are seated directly

below him, a passage of prose, a poem, or something of that sort that is worthy of

learned ears. After each person has had a turn, the head of the academy solicits songs

or epigrams as if requiring payment from his guests, and they recite aloud something

they have just composed on the spot. Since the two of you are devoted to this most

tasteful kind of study, I will bring you along with me. Everyone is welcome. But for now,

in the meantime, make yourselves at home and wait for me to return. I have to bring my

dynast some things he needs so his lunch can be prepared. We will eat the leftovers

later.”

Gallonius left and came back. On his way back, he ran into someone he knew.

That man had clung to his side and Gallonius had not been able to shake him off, even

after he had already arrived at home. Holding fast to him the man said: “I am eating

lunch at your house today.” Gallonius, by way of brushing him off, said “You must be

teasing and joking with me. I’ll be damned if I went shopping for your sake.” “No need,”

he replied. “It’s all planned; I am supposed to be here today.” As he was talking, he put

down his coat, removed his sword from around his waist, took off his shoes, and went to

recline at the table. Gallonius (it is hard to keep on fighting once you have been

334

defeated) threw up his hands and gave in. “Have it your way,” he said, “but you will be

received in such an informal manner that you will regret having come.” So as not to

seem as if Gallonius was inviting him unwillingly, the man showed his face and started

laughing. The man’s dishonesty and gluttony were evident in the way he grabbed

everything single thing that looked best, shoved it in his mouth, devoured it, and filled

himself with wine. After he had eaten his fill and gotten himself drunk, he took his feet

off the couch, put his shoes on, asked for his cloak and sword, arranged them on his

shoulder and around his waist, and, after saying goodbye to Gallonius, he left. After he

had gone, we passed the afternoon in conversation on various topics. Admiring the

impudence and voracity of the man, I couldn’t contain myself from asking what sort of

man would come over to destroy another person’s meals with such force. Gallonius

replied: “He is from this very town and contracts his services to the same dynast as I do.

But if you judge men like that, who spend time at court, by their appearance and dress,

they will seem like they have a lot of money; but if you take a good look at their assets,

you will find that they are emptier than a hollow nut. I tolerate him weaseling lunches out

of me more out of a sense of pity than because I feel forced to. Maybe that poor man

has nothing to eat at home. Since we have relaxed enough, I think we should set off to

where we planned to go.”

After this brief digression we arrived at the nobleman’s house. It was situated in

the most crowded and densely inhabited part of the city where, during certain hours of

the day, most members of the nobility bustle about to and fro for their own amusement.

The name of the master of the house was carved in capital letters on the front of the

335

palace: LUCIUS MINUCIUS SINISTER.58 A fountain stood before us as we entered, situated

in the middle of a most elegant garden. A figure of Pegasus, carved out of marble and

flanked by Phoebus and the Muses, was beating the earth with his hoof and sending a

large quantity of water up into the air.59 There was an epigram at the base of this

sculpture group, written by the scholar Aridus,60 in honor of the master of the house:

That there may be a place here—where the air resounds sweetly with

swan-song, where Lucius establishes a new Helicon,61 and where

Pegasus’s hard hoof brings forth a spring, famous for its leaping waters—

where you, Muses, and you, proud Phoebus with your tortoiseshell lyre,

may raise your master to the heavens, whenever he is oppressed by an

extraordinary burden: this is the purpose of your art, Phoebus and

Pierides.

After we had sufficiently feasted our eyes on that pleasing and beautiful sight, we

arrived in a great hall that was decorated and filled on all sides with paintings chiefly

honoring the academy’s tutelary deity.62 Another painting depicted a virgin goddess

sitting atop many books and holding a trumpet in her left hand, and at her feet lay two

dead monkeys. The virgin represented the academy and the dead monkeys, in turn,

represented academies that had been established to emulate the academy that we

were visiting, but had died out in short order due to unlucky auspices.63 On either side of

the great hall hung paintings depicting two illustrious members of the academy, one of

members decorated the rest of the walls. Through these emblems each academy

member, with the addition of a brief motto, endeavored to demonstrate and call

attention to the benefits accrued to him from his academic contributions. The emblems

were so fitting and so elegant that there was no way we could sate or fill our spirits and

our eyes by examining them.67

Because a crowd was starting to gather, we went and sat down, fearing that the

man caught our eye. He was running around here and there asking this person to come

in, talking in that person’s ear, leading another person to his seat, intercepting another

person, and not pausing for even a little bit. I asked who that man was, who was so

busy and restless that he never stopped moving. Gallonius told me that he was a

certain Salvius Tifernas,68 a colleague of Lucius Minucius, upon whose care and

diligence the weight of the entire academy depended. He signified only one thing to the

academy: τὰ πάντα.69 He told me that they praised Tifernas especially for the

enthusiasm with which he sought out and recognized each scholar, embraced him in

friendship, maintained each one’s regard for him through his attentiveness, and

obligated everyone to himself with his services and favors. Because of this he neglected

his own affairs, while taking care of everyone else’s, and was just about reduced to

poverty. But it is everyone’s firm opinion that the academy exists today solely because

of his effort and diligence. He frequently goes around to the house of every single

academy member to greet him, bring him here, and accompany him back home. He

single-handedly sees to it that these scholarly gatherings are well attended.

While Gallonius was talking, Salvius appeared out of nowhere and was reading

to a man named Cuminus, who had a dark face and black hair and was holding a

writing tablet in his hands. “What did you think of that speech in which Obtusus praised

nothing?” “It was elegant and pleasing,” he replied. “But I am glad he decided to come

here, especially on my account. I used to worry that I was considered to be worth

CUMINUS TO OBTUSUS, GREETINGS. I used to become aggrieved and red in

the face if anyone said I was nothing. Now, Obtusus, since your writings

praise nothing, I am neither sorry nor ashamed to be nothing. But may I

drop dead if you would prefer to be utterly nothing, even though you have

the ability to be either Caesar or nothing.

When he had finished writing, he handed the tablet to Salvius who, in his usual hurried

manner, made sure to take it to Obtusus and then bring it back. We, on the other hand,

were seized by a strong desire to get to know everyone, and we wanted to know what

kind of a person this Cuminus was. We found out that he was learned in Greek and

Latin, and that he spoke Greek so well that he seemed to know no other language.

70 “Aut Caesar aut nihil” (“either Caesar or nothing” or “all or nothing”) was a motto adopted most

famously by the Italian nobleman, politician, and cardinal Cesare Borgia (1475-1507).

71 The following poem is the first of a series of paradoxical encomia (poems in praise of mundane or

unexpected subjects) recited at this gathering. Paradoxical encomia on the topic of nothing (de nihilo)

have existed since the middle ages (Lehmann 1922: 244-5) but they gained immense popularity in the

seventeenth century after the publication of Jean Passerat’s satirical poem Nihil (Paris: Chez Estienne

Preuosteau, 1587). Carlo Ossola (1997: vii-xxvii) describes a vigorous two-year-long debate in the

Venetian Accademia degli Incogniti regarding the value of such poems, which was initiated by the

publication of a discourse by Luigi Manzini titled Il niente (Venice: Andrea Baba, 1634). Ossola (xliii-xlv)

convincingly demonstrates that Rossi’s friend Gabriel Naudé was in Padua during the time of these

debates, which were associated with Venetian intellectuals, and cultivated an interest in paradoxical

encomia, including Nothing-poems. The following poems include ones on such subjects as a gnat, a

honey apple, a pomegranate, and a beard.

339

We would have learned more about him had exuberant laughter, coming from the

people sitting next to us, not directed our curiosity elsewhere. They were ridiculing the

ability and acumen of a certain philosopher72 in their group, who had supposedly

discovered that all dense and solid bodies were transparent, something he attempted to

demonstrate in the following way: He moved his right hand back and forth over his left

hand at such speed that the brief period of time when his right hand, which was in

motion, was covering up his left hand was not perceptible to the naked eye; because of

this his left hand was always visible. The philosopher, either not noticing this, or

pretending not to notice, concluded his reasoning thus: “Is my right hand not a dense

and solid body? As it moves quickly back and forth it covers the left hand, but it

nevertheless does not remove it from sight. Therefore, are not all solid and dense

bodies transparent?” He failed to understand that the movement of his right hand was

creating an optical illusion, and that, if his right hand remained motionless above his left

hand, it would cover it in such a way that you wouldn’t be able to see it. Moreover, he

taught us that the earth was liquid and that all living things moved about in it like fish:

“What else could those little objects be that you see floating about in sunrays, as if in

water, if not little particles of earth? Therefore, the earth alone fills these lower parts and

surrounds everything that moves.”

But we were not going to hear such things from the person who was about to

speak, since he always conveyed ideas that sprung from his genius, were elaborated by

72 Giovanni Ciampoli (1589-1643) was at one point made papal poet laureate (Rietbergen 2006: 108). He

lost his position as secretary of the Papal Briefs in the 1630s because he was an admirer of Galileo

Galilei. Rossi devotes a portrait to Ciampoli in his Pinacotheca altera.

exacting effort, and honed by good judgment. That man is Hiero Volusius73 who is first

and foremost learned, is an expert in divine and human law,74 as well as in Greek and

Latin letters, and is refined in all manner of learning. He has published many

outstanding books in both prose and poetry, and, though he has distinguished himself,

he has not attained the highest honors, which frequently happens to the best people in

this Republic.75 While we were listening to these things, and more, about this man, he

appeared at the podium. His face was honest, albeit gaunt and a bit pale from the toil of

study; because his eyesight was weak, it was shielded behind spectacles, which made

him look authoritative rather than deformed. He proceeded to praise a gnat76 with such

erudition and eloquence, with phrases so skillfully joined together and so elegant, that it

was judged, by the consent of all, that nothing more perfect or more excellent had ever

been heard in that venue. After he had concluded his recitation, he stepped off the dais

and went to sit with everyone else. The Prince of the Academy,77 a most noble youth—a

redhead of the highest birth, the greatest intelligence, and who had risen quickly in his

career because, at the age when others were considering embarking on their studies,

he had already completed them—began asking everybody, one at a time, to bring any

new poems forward, if they had any. Specifically, he called on Plusius Accipiter,78

whose hair was gray but whose mind and demeanor were not at all that of an old man.

He was said to be a witty conversationalist, lively, pleasant, affable, a friend to his

friends; and he was an especially delightful poet, both melodious and charming. In a

clear, sweet voice he recited this six-line poem, which he had written in honor of a

maiden to whom he had sent honey apples as a gift:

We apples blush with red and are brimming, smooth and heavy, with

honey. At the same time, we grow old after a brief life. Our rosy hue

forsakes us and ugly wrinkles take its place. Wrinkles await you in the

same way, maiden; the destiny of old age will descend upon you, and the

pretty blush of your cheeks will fall away.

Since it was customary in this academy to repeat everything so that, if something

was not understood the first time around, it could be absorbed more precisely when

presented again, I had plenty of time to take in what was being said. Nicobulus Aridus79

was invited to speak next, and he praised the late Claudius Magius—famous among

academy members both in reputation and name, and who had once presided over the

academy—with a poem, in which (in my opinion) he cleverly poked fun at the

academy’s emblem, which was a magnificent fountain with many swans swimming in its

lucid waters.80 Because he began speaking so quietly that he could barely be heard,

even by those nearest to him, Plusius, with his usual charm, said: “Speak up, Nicobulus,

so those at the back of the room can hear you.” Nicobulus complied:

78 Enrico Falconio. Rossi devotes a portrait to Falconio in his Pinacotheca.

79 Gian Vittorio Rossi.

80 The emblem of the Academia degli Umoristi consisted of an image of the sun partially obscured by

While Magius sails the calm river to Elysium and the noble shade subdues

and flees the funeral pyre, a dense crowd, hiding in the green forest,

comes forth from all directions and is seen high atop the mountain ridges.

The crowd of people does not know, but tries to find out, what sort of world

the sailor is hastening to and whence the little boat is carrying its unusual

cargo. But when they see Bellinus showering his old comrade with many

kisses and see the two entwine their necks in an embrace, they discover

that a great glory has flowed from these waters and has shone forth from

these places. Their applause immediately increases and they utter the

following sayings mixed with joyful dancing: “Surely if that river brings forth

such shades, this grove81 will be more famous than heaven above.”

When Nicobulus had finished speaking, Fabullus Leonatus,82 spontaneously and

without waiting for the Prince’s order, said: “Nicobulus’s epigram reminds me of an ode

with which I once eulogized that most famous poet Bellinus while mourning his death.

Unless you deem otherwise, I will recite it to you here.” “As you like,” said the Prince.

“Whatever you have to share will be beneficial.” Fabullus Leonatus began:

Alas, what excellence has passed away and left the world behind! Alas,

what lamentation has caused the air to resound! Bellinus has died, the

love, delight, and darling of Phoebus. He has entered the vast region of

heaven, as the fast flame climbs upward and the swift arrow takes leave of

a bent bow. As the rent air cracks like a thunderbolt when an arrow leaves

the bowstring, so the world cries out at the death of Bellinus who is

returning to the stars. Installed in the ranks of the gods, he will be carried

by the quick force of the resounding heavens and will be submerged, late,

in the deep ocean. A new shooting star, trailing a white tail, shows how a

noble virtue that serves the righteous gods now gleams among the eternal

fires. Both Venus, blushing with ruddy hue, and Phoebus are glad to add

him to their company and, by joining their light together, restore the losses

of the night. Weave garlands of twining ivy, Delphic laurel, and green

myrtle, and bring gifts of frankincense to the sacred tomb of that great

poet. Let his lyre fly up to the stars, a lyre with sufficient skill to sound a

song sweet enough to hold back the rivers in their banks, until an equal

bard arises.

81 = Elysium

82 Fabio Leonida. Rossi devotes a portrait to Leonida in his Pinacotheca.

343

Lepidus Gallutius Sinister,83 son of Lucius Sinister, master of this palace, was

seated near Fabullus. On account of his quickness of wit and the wealth of his

education, he was admitted to their ranks just a few days earlier, which was sooner than

the rules of the academy would normally allow. But everyone was exceedingly eager to

get a taste of his intellect. Lepidus, either guided by gentlemanly modesty or because

he was afraid of being subjected to the judgment of so many learned men, declined

when asked to speak. After being persuaded by his friends, however, he finally said: “I

will recite some verses that I allowed to slip out over the last few days while I was in the

country. The beauty of that place, the healthfulness of the weather, and the

peacefulness of the day inspired me to praise that most beautiful time of year”:

Now let my shepherd’s pipe make the tender delights and joys of happy

Spring resound in festive song, here where the lush lands, hills, and fields

smile, which the blessed breeze of Favonius84 breathes on and clothes in

snowy-white and red. O Spring, most excellent ornament, most shining

splendor of the year, when the fields glimmer with a purple hue and the

earth, sprinkled with pleasing flowers, dares, in her beauty, to compete

with the starry sky; among which flowers white lilies, narcissus, and purple

amaranth gleam, looking like goblets; and nature covers soft violets,

tinged with the sweet paleness of lovers, with a rich variety of colors.

Indeed, they are white and at the same time they look as if they are

bleeding. The rose, suffused at its core with a maiden’s blush, turns red

with a desire to hide its hair under a green cap, and at the same time to

conceal its rosy countenance and, abiding in a maiden’s bosom, to glow or

be plucked by the white thumb of an admiring boy. The playful girl opens

her arms; then she slowly shakes the flower off her lap, tinged with its

natural purple hue, and it colors the green grass of the sunny field. How a

song sung by the delicate voice of birds drives away sad cares and brings

back leisure! Colorful sirens of the grove—you peaceful birds—you

captivate our anxious minds with your innocent songs; you compel us to

wash off our unshaken spirits which sink their troubles in the secure

83 Francesco Maria Mancini (1606-1672), son of Paolo Mancini, was made a cardinal by Alexander VII.

84 Favonius: another name for Zephyrus, or the West Wind.

344

depths of Lethe,85 and, with our spirit calmed, bring exquisite forgetfulness

into our stress-filled lives. Therefore, let my lands ever resound with your

warbling; there will be no traps here, no bird-catchers with bird-lime.

Melliferous swarms, with their delicate and peaceful hum, gather thyme or

build their waxen homes. Shall I, forgetful of breathing the gently

whispering heavenly air, be silent about your honors? How your sweet

spirit strikes me coming right up close to my ears! How many scents reach

my nose! Your spirit, traversing fragrant hills and Nabataean86 fields,

brings back to me, in my heated state, sweet, pleasing gifts freely offered

up by flowers.87 Stay, mild air, and grant this favor to my plot of land, that

you will always hover over these leafy trees, and that they will shine, free

of ice and rigid frost. Whether fierce Sirius scorches the thirsty fields, or

snow and rain pull the sky along with their rumblings, there must be no

shortage of flowers for bees, no shortage of roses, the garlands’ friend, or

of long-lived celery, violets, or white lilies, or the privet, whiter than snow.

The youth’s innate talent for poetry met with everyone’s approval, and there was a

consensus that his eloquence, which was still sweet, lush, and in the process of

fermenting, like must from the bottom of a wine barrel, would become much gentler and

more pleasant as the years went by.

Liberalis was up next, and he recited these two epigrams:

Your swollen eyes pour forth diamonds, fierce love scorches your heart

with a mighty flame. Is it any wonder that, shining through the air, your

eyes emit double fires as their moisture glows greater? Similarly, we see

stars imbued with a fine, reddish mist carrying burning torches.

After he was silent for a bit he said: “I have praised the tears of another; now I will

lament my own”:

My heart is constantly aflame and my eyes are wet with copious moisture.

Can my eyes bring forth clear spring waters, while my heart is emitting a

flaming funeral pyre? Why does the rain shower of my tears not put out

the swift flames, or the fire at least not drink down flowing waters? It is no

86 Nabataeans were an Arab people who inhabited northern Arabia and the Southern Levant and whose

wonder: cruel love combines two contraries, mixing rain with fire and fire

Among the members of the academy, this man was considered a tragic poet and his

writings were said to resound mightily like a battle trumpet; but from the epigrams he

recited, we concluded that he possessed charm in equal amounts.

Sabellus88 followed up by saying: “Lepidus Sinister challenges me to recite

another poem in which I praise the loveliness of this past Kalends of May”:89

The joyous Kalends of the festive month has arrived. May is upon us,

pride of the passing year. Behold Titan, bathed in rose-colored light,

brings back bright, cloudless days. The tilled fields, painted with fragrant

colors, prepare the lilies, together with violets, for new garlands. Young

girls are spotted throughout the long byways, carrying white and purple

roses in their aprons, and, at the same time, they lift up their hands and

ask for gifts while piling green boughs on raised altars. Why is the whole

year not decorated like this? Why is summer scorching hot? Why is winter

savagely fierce? But the new spring renews your joys again and brings

back beauty with its trees and plants. But as soon as our best years have

faded away, every blossom and beauty are absent from our rough cheeks.

Everybody praised his writing style, which was cheerful, bright, and charming,

and we in the audience felt ourselves moved to joy. Then Sextilius Ligur,90 who was

considered among the preeminent academy members in terms of intellect, erudition,

and education—and who, it was said, had published extremely learned commentaries

on the Tablet of Cebes91 (besides his books of excellent epigrams and his brilliant

the riches and rewards of spring. But I understand that autumn surpasses spring to the

extent that it produces more fruit than flowers and foliage, which I think is more

important. What is more, I am closer to autumn in my stage of life. Therefore, I have

attempted to praise the pomegranate in my verses, which abounds during this season”:

The tireless trader rushes to the farthest Indies and prepares to cleave the

pearl-bearing92 ocean with his fleet so that, new bride, he can bring you

whatever gemstones and dyes the Indians and Tyrians have to offer for

your retinue. If these pomegranate seeds, much like brilliant bronze, shine

more brightly than purple dye and precious stones, why does he only seek

nourishment with his eyes in that place when his mouth can also take a

draft of rosy nectar here?

Following Sextilius Ligur, a young man (whose name I don’t remember) was

commanded to speak. He possessed a particularly wonderful talent for poetry and could

produce a hundred lines of poetry while standing on one foot.93 He said: “I do not know

whether it is more desirable to excel in intellect or in wealth, especially in the context of

these customs, and in this city where rewards, pleasures, honors, and delights accrue

only to the wealthy. But I wrote this epigram for a friend of mine, a fortunate and noble

man who was complaining about the sluggishness and barrenness of his own talent,

especially in regard to composing verses. He said he envied me, on whom nature

herself, as they say, had bestowed her aid in writing verses”:

91 The work referred to here is Mascardi’s Discorsi morali su la Tavola di Cebete tebano (Venetia: Ad

92 Prop. III.IV.2. The translation “pearl-bearing” for gemmiferum is from Propertius and Goold 1990.

You sweat, grow pale, tremble, and gasp your last breath as you write

down a few songs, as if Apollo were against you. You fool, why are you

rushing toward the infernal shadows now, while Fortune’s pleasing face

shines on you? On you she bestowed money and acres of cultivated

fields, and on me the ability to produce verses. If you complain that what

was given to me is more than my fair share and that my prayers to the

gods were granted, ask yourself whether the gods would cause you to

enjoy a richer vein if they rescind my gifts, in which you awkwardly tread.

Among the academy members was a certain Ianus, by the surname Thorius, who

was called Offuscatus94 within their group. There was a consensus among everyone

that he was the first to be acquainted with ancient coins and inscriptions. And though he

yielded to few the highest praise of learning and erudition, he also surpassed everyone

in wit and humor. His speech was highly anticipated by all, because he always had

something charming and witty to offer. When the Prince of the Academy finally called on

him, he said: “In this poem, I lament my friend Caesar’s bad fortune, because, at the

age of thirty-two, no hair has yet managed to put down roots on his wrinkly chin”:

Caesar had added two years to his six lustra,95 but his face had not yet

grown a wispy beard, and he diligently continued to apply medicated

ointment to his chin and to exhort the gods with prayers. The compliant

gods finally granted his wish and his wrinkled cheeks were stiffened with

facial hair. While he rejoiced being able to march with a bearded face, and

thought himself handsome because of it, by some stroke of fate, his

beard—which had come about through such effort—was not well

established, and it fell out. Such is the fickleness of the great gods. They

take away such small gifts so quickly!

At this point everyone burst into raucous laughter and, at the same time, praised the

purity and elegance of his Latin, which that epigram showcased.

By chance, a certain inquisitor named Euganeus96 was present, a man of utmost

authority and advanced age, some of whose writings I had seen at Gallonius’s house. I

liked them so much that I cannot easily say I had seen anything that better preserved

the pure method of writing from the age of Virgil. Everyone was saying that, if there

were room in this society for honesty and liberal studies, Euganeus should already have

risen to the highest ranks. My ears pricked up with enthusiasm. I was eager for that

erudite voice, which was worthy of Roman ears, to delight my own. But it was not to be.

He was endowed with such age and such influence that they all treated him as a father,

and they thought that he was treating them fairly—indeed excellently—if, every now and

then, he was not burdened with attending their academic events and this gathering of

learned men.

But a noble young man named Tyrrhenus97 satisfied our desire, whose

ancestors, very religious and very rich men—who estimated their wealth not by the

pound but by the ton—had built the most elegant shrines and magnificent palaces in the

city.98 He had devoted his most excellent mind to that loftiest of subjects, the civil law,

and had placed himself under the direction a very learned lawyer. He is so devoted to

the skill and practice of the liberal arts, that, even when he had free time, especially

when court was not in session, he still composed verses that are endowed with the kind

of purity and elegance of language as to garner admiration. He sprinkles them with a
