Apollo sleeping beneath an oak tree:

While sleep flitted about Phoebus on gentle wing and the shady oak cast a

shadow over him with its branches, swift Cupid saw him from a nearby

rock; ordering his quick feet to move more slowly, he said: “I see the sun

sleeping in the shade, and the light which brings the day is hidden by the

night.”

Associated with that gathering of learned men were a few who were passed over

freely, and from whom no recitation was expected. When we asked the reason for this,

someone responded that they were from the old academy where there were no rules

obligating them to recite. When we insisted on asking Gallonius what kind of men the

old academy was made up of, he said: “The best and most agreeable kind. As for the

rest, this academy, which rose out of small beginnings, has grown to this large size,

which you now see. Indeed, in the beginning only a few young men used to gather in

this house, on the festival of Dionysus, to pursue entertainment and pleasure by putting

on comic plays. These are the people who sit silently among the others. But their

custom did not die out, and it lives on even now. According to their laws, no one is

admitted into these comedic pursuits except by a vote, and if someone is even one vote

short, whether he is a dynast or the king himself, he is excluded and rejected. Noble

wives are permitted to attend academy meetings along with their husbands, for it is not

considered unseemly or indecent to make noblewomen laugh, as long as they are

outstanding both in age and beauty.”99

allowed to attend meetings. Frederick F. Hammond (1994: 86) asserts that the virtuosa musician and

There was a man among them named Iberus who had an honest face, gray hair,

and a robe that went down to his ankles. Although he had been passed over according

to custom, he rose and said: “I do not want it to seem like I’m getting off easy by only

performing comic plays. I also desire to prove my dedication to composing verses with

this epigram, and to show you how I keep my health up through the summer months.”

Everyone pricked up their ears to listen, and he began:

To stay healthy all summer, and for Leo’s furious star not to harm you,

always wet your lips with dark, chilled wine, and lay your body down in a

dry place.

He moved us to laughter and, at the same time, this charming man’s character received

unanimous praise. We heard the following about him, that there was nobody in that

most respected troupe of actors who could play the braggart soldier100 more realistically

than he. He was beloved by everyone on account of his pleasantness, and he was the

guest of honor at the gatherings, banquets, and drinking parties of his friends.

Micrus of Pesaro,101 who was always the last to be called on, had still not

spoken. There was nobody better than he in terms of his voice or his quickness of wit;

nobody sharper in challenging others or in responding to challenges; nobody more

polished, in any speaking style, in terms of his wit and humor. He had a writing style that

was magnificent, clear, delightful, and comprised splendid and acute phrases. When

Micrus came prepared to speak, he did not tolerate getting caught up in the pettiness of

those who spent the day protesting or making excuses, when they themselves preferred

speaking much more than others preferred listening. He recited these words with

outspoken and frank confidence:

While pious Aeneas burned with the fire of love that he was imbibing from

your eyes, sweet Elissa,102 he exclaimed: “Did the fires of Troy let me go

unharmed so that lofty Carthage might burn with new pyres? Alas, I will

die your unequal! Before, death could have brought me fame; now, life

and honor are dead to me.”

“I was thinking about reciting another poem for you in which I present as a speaker the

recently deceased wife of Philippus, the leader of our troops. Rather than burden you

with more verses, however, I think I will concede that you have heard enough. For this

reason, I will refrain for the moment and put off that poem for another speaking

occasion.” But everyone said they wanted to hear it right then and there, and so he

recited with his usual enthusiasm:

This gravestone is sprinkled with tears and with songs, so that my fame

will be celebrated throughout all eternity. These pious gifts are indeed

pleasing to our ashes. What is more pleasing, however, and the highest

honor, is that I was joined to you, my husband Philip, and was dearer to

you than your very eyes and your own life. This will grant that my long life

is secured. You alone are the steady pillar of my renown. Other women do

not have poems dedicated to them, whereas I have them in abundance,

because they will say that I was married to such a man.

The silence that greeted the poem, along with everyone’s approbation, showed that it

had pleased them exceedingly.

When it seemed that there was no longer anyone left to take a turn speaking,

everybody got up to leave. Hiero Volusius, the one who had so eloquently praised the

gnat, called for silence by raising his hand and saying: “I do not want to seem like I have

102 Elissa, or Elisa: an alternative name for Dido.

352

gotten away without contributing anything to this venue, or rather, to this veritable

convivium of writers, where offerings have been collected from so many literary men, as

if from guests at a banquet. For this reason I will also contribute something to the mix

and recite the poem, in iambic meter, with which I mourned the untimely death of

Ursatus, the recently deceased defender of virtue and honor. As you know, he was the

very model of integrity and of every virtue”:

The unrighteous mind of mortals always rushes headlong into wickedness.

The decrees of menacing laws do not hold someone back if he is bent on

committing a crime, and the fierce hands of lictors do not restrain him with

any authority. Nor do the rewards, allotted to the righteous, compel him

toward shining virtue. Thus, we detest things that are right. What praise

and great glory awaits you for all time, Ursatus, whom neither the vigorous

and flourishing ornament of age, nor the bright glow of power, has diverted

from the narrow path of virtue and drawn into slothful leisure! We are

amazed that the dark day has carried you off and overwhelmed you with a

quick death. An extraordinary event does not grant a long showing but

ceases within a brief period of time. You, like a miracle, not having

reached a fitting age for death, have taken flight prematurely toward the

stars.

When he had finished speaking, the evening was suddenly at an end. Once we were

granted permission to take our leave, we stood up and exited with the rest of the crowd

leaving behind a group of academy members that was making its way over to Hiero to

congratulate him on his learned poem in praise of the gnat.

When we had crossed the threshold of our house, we caught sight of a long

procession of adolescent boys walking in pairs, barefoot, and with their eyes cast down

on the ground. They were singing a song, with which I was not familiar, in a doleful and

low voice. An equally large group of girls was following them and singing in almost the

353

same manner. While we were looking on in wonder, Gallonius said: “Alexander,103 priest

of the Temple of Daphne and Apollo and a most renowned dynast, has been bedridden

for six days now consumed by a serious and dangerous illness. As I heard tell, a few

hours ago, while you were attentively taking in the recitations of the academy, his illness

worsened so much that the doctors almost gave up hope. But these boys and girls,

supported by his charity, have been praying at all of the temples dedicated to

Aesculapius and asking for his favor. This city would certainly sustain an enormous loss

with his untimely death, since there is nobody who comes close to him in terms of

financial outlay, and who goes further than he in terms of expense and splendor.” When

Gallonius was finished, and since it was almost evening, we gradually and quietly made

our way home. When we got there, we gave ourselves over first to dinner and then to

bed.

We awoke at the second watch104 startled by mournful and plaintive voices that

were filling the entire neighborhood. Terrified, we got up, stuck our heads out the

window, and discovered that the wailing was coming from the hospital next door to

Gallonius’s palace. We were only able to make out these cries: “Woe is me! Woe is me!

I am in agony! My stomach is exploding! My spleen, my liver, my intestines are all

rioting and preparing an assault!” That particular hospital was the largest and by far the

103 Cardinal Alessandro Damasceni Peretti di Montalto. He also appears under the name Plusius. He was

famous for his patronage of the arts as well as for being a collector of art.

104 A Roman day was divided into twelve equal daytime hours (sunrise to sunset) and twelve equal

nighttime hours (sunset to sunrise). The length of each individual hour was not fixed but would vary

according to the seasons (i.e., according to the length of days and nights). The nighttime hours were

divided into four periods of three hours each, called vigiliae, which originated as a military term signifying

a shift of the night watch. The second watch occurred between 9:00 p.m. and midnight.

most famous of all of the hospitals in the city,105 and it maintained a large number of

employees in order to attend to patients. The staff was managed by a certain old man,

with the authority and title of Chief of Staff, who was said to be extremely stingy and

severe and who strove for nothing so much as to keep costs down. He employed

neither good judgment nor moderation in this endeavor, and he occasionally lost large

sums of money in order to gain a single mina of profit. Gallonius, who was either seized

by pity for the afflicted employees, or eager to understand the suffering of the human

race, said: “What do you say we go and give the staff and patients a hand?” “Agreed,”

responded Aemilius, and we all donned our swords and hurried together to help those

poor people.

We entered the hospital and crept through the entire place—the cafeteria, the

pantry, the spice cabinet (where didn’t we go?)—but we didn’t bump into a single

person. In the infirmary, we found a doctor applying bronze cupping glasses to a patient

and drawing blood from his skin with a blade. Since we never came across anyone, we

ended up following the sounds of groaning voices. We entered a bathroom, and there

we found the entire staff huddled together driven there by a gastric emergency. There

were more than fifteen toilets in the bathroom, and each one was occupied by people

evacuating their bowels. The last ones to run to the bathroom were asking the first ones

to get up and give them their spot. Others, who were more prone to anger, were

threatening to evacuate their bowels on the laps of those who were already sitting on

the toilet. Others resorted to violence and struggled to shove the ones occupying the

105 This is a reference to the Ospedale di Santo Spirito an ancient hospital (now a convention center)

located in the rione Borgo in Rome, east of Vatican City.

355

toilets out of the way. Everyone was filling the place simultaneously with a foul sound

and stench.

We asked one man, who had gotten off the toilet, how it had come to pass that

everybody was emptying their loose bowels at exactly the same time. He said he

blamed it on the wine they had consumed at dinner the previous evening. In fact,

because that cheap, tight-fisted hospital chief didn’t want the large quantity of dregs

collected from his many wine casks to be thrown out, he consulted with the wine

steward as to how he could foist them on those who were drinking. The wine steward, in

order to enter into the chief’s good graces, said: “I will concoct a wine for you out of

these dregs that is so pure, so unadulterated, so pungent and smooth at the same time,

that whoever tastes it will not only not be put off, but will gulp it down eagerly.” In sum,

the steward diluted the carefully collected dregs with a lot of flat wine and, after adding

egg-yolks, sulfur, and especially a large quantity of alum, he strained the whole batch

and served it up to be consumed in place of the wine. Barely had four hours gone by

after that drinking binge, when everyone’s bowels began to overflow and be torn up by

the sharpest pains you could possibly imagine. Upon hearing this, we burst out laughing

at him so completely that we almost busted a gut. But Gallonius told him to cheer up, for

he hoped that this wine would serve in place of the medicinal syrups that keep those

lethal illnesses at bay, which the arrival of the unhealthy season had brought in.106 We

departed immediately, returned to our beds, and went back to sleep.

106 The “unhealthy season” is summer, during which season epidemics of malaria would break out (see

Chapter 3, n. 26).

356

Book Four

The following day we got up much earlier than we had the day before so we

could visit the rest of the neighborhoods in the city. However, the news had become

public that Dynast Alexander had died that night. There was sorrow and mourning all

around, and people of every age and rank were flocking to his palace to see him. As

one dynast was arriving and another was leaving, the two bumped into each other,

whereupon they stopped and greeted each other in the friendliest manner. Each

solemnly declared to the other that no one was more pleasing or dearer to him than he,

and each then pledged to the other his unqualified devotion and service, be it labor,

effort, or time. Each added, moreover, that no request was so arduous or so difficult that

he would not easily and cheerfully take it up on the other’s behalf. At this point,

Gallonius let out a loud guffaw. Astonished, I asked him why he was laughing, to which

he replied: “I am laughing because it is not easy to find two men who are so divided by

hatred from one another as these two are. See how these wicked men are dissembling,

embracing each other, and pledging their mutual aid? In Rome people behave

differently. There hostilities are declared publicly and are out in the open, rather than

kept secret and hidden. Here everyone puts on a friendly face, but many harbor an

angry spirit. Anger is concealed, while flattery is on full display.”

He would have said more about the character of those two men if a great cry had

not interrupted him. This caused us to turn around and see a large crowd of children

and other people whistling and crying as they followed one lone man, who was pale,

filthy, and looked like he had just returned from the dead. “Hey, what did you do among

the dead?” one person called out. “Do they have taverns and innkeepers there? Do

357

people eat and drink?” Another shouted: “Why didn’t Orcus107 want to keep you? He

maybe could have used someone to strike fear into children who refuse to go to school!

I ask you, did Pluto provide you proof that you were dead?”108 Others chimed in: “If only

a similar right of return could be granted to Dynast Alexander whom Pluto has just taken

from us. But that is something we can only wish for, rather than something we hope

could actually come true. What an evil deed! This man here, who deserved to be among

the shades, has been summoned back to the light, while that man, who was the

brightest light of his country on account of the superlative splendor of his life, has been

deprived of life.”

Ignorant of the whole matter, we asked what the story was. There was one man

among them who appeared to be the sharpest at weaving a tale. This man replied:

“Listen to this ridiculous story. This man, who was carried out of his house with a large

retinue, was thought to be dead and was placed in a tomb while still alive, and he lay

there for three days without any food.” We were horrified when we heard this and

burned with an even greater desire to hear the story. The man satisfied our desire. “But

before I get to it,” he said, “I need to tell you what sort of a man he is. There is nobody

more ferocious, more full of disgrace than this man here, who now appears before you

as calm, despondent, and quiet—though old age has diminished his usual

aggressiveness and wild behavior quite a bit. Before this he was, more than can be

expressed in words, bad-tempered, angry, drunk, arrogant, gluttonous, spoiling for a

fight with both his hands and his tongue; a master of nighttime orgies, and a leader and

107 In Roman religion Orcus is a synonym of Dis (or Dis Pater), the god of the Underworld, or the

Underworld itself. Pluto (below) is another name for Dis.

108 Translation informed by Marshall 2016: 53.

358

commander of others in killing and beating up men. He had an almost singular talent for

whipping up a crowd and inciting riots, and he was far superior to anyone else in hurling

frightful curses—for no reason—against the immortal gods.

“If it is permitted to judge the nature of a man especially from his actions,

consider what rank and position he should hold based on this one outrage: When he

arrived as a young man among the porridge eaters109 (foreigners whose customs are far

removed from ours), he was seized in one of their districts and questioned as to his

identity. He replied: ‘Scoundrels, parasites, thieves! May the evil that the gods bring

down on you be great and swift! What business is that of yours? Go to hell!’ Even

though the barbarians didn’t understand what he was saying, they guessed, from his

facial expressions and his intent look—and from the force with which he was trying to

free himself from their chains—that he was cursing them, and they unanimously

decided to cut off his head with a single blow. But behold the fearless spirit of this man.

While he was dodging their spears and being carried off to his death, just as the sword

was hanging above his neck, and just as he sensed he was about to be harmed, he

yelled: ‘Come on you filthy thieves and murderers! I will get my revenge on you good

and proper, if I live!’ But when the barbarian, who had taken it upon himself to lop the

man’s head off with a single blow of his ax, was not able to complete what he had

attempted, he left the man gravely wounded in the neck and abandoned on the ground.

109 The Latin is pultiphagos, which is a comic designation, found in Plautus, for early Romans who ate

mush or a type of spelt porridge (puls) instead of bread (see Plaut. Mostell. III.ii.828: “non enim haec

pultiphagus opifex opera fecit barbarous”; and Plaut. Poen. Prologue l. 54: “latine Plautus patruos

pultiphagonides”). Drujon (1966: 1055) supposes that the word in this text designates either Swiss or

German people, and IJsewijn (Eud. 1998, Lib. II-IV n. 18) surmises that it refers to Germans. These are

convincing suppositions, since the man in the story is seized in a pagus, a term employed by Caesar,

Tacitus, and Ammianus to refer to the districs and cantons of the Gauls and Germans (e.g., Caes. BGall.

VI.11, I.12, IV.1, VI.23, VII.64; Tac. G. 39; Amm. 18.2.1).

359

Because of his very robust health, the man healed from his wound in no time. Furious

that he had suffered such a grave injury, the man carefully considered how he could

return the favor and repay those wicked men, set his mind on various plans, and could

not get a moment’s rest. When all of his plans were nicely drawn up in his mind, he

quickly pulled up stakes and made his way over to his enemies. Learn the method of

the punishment and, at the same time, admire how much audacity can exist in a single

individual. In the dead of night, he took advantage of the wind that was blowing, and,

setting fire to a few huts, he burned down almost the entire village before any of his

enemies noticed or could pull themselves together.

“The man, however, hidden with the aid of night, reached our city unharmed. He

was taken in by Dynast Palladius as one of his servants and, after that, into the service

of many other dynasts. However, this fickle and capricious man finally grew tired of life

at court and he set his mind to getting a wife. To make a long story short, he married a

young girl and then hired out his services to the Vestal Virgins. You are acquainted with

a woman’s character: fickle, hard to please, superstitious, and difficult. Those good

Vestal Virgins worked him so hard that they did not allow him any time off. There was

not a day during the winter months, even during a huge or violent storm, that they did

not force him to walk—twice—to the Placidiani gardens, which were located four miles

outside of the city at the estate of the dynast who owned them.110 Wherefore, from the

110 Placidiani Gardens possibly refers to Villa Peretti-Montalto and its famous gardens (see Chapter 3, n.

18). Given that the locus of action of Eudemia is the Vatican and the court of Urban VIII, the distance from

Vatican City to Villa Peretti-Montalto more or less matches the four-mile distance given here (I thank

Laura Foster of John Cabot University for suggesting this identification). The description of a hardworking

servant forced to walk back and forth through inclement weather is reminiscent of the story of the long-

suffering Nicius Rufus in Book Five, which is a clear reference to Rossi’s own days in the employ of

Cardinal Peretti di Montalto.

360

cold and exertion, he contracted an illness that lasted many months. In the end, it was

determined, in his doctors’ opinion, that he should abandon all hope of ever getting well.

The man laughed, called the doctors mad, and declared that he would outlive both them

and their children.

“While he was defying the doctors’ prognoses, he appeared to lose

consciousness. His breath was impeded and flowed with such difficulty that he lost all

his senses. He displayed all the customary signs of a dead man: a pale complexion,

stiffness throughout his whole body, and a complete loss of sensation. His wife

prepared a funeral for the supposedly dead man, and she couldn’t get his corpse out of

her house fast enough. Because of his uncontrollable temper, her husband often spoke

rudely to her and even beat her badly. Nevertheless, so as not to incur gossip and

rebuke from the public she performed the final rites for the man she believed to be

dead, not only with her tears but also with as much expense as she, a poor woman,

could manage. After the undertakers had been summoned, the dead man was carried

away, placed in a tomb, and the entrance to the tomb was sealed. After only one day

had passed after his burial, his breathing, which had stopped, returned to its life-giving

role, and he woke up believing he had been sleeping next to his wife for no longer than

a single night. He raised his head up a little, and he perceived a sort of thin ray of light

coming from the entrance to the tomb, which had not been properly sealed. Gently

nudging the corpse of some woman who had recently been placed there, he said: ‘Hey

Milphidippa!’111 (that was his wife’s name), ‘get up and open the window!’ Milphidippa

did not respond. Again, he said: ‘Hey, are you planning to wake up any time today? I’m

111 Name of a maidservant in Plaut. Mil.

361

already late in taking the medicine my doctor prescribed.’ His words fell on deaf ears.

Annoyed, he said: ‘What is this? Am I speaking to the dead? Look at this woman!

Before, when I was well, she always got up before sunrise and shook me out of my

sleep. Now, when I don’t need to sleep, she is thoroughly in the grip of it herself.’ Since

his bed seemed firmer than usual, he tried lying on his other side, where he bumped up

against the cadaver of another dead man. Suspecting that it was some lover or other of

his wife, he exclaimed: ‘What a shameful outrage! That most wicked woman has

brought her lover right under my nose—and even into the same bed! What would she

do if I were dead, buried, and in my grave? And to mock me even more shamelessly,

she is pretending to be asleep!’ Swollen with rage, he said: ‘We’ll see soon enough if

I’m not able to wake you up!’ He grabbed one of her legs and began nudging her back

and forth. Barely had he touched the dead woman’s leg with his hands, when it tore off

and came away from the rest of her corpse. When that happened, he was hit by the

foulness of a repulsive stench and it was clear he was extremely terrified. He then

carefully felt around with his hands to see what else was around him, touching only

pieces of wood and the bones of dead people, until he finally realized whose lands he

had come to rest in. He cried: ‘Alas, I’ve been buried alive! Somebody open up this

tomb immediately!’

But the poor man spoke these words in vain to the senseless air, which

was unable to hear or utter any sounds in reply.

“Either some god was looking out for him, or fate came to his aid, but within a few

days of this happening, a certain porter died and was carried into the same tomb. When

the pallbearers opened the entrance, the man inside began shouting: ‘Bring me some

lunch—it’s now been three days that I’ve been in here without any food!’ The

362

pallbearers, undertakers, and morticians, terrified by his voice, dropped their candles,

abandoned the corpse, and ran away as quickly as possible. The man didn’t stop, but

he yelled even louder for someone to get him out of there, saying ‘Where the hell am I?’

What kind of men, what kind people are so barbaric as to do this? Are the

living to be kept from the gift of light?

Perhaps that poor porter had drunk a bit too eagerly to his own health at the tavern and,

because of that, he had fallen asleep—and before he had slept off his hangover, he was

carried into this tomb, as if dead.

“Once the other men had recovered a bit from their fear, they returned and spoke

with him, as if they were talking to portents and omens from hell. To which he

responded: ‘You must be joking. I am alive—and I’m hungry!’ He narrated the rest of the

story in the order it happened. Believing the man, they got him out of the tomb, gave

him food and drink, and brought him home to his wife. It was not certain whether she

would be struck more by surprise or resentment. Thinking that her husband had gone to

a place from which no one is permitted to return, she had identified, on her own, another

man to be her husband.”

Here was an opening to interrupt our storyteller. “How his wife must have wished

that funerals for the dead were carried out here the same way they are in Rome where

bodies are thrown on a burning pyre! By god, she wouldn’t now be witnessing the return

of her husband after his funeral.” He replied: “If we had that custom here, I reckon she

would have lit the pyre herself and carried her husband onto the flames with her own

bare hands. Then, in order to be entirely free from fear, she would have gathered his

ashes and tossed them into some river or other. Such is her hatred of her husband that

I believe she is tormenting herself, saying she is unattractive and lamenting that she

363

was born for the sole purpose of putting up with suffering.” To which I replied: “If the

dead came back to life here, everyone would prefer to live here as a pauper than have a

kingdom elsewhere. Indeed, as far as I am concerned, I would not want to live out my

life anywhere else.” He said that coming back to life is only granted to those who have

not yet crossed the Cocytus, and that those who reach the far shore of that river are

made to lose all memory of this life, along with their hope of ever returning to it. When

we had finished, we dismissed him with a laugh and proceeded to tour the rest of the

city.

At last, we returned home because we were tired of walking and because the

hottest period of the day had begun. We had some free time and nothing to do. It wasn’t

lunchtime yet, and Gallonius was not allowed to sit at the table before his dynast had

finished his own lunch and the tables had been cleared. We reckoned that the morning

hours would be less tedious if we could spend them with Gallonius in his dynast’s

house, where many things would be readily available for us to see and hear and to

entertain us with delight. We headed over there, entered the anteroom, and withdrew by

ourselves into a corner. The good servants, as they are wont to do to pass the time,

unsheathed their tongues like swords in order to destroy everyone’s good name. First

they began to slander the reputation of a certain well-known woman, then they

undertook to strip another man, one of admirable virtue, of his long-standing reputation

for honesty and loyalty. One of the servants recounted, from memory, the names of all

of the city’s prostitutes. Because of their number, which was beyond count, and

because of the power of his memory, which was unbelievable, he seemed like Cyrus

who, while reviewing his army, could call on each soldier by name. Another servant was

364

savaging the gauche host with curses because he was serving starling instead of thrush

for lunch and beef instead of veal. When there was nobody left to insult, and when they

had grown tired of cursing, they began talking about Dynast Alexander. They confirmed,

based on the opinion of all the doctors, that he had died prematurely, especially since

he was not very old and, moreover, since he enjoyed robust physical strength. Next,

they asked which man, from among those who were holding out so much hope, would

succeed Alexander as King in that most distinguished office which he had just held.

Each one of them favored a certain person over another, according to the enthusiasm

that each candidate excited in him, either out of friendship, or hope for some sort of

favor.

While they were chatting, a man appeared in the antechamber. His face was

honest but his eyes were cast downward on the ground. All of the servants immediately

approached him, walked around him, stood around him in a circle, and congratulated

him on some honor he had recently received. One of them, more than the others,

seemed almost to melt and flow away out of love and goodwill toward the man, so much

so that he took turns crying and hesitating, as if he did not possess a vocabulary

sufficient for declaring the magnitude of his love. Gallonius was amazed and was stifling

his laughter with a handkerchief. He finally came over to us and said: “I can’t tell you

how much these people are making me laugh. You see that man receiving all of those

congratulations? A few days ago, he was very powerful, thanks to his authority and

influence with our dynast, that all of the affairs in our household were administered

according to his counsel and judgment. This aroused a great deal of jealously and led

many people to plot against him. Noticing this, he reckoned that he would do better to

365

leave of his own accord than be removed in disgrace. In order to make it seem like he

had changed jobs rather than quit, he asked the dynast, out of favor and goodwill, for

another position that seemed, at least in appearance, to be distinguished and noble but

was, in fact, utterly trifling and trivial. So that poor man has come to the dynast to thank

him. But the man who especially makes me laugh is that one there, who is hiding his

hatred so skillfully behind a pretense of goodwill. There is no more dangerous or hostile

an enemy than he to that other man who gave up his position. Our dynast has been

particularly taken in by his efforts and misled by the jealousy and attacks on that man’s

privilege and renown. I ask you to observe how that evil man dissembles, how he

deceitfully flatters and artfully slanders him!”

In the meantime, someone rushed into our midst and said: “I have in my room a

jug of excellent and very cold wine. I’d say that I have not tasted any more pleasant a

wine this summer than this one. It is the king of wines, the darling of Bacchus—it will

tickle and soothe your tongue at the same time.” “Perfect timing,” said another,

“because, you see, I haven’t drunk any wine since I got up this morning—and you see

what time of day it is!” Another man added: “My parched throat is also burning with

thirst. If I don’t water it quickly, it will turn to dust.” Grabbing Gallonius by the right hand,

he said: “Let’s go quench our thirst—I see you are also dying of it. At the same time, we

can find out whether what he is saying is true.” Gallonius complied and followed him,

and we tagged along. Everyone rushed into the man’s room, attacked the wine jug, and

blotted out their minds with barely one draft. There was a pot placed next to the fire, full

of lamb that had not yet finished cooking. One of the men snatched the meat away and

out of the room, put it on a plate, and, while it was still hot, put it in his belly. Another

366

man cut slices of bread onto his plate, placed some of the bread into his broth, sprinkled

grated cheese on it, added pepper, and devoured it. The man who had been praising

his wine regretted what was happening, because he saw his lunch being plundered, and

he exclaimed: “Since we have lit the funeral pyre, why don’t we burn up the day on it as

well, which is half gone already,112 and happily eat our lunch.” “Let’s do that,” said the

man who was devouring the broth-soaked bread. “Each person should request that,

whatever he is having prepared for himself for lunch, it should be brought in and placed

in the middle of the table for everyone.” Everybody liked that idea. Gallonius said: “I will

commit to enough food to suffice for myself and for my two guests.” In the meantime,

word arrived that the dynast was asking for his luncheon. Gallonius, spurred on, rushed

to prepare whatever was needed. He returned not much later full of leftovers, because

the dynast was suffering from indigestion and had not eaten anything besides the broth,

leaving the rest of the food untouched. When they saw that the spirits of the dinner

guests had been restored, each of them asked the gods if that colicky dynast could be

there every time they dined with Gallonius. When they had finished talking, they all

removed their shoes, laughed, and reclined at the dining couches.

The laughter multiplied when a certain scholar joined in, whom I recalled having

seen the day before at the academy meeting. They said that he was a very famous

philosopher,113 an outstanding orator, and he ventured to ask in that gathering what

each person wanted to hear. They all called on the man—who was keen on pleasure

112 The Latin phrase literally translates to: “why don’t we burn the day dead on the pyre almost to its

113 Possibly Kaspar Schoppe (1576-1649), a German humanist and scholar. This is the same philosopher

and devoted to parties and lustful behavior—to approach, remove his shoes, and take a

table. They ate and drank joyfully. When they were all thoroughly stuffed, a discussion

was introduced regarding the women of that city whom, with few exceptions, they found

guilty of the crimes of avarice and promiscuity. In order not to seem like I had nothing to

say, I said: “Of all the women in the world, I do not believe that any surpass Roman

women in terms of chastity and modesty. All of the histories are full of examples, as is

the collective memory of antiquity.” The philosopher challenged my words saying: “You

seem to me to be truly unschooled in—and a stranger to—Roman history. You have

clearly not read what Sallust, the foremost historian of the Romans, left us in writing

regarding Fulvia, Sempronia, and many other women of that era.114 Even if you do not

know these things, has what Horace, player of the Roman lyre, sang on this subject not

reached your ears? I can recite to you his verses by heart:

The girl who has just reached puberty enjoys taking lessons in Ionian

dancing and is trained in the arts that go with it; even at this stage she

contemplates illicit love affairs with total absorption. In due course, when

her husband is in his cups, she looks for younger lovers; but she does not

select some man to whom she may hurriedly give forbidden pleasures

when the lamp has been removed; on the contrary, when sent for quite

openly, she gets up, with her husband’s full connivance, whether the caller

is some salesman or the captain of some Spanish ship who pays a high

price for such degradation.115

Could he have expressed more eloquently the character of Roman women so prone to

wantonness and excess?”

114 Descriptions of Fulvia and Sempronia are found in Sall. Cat. 23 and 25. See also Eud. 1998, Lib. II-IV

n. 24.

115 Hor. Carm. III.VI.21-32. Translation from Horace and Rudd 2004.

I was now trapped with no way out. By way of giving some response, however, I

asked: “What have you to say about Lucretia?116 Cannot she, who punished Tarquin’s

injury against her the way she did, most rightfully be said to be chief among all chaste

women? What could a woman, who is desirous of a good reputation, do more

eloquently than bear witness, with her voluntary death, to the pain of having her chastity

taken from her, as if a life that does not draw its essence from chastity holds no value?”

“My assessment of Lucretia is far different from the one that has been established in the

collective imagination,” the philosopher responded. “In fact, I grant her no virtue, nor do

I praise her for her restraint.117 When Tarquin violated her, she either accepted the

dishonor, or she did not. If she did consent to it, she is undeservedly given pride of

place among chaste women. If she did not consent to it, why did she prefer to kill herself

after being violated rather than be killed by Tarquin while still a virgin? Perhaps, you will

say, it was in order to vindicate herself and her chastity in public opinion. Because, if

she had offered her neck to Tarquin immediately, people might have thought that he

killed her because she had committed adultery with her servant. Thus, there was

something more important to her than her chastity: her reputation, clearly. If she had

been led solely by virtue, which does not require the testimony of anyone besides one’s

116 The story of Lucretia is found in Liv. I.LVII-LIX. See also Eud. 1998, Lib. II-IV n. 27.

117 The challenge that the philosopher mounts to Lucretia’s famed chastity is similar to St. Augustine’s

criticism of Lucretia’s actions in City of God, 1.19. Augustine maintains that, if Lucretia was not a willing

participant in the sexual encounter with Tarquin, she was not guilty of adultery because she was chaste in

her heart; therefore, taking her own life makes Lucretia the murderer of an innocent woman (herself).

Moreover, if her desire to kill herself was out of a sense of pudicita to protect her reputation as an

upstanding Roman woman, then she is also guilty of pride and not to be lauded as an example to

Christian women. Rossi also argues against Lucretia’s chastity in a dialogue titled De verecundia in

Dialogorum volumen alterum (Coloniae Ubiorum: Apud Iodocum Kalcovium & socios, 1649). Gerboni

(1899: 72) notes that Giambattista Marino casts similar doubt on Lucretia’s chastity in L’Adone (11.53-7)

as does Tassoni in La secchia rapita (VIII.66-75).

369

own conscience, she would not have been so concerned about what people might have

said about her. But if we delve into the innermost recesses of this matter, with the gates

fully opened through this avenue of suspicion, we can find some crime lurking in it. How

was Tarquin able to gain entrance to the woman’s room at bedtime, which was most

likely locked with many bolts? Why did her guards fail her? Why did she not cry out

when Tarquin assaulted her? Her entire household would have come running and that

wicked man would have either stopped before the deed had been committed, or, if he

had killed Lucretia while she was resisting him, she would have made it so there were

many witnesses to his crime and to her chastity.” The philosopher would never have

stopped talking, filled as he was with the flower of Bacchus, if a ruckus that had erupted

among the dinner guests had not interrupted him.

We then noticed a certain man among those who were snatching food off of the

grill. By begging and pleading he had forced them to let him into their group, but as

soon as he climbed onto a couch, he began to reach his pushy hands into every platter,

grabbing the best sausages of the lot, as if the lunch had been set out just for him. After

he had consumed the first round of dishes, a turkey hen was then recruited, which had

been arranged on a large serving dish. The turkey hen was seasoned in such a way

that, with its aroma, it would not only have roused a sleeping appetite, but would have

even resurrected a dead one. This most just man, as if he had been called upon to

judge the bird, summoned his slave, whom he had stationed at the entrance ready to do

his bidding. When he had convicted the bird, he covered its head and ordered it sent

into exile to his own house; and the innocent bird realized that it was made an exile

before it could even mount a defense. Having witnessed this, the dinner guests were

370

astounded, they looked around at each other, and they were transfixed by his

shamelessness in a state of silence and incomprehension. The hilarity that had

occupied their minds earlier left no room for anger, but everybody hid their pain and

continued with the ongoing festivities. The feast was just about nearing its end when a

dessert baked in an earthen pot was carried out on a tray, placed on the table, and

presented as the grand finale of the lunch. When the man—the one who had ordered

the turkey hen to acquire citizenship elsewhere—saw the dessert approaching, he acted

according to his nature and ordered the poor thing to be exiled to his house, following in

the footsteps of the turkey hen. His servant, who was at the ready, grabbed the dessert

by the throat and snatched it away. At that point, the man had exhausted the patience of

the dinner guests and everybody cried out in unison: “This surely cannot be tolerated!”

One of them, more enraged than the others, yelled: “This dessert will move to a new

colony over my dead body!” He grabbed hold of it and began bringing it toward himself.

The other man was taken aback at the violence being done to him. Finally, after being

intimidated by everyone’s threats and chided by everyone besieging him with words of

reproach, he backed off of his plan and leaned back onto his elbow at the table. When

lunch was over, one of the dinner guests, who lived for gambling, asked for some dice

and challenged the philosopher to a game. Since sleep had come over us, we got up

from the table and went off to Gallonius’s house where we spent the afternoon partly

reading and partly resting.

When the heat of the day had subsided, Gallonius said: “It’s time for us to go to

the Temple of Daphne where everybody is gathering today. From there, that noblest

Dynast Alexander, who has passed away, will be borne in a magnificent funeral

371

procession to the shrine that he had built in order to be buried there. It is the custom

here to be buried in a temple of the gods.” I said: “Take us there. I reckon there is no

more important a sight to see.” In short, we left the house and came to the Temple of

Asclepius,118 which was jam-packed with an enormous crowd. We went in and saw the

body of a young man placed in the midst of four candles. Gallonius asked who the

deceased man was, and what the people crowded around him were doing there. He

responded that the young man was a certain Philotas, for the love of whom two young

women had died a few days before; and that Philotas, upon learning of their deaths, fell

into a depression and died in the hospital from his affliction. I asked Gallonius what he

could tell us about Philotas and about those women and he responded: “The story is

worth hearing, but I am not able to tell you what really happened.” Another person said:

“If there is reason for you to know, I will recount it to you, and I will tell it to you in as few

words as possible.” I replied: “Do tell us, and don’t spare any details. You will be doing

us a great favor.” On that account, he began.

“In a certain town, on an island very close to this one, where King Theridates119

rules over his republic with the highest respect for justice, there lived a virgin of

marriageable age, named Olinda, who was not from the best or richest family, but was

so elegant and beautiful that she caught everyone’s eye. In particular, she attracted the

attention of Philotas, the preeminent man in that community, such that she made his life

unhappy and unpleasant. Because the poor man was consumed with love and sorrow,

he did what it might have occurred to anyone to do, that is, he allied himself in

118 A Homeric hero (the “blameless physician” of the Iliad) as well as a god of healing.

119 King Louis XIII of France.

372

partnership and friendship with the maiden’s father. He was successful in this plan, for

he won the father over within a short period of time. Indeed, since he visited the

maiden’s house often, and signaled his love to her with his eyes, face, and his very

voice, he discovered the same desire and love in her (which rarely happens).

“Enjoying the freedom that the customs of that region permit, they could not stop

hugging and kissing each other. When their embraces exceeded the bounds of

moderation, however, they came under suspicion from Olinda’s parents, who were

particularly desirous of a good reputation. For which reason, fearing greatly for their

daughter’s chastity at the hands of that man—who was both noble and of a certain

age—they decided to protect her with a guard. Since there is no fortification so strong

that it cannot eventually be conquered by an enemy’s unrelenting siege, they decided to

cut short their daughter’s relationship with the young man and drive him as far away as

possible from the boundaries of their household. In brief, they approached the young

man, informed him about what they had discovered regarding his love, and explained

the damage that would be in store for their daughter if she came to be the subject of

common gossip on his account. They begged and pleaded with him not to cause her

such dishonor, but to flee from her sight and from their home altogether. The young

man responded that he did not want any shame to come to her, nor to cause her any

insult himself; that he had already intended to marry her all along; and that he had been

led to many of his actions by his confidence in their future marriage. He asked—nay

insisted—that they promise her to him as his wife. They pointed out that his social

status was not the same as theirs; that they were of modest means and middling

nobility, while he was born to the greatest riches and to the most noble parentage; and

373

that moving up so suddenly from asses to cows, so to speak, was a very dangerous

proposition. Next they asked him to seek out another option, another marriage

arrangement. After Philotas had finally won them over, he took his leave from them with

the promise that they would continue to reflect on the matter and speak with his parents.

They wasted no time. They went to Philotas’s parents and told them everything. His

parents thanked them and suggested that they find Olinda a husband as soon as

possible. (Everyone in that country is at the ready with rash and hasty advice.)

“So Olinda’s parents immediately found her a husband, a noble youth to be sure,

but of no rank compared with Philotas. The wedding ceremony took place right away,

and everything was done quickly and carelessly. But this hasty plan failed to keep the

looming force of misfortune away from Olinda’s ruin; in fact, it actually came upon her

even more swiftly. After her wedding the reciprocal love between Olinda and Philotas

was not diminished, and Philotas could be spotted at all hours of the day in front of

Olinda’s house—and not without grave offense to the neighborhood and to Olinda’s

husband. In fact, the husband made sure to warn Philotas, through friends, that he had

better flee the country entirely, unless he was asking for trouble. As with many

noblemen, Philotas displayed a scornful character and arrogance, so he ignored

Olinda’s husband and kept visiting her house. Spurred by Philotas’s disrespectful

behavior, Olinda’s husband, when he came across him one day (and when Philotas was

least expecting it) he struck him with the flat of his sword and forced him to flee. Do not

ask what fire this egregious insult ignited in that furious and extraordinarily proud man.

Philotas rushed home like a madman, grabbed his sword, and came back. He

approached his enemy who was standing at the gate and, as the husband struggled

374

mightily, Philotas stabbed him right before Olinda’s eyes. The matter was brought to

judgment on the spot. They searched for Philotas around the entire island, but he had

already escaped and come straight here to Eudemia. But the judge overseeing the

case, at the urging of Philotas’s relatives (who were insisting that she had

masterminded the murder), ordered Olinda to be seized and thrown in jail. Thus, the

poor woman was taken from her parents’ embrace to a court of justice, and from her

happy marriage bed to jail.

“She had barely set foot inside the jail cell, however, when a new storm flung her

onto a different rock. The prison warden’s heart not only inclined toward pity for the

prisoner, but also burned with love for her. He came to her at night asking her to oblige

him and declared that he wanted to bring her home as his wife, offering his right hand

as a pledge of faithfulness to his promise. She responded that now was not the right

place for such a pledge, nor was it fitting for a wretched, shabby girl, brought up on

capital charges and forced to plead her case in chains, to enter into what would only be

a doomed marriage. She suggested he wait until she was released from her shackles.

But the man was not easily rebuffed by her words. Since his passion was at its peak,

inspired by love—or rather by insanity—he changed plans. He bought a horse, grabbed

a bag containing his traveling money, and ran away with Olinda. When they arrived at a

forest, the warden, who couldn’t wait any longer to rush into Olinda’s arms, feigned

exhaustion, dismounted from his horse, and flung himself into her embrace. She pushed

herself away from him, saying that she was still not available. He begged her to help

him, to aid a dying man, and he continued in this vein, but to no avail. He threatened her

with violence but the outcome was the same. In any case, when he saw that she was

375

moved no more by threats than by pleading, he resorted to force and struggled to wrest

an embrace from her. She fought him off by attacking him with her fingernails and teeth.

But she had taken on an unequal match with a mightier opponent.

“There was already no way left for her to resist, and she was close to

succumbing when a new development brought her certain victory and secured her

chastity. While she was struggling, she noticed a dagger hanging from his belt. Acting

quickly, she stealthily drew it out and drove it as far as possible into his side, freeing

herself from that hateful man’s eager embrace. What should she do now? What was her

plan? She was a very young woman alone, she had no friends or companions, and she

was in a harsh, deserted, and remote location. She did not lose heart, she did not

despair. Instead, she added another crime to her previous one, one that was worthy of a

man. She removed her women’s garb and dressed herself in the clothes she had taken

off that wretched warden. She grabbed his bag, mounted his horse, and resolved to find

her lover, wherever he might be. But she was only equipped as a summer traveler for

such a journey. She had not even set foot off the island when she had already used up

the small amount of money she had found in the bag, and she had sold the horse

besides. Because of this, she needed to contract herself out as a squire to a certain

man. This brought new troubles and new headaches.

“The man had a maiden daughter who was not unattractive. As soon as the fresh

beauty of the squire caught the daughter’s eye, it caused the greatest fire in her heart

that a maiden’s breast could bear. But the daughter was in love with something that did

not exist; she was chasing smoke and shadow. She signaled her love to the squire, at

first with her eyes and then with her face. Olinda, who was seized by a stronger love,

376

paid her no notice. The maiden, believing that the youth was just inexperienced and

slow in the matters of love, expressed with words what the squire was not grasping from

her glances, and she begged him to bring her aid in her state of distress. Aware of the

sort of aid that was being requested, and knowing that she could not give it, Olinda

responded to the maiden’s words with laughter. Believing she was being mocked, the

maiden responded: ‘What are you laughing at? Am I a ridiculous sight to you because I

am dying? Don’t be so cruel!’ Olinda responded: ‘When you really get to know me, your

love for me will immediately vanish, and hatred will take its place. I beg you, if you love

me, do not tell your father, or anyone. There is nothing more of the male sex in me than

there is in you or your mother. It is up to you to test firsthand what you don’t believe. But

if you inquire what the meaning of this getup is, I will tell you: love and mortal danger

cast me into these clothes and forced me to pretend I was a man.’ She immediately told

the maiden where she was from, whom she loved, whom she had killed, where she was

going, and everything else in the order that it happened. Finally, she began to implore

the maiden to help her with money, which was the thing she needed most—that is,

travel funds so she could quickly get to where she was going. What is that you say? Do

you think that the maiden, hit with such surprising news, cast her hope or her love out of

her mind? Nothing could be farther from the truth. On the contrary, she held onto both

most firmly. She believed what she had read in fairy tales, and what she had heard from

old wives’ tales, that, once upon a time, there were women who had been transformed

into men.120 She reckoned that the same thing could happen to the one she loved. But

silver, and other precious objects, and since her father had left for his country estate,

they marched out in this direction.

“Because it was a favorable time of year, they arrived quickly and stopped

together at an inn. You could see them dressed in men’s clothing wandering throughout

the entire city, their outstanding beauty catching everyone’s attention. How many people

do you suppose would have disputed that there were women under those clothes? The

face of a woman coming in search of her lover was especially obvious. After looking

everywhere and investigating everything, Olinda determined that her lover was here in

this city. After stealthily tracking him, she finally found him (sad to say) ensconced

already for some days in a whorehouse in the company of some prostitute. Out of her

mind with grief she cried: ‘Philotas, have you completely forgotten about me? Have I

endured so much toil and humiliation for nothing? It is because of you that I am without

a homeland and have been behaving like some shameless hussy, while, in the

meantime, you’ve been busy having fun and placing the love of a prostitute before our

marriage!’ She immediately lost hope and became weak from illness. Incredibly, when

assertion (HN VII.4) that “ex feminis mutari in mares non est fabulosum” (“women turning into men is not

378

she became sick, the other woman immediately started to fall ill too, and when the

sickness in one of them increased, it also grew in the other. Finally, when one of the

women died, the other likewise died the same death. The bodies of both women were

carried to the Temple of Cupid on the same day, in the same funeral procession, in the

same coffin. One and the same burial was conducted, so that death could not put

asunder those souls that love had joined together in life; and so that one and the same

tomb would house their bodies.

“Let me return to Philotas, who had sent Olinda to her death unaware that he had

committed such a terrible deed. As soon as he found out about it (since Olinda had

already revealed the whole matter to someone while she was dying), out of breath he

hurried immediately to Olinda’s house after she had just then been carried out.

Dissolving into tears, he cried: ‘So, my heart, I was the cause of your death? I never

understood how much you loved me. Unhappy me that I was not able to enjoy such a

gift! But my sickness over you will strip me of my life as well. Departure from this life

would be marvelous, if it allowed me to breathe my last in your arms!’ He went to throw

himself upon Olinda’s body. He could hardly be restrained and was finally carried away

from there, as if dead, to the home of a friend and compatriot. Since his illness was

increasing, and it seemed like he could not be sufficiently cared for, this same friend

saw to it that he was carried to this hospital here where noblemen are attended to in a

suitable place, and as comfortably as possible with food and other amenities. However,

on account of the season,121 they found the hospital filled to the brim with sick people.

Because of this, it was necessary to place him among the commoners until someone in

121 Summer was peak season for illnesses like quotidian fever, or malaria (see Chapter 3, n. 26).

379

this hospital recovered. When this most noble man, the first among his fellow citizens,

saw himself cast among the dregs of the city he was overcome by such a force of

sickness that he died that very same day. This was the end of the lovers. Thus, as you

can see”:

There is no one on earth that lives a harder life than the lover, and no one

that, if you were wise, you would less wish to be.122

The deadly fate of these poor lovers brought tears to our eyes, and there was

something I wanted to ask about, but I was distracted by the keening of children that

alerted us to an approaching funeral procession, in which the deceased dynast was

being carried. Gallonius rushed toward those voices and brought us with him because

we were eager to see it. The entire procession was organized as follows: boys walked

in front, along with a large number of girls, all of whom had been supported by the

charity of the deceased. Next came the various guilds that had been under his

protection. Many mourners dressed in white followed them, who were singing a doleful

and sad song to the gods of the Underworld in a voice that was modulated to a plaintive

tone. Then the body of the dynast was carried, surrounded by forty candles, on a bier

that was covered in gold and purple cloth. As a sign of respect the rest of the dynasts,

walking in pairs, followed the funeral procession, after all the members of their own

household—and a great number of their own attendants—had gone on ahead. Quite a

few ushers were managing the procession surrounded by lictors dressed in black.

Wherever the funeral procession went, the streets resounded with cries and the

heavens rung out with words such as these:

122 Prop. II.XVII.9-10; translation from Horace and Goold 1990.

380

Now is the time for shedding tears and for pouring forth complaints and

lamentations in sad song. Now is the time to don a black cloak and

conceal your bright clothes. Alas, Alexander—that eminent and renowned

man on whom the sun rose and set—has died an untimely death, like a

flower scattered about by a fast whirlwind. Rome itself, founded atop a hill,

does not stand as high, nor does a torch burn as bright, as honesty,

justice, faith, and simple truth shone in his pure heart. O death, long

accustomed to cut down with your scythe those who did not deserve to

die, while leaving the worst ones untouched, were you able (you savage!)

to witness such grief without pity? Did the long train of pious citizens not

move you, who were endlessly lamenting, with mournful voices, that the

aid, which they and their loved ones depended on in hard times, was

being taken away? Others were crying out: “Who will clothe those who

would keep the cold at bay from their naked bodies?” The widows were

demanding: “Who will share their meal with sons who have lost their

father?”

The benevolent townspeople proclaimed these and similar things about Dynast

Alexander in his presence. For this reason, it was unanimously decided, then and there,

that oftentimes it was Fortune rather than hard work or diligence that benefited men in

search of renown. That dynast, who was being received in death with such favorable

acclaim by the people, had drawn acclamation based solely on a belief in his generosity

and benevolence, even though he was not very learned and had not achieved any glory

from his deeds. Among other things, his fortune was attributed to the fact that he died

when he had not yet experienced any other lot.123 We did notice that the words of praise

for Alexander’s nephew were mixed in with continuous lamentations of public

mourning.124 They spread the word that the nephew would surpass his uncle in dignity

and glory on account of the integrity and elegance of his life, and especially on account

of his studies of the best literature.

The time of day reminded us to think about dinner, so Gallonius sent his servant

to go shopping. In the meantime, a ship’s captain was brought to us who was going to

set sail the day after tomorrow (if the winds proved favorable) for an island that

everyone said was very beautiful and fertile, and whose inhabitants were peaceful,

cheerful, agreeable, and pleasant. We came to an agreement with the captain on a fare

for the voyage. Afterward, we began to head for a nearby fountain so we could shake

off the heat that was sticking to our bodies, but someone riding in a carriage blocked our

way. In a loud voice the man said: “Gallonius, just the person I’ve been looking for!

Please, if you are not busy, give me your attention for a bit. I must consult with you.” “I

serve at your pleasure,” replied Gallonius. Approaching Gallonius, the man whispered a

few words in his ear and asked him to pass them on to his dynast. Afterward, he

inquired where we were just coming from. Gallonius responded: “From the Temple of

Daphne where I had taken these two young men, my compatriots. They are noble men,

devoted to letters, and they participated with great pleasure yesterday in our academic

endeavors.” Turning toward us, the man said: “How I wish you could have been there

two weeks ago! I demonstrated, in elegant terms, that all solid objects are transparent

and that the element earth, when separated from these lower elements, extends up to

the heavens.” Then he asked me if I had heard anything elegant and witty in that

gathering, to which I responded: “Many things, but most of all I was extraordinarily

entertained by the ingenuity of Hiero, who elicited such abundant praise for a gnat, an

insignificant insect.” Enthusiastically confirming the young Gallutius’s talent for poetry,

382

he then asked: “Did he, by any chance, recite the poem in which he expounds his praise

for Spring? I read it because his father showed it to me. But who is the best poet to

imitate, in your opinion?” “I believe Virgil is the prince of poets.” To which the man

replied: “On that score, he has disappointed me. I am sorry to hear that the quick and

sublime mind of that excellent young man is being stymied by being linked to the

sluggishness and baseness of Virgil, and by not daring to elevate itself higher.” What

are you saying?” I replied. “Does Virgil seem to you to crawl on the ground?”125 “He

would also seem to you to crawl on the ground if you read my poetry,” he responded.

Then I said: “So you are more learned than Virgil?” “More learned?” he said, “What are

you saying? I would be embarrassed to compose verses that were anything like Virgil’s.

If I gave the order, I could remove that talentless and barely educated author from my

library. Listen to what I wrote on the very subject of Spring, and dare to compare Virgil’s

meagerness with my rich abundance of subjects and vocabulary”:

Once Spring126 has resolved to bring an end to the fierce wars of frozen

winter and to the dreadful clash of the elements, behold, shining, she

displays her footsteps on tall Mount Olympus, and, wherever she walks,

she offers lilies with full hands; and Zephyrus127 catches the goddess’s

nose with his fragrance and, with a welcome murmur, lays down a

tapestry decorated with flowers, green foliage, and snow-white plants.

Next the elements, under the gaze of the approaching goddess, set down

their weapons and, subdued by fear, quickly seek out their dwelling

places; the battalions of hateful winter give the order to decamp and,

lacking energy, they do not dare fight back on equal terms, but they bring

125 The Latin phrase “humi serpere” (to crawl on the ground) is used to refer to poetic style that is dull and

does not rise to lofty heights. See Hor. Epist. II.I.250, Hor. Ars P. 28. Erasmus (Adagia 2.10.88) defines

the phrase this way: “Humi serpit oratio, quae pressior humiliorque est quam oportet, semper quasi

jacens, nunquam assurgens” (“speech crawls on the ground if it is plainer and in a lower register than it

needs to be, as if it it always remains dull and lifeless and is never lofty or soaring”).

126 See Chapter 2, n. 269-76 for the extent to which this poem quotes directly from Alain de Lille’s

Anticlaudianus.

127 Zephyrus: the West Wind. It is the gentlest of the winds and, with its fructifying quality, it was

new battles to a different region of the earth. Spring hurls a bolt of love

from her brow and disperses swollen rage from the spirit of warring

peoples; fake kisses of a false peace take over, together with simulated

love joined with feigned concord, which the savage season of cold winter

later beats back with icy cold blows summoning their anger, which had

been banished, back into power. In the meantime, her laughter forbids any

rain clouds in the sky, and angry Notus128 ceases to hurl lightning bolts, or

darts of hail, from his rigid bow. Instead, Favonius’s fertile breeze, glowing

red, fills the pregnant earth’s womb with soft beads of dew, sprinkling it

with beauty. But when the goddess, happily in labor, produces and

scatters flowers, she surpasses laboring Lucina in her duties. Afterward,

sitting on her brilliant throne, the queen inspects the armies of plants

under her command throughout all the lands. She also condemns those

plants of hers to the fire, which do not know how to pay a profit of seed

and fruit to Nature. Everyone suddenly rushes in, clothed in green, and

she, hurrying, bends over and, pulling back her hands, marks the all-

sustaining earth. She raises her head, veiled in branches, and kisses the

clouds. So as to appear limpid in its snow-white vestments, the river, after

ridding itself of foreign sediment and returning to a pure element, clothes

itself completely in brightness. Behold, her roving retinue of flowers places

grateful kisses on the goddess’s hands; the lovely rose, surpassing all the

rest, bears on its face the mark of modesty. All the while the songbirds,

the beautiful lyre players of the countryside, rush willingly toward Spring’s

footsteps, and everywhere they pour forth sweet songs from their

melodious throats, which she, thirsty, avidly drinks down with her ears

and, tipsy, lies down, won over by languid sleep.

“Tell me the truth, have your ears ever heard anything more perfect than this

poem, either in terms of greatness of spirit or in figures of speech and ideas? Look how

it washes over your senses, how it delights them, how the number of ideas is equal to

the number of words! I was the first129 to elegantly invent this style of writing; I made it

famous and fashionable; I opened the way and, imprinting it with my footsteps, showed

it to whoever might wish to follow and to arrive at eternal fame with no detours. Take

this poem, written in my own hand, and adopt it as your teacher for writing poetry.”

While I was accepting his poem and thanking him, Gallonius said: “If you read his

letters, you would absolutely think that, according to the doctrines of Pythagoras, the

soul of Cicero had migrated into him, or that his eloquence had come to him as a

birthright.” When he heard these words, he was deeply distraught and said: “You do me

a dishonor. One line or another of any of my writings is worth more than a hundred

letters of Cicero. Good god, what does that orator have besides a fast-moving gallop of

words and flagging speech without force or energy.”130 A certain dynast, who was

returning from Alexander’s funeral, lifted him into his carriage and out of our sight,

preventing him from saying any more words against Cicero. Afterward, I asked

Gallonius if there was anyone in his right mind who had that man as a patron. “Why?”

he asked. “Because he is mad.”

Without delay, we arrived at an abundantly flowing fountain. There we were

accosted by that philosopher, who, at lunch, had leveled the charge of promiscuity at

just about every woman. When we caught sight of him, Gallonius nodded to us to turn

back and escape from that annoyance. But the philosopher’s shrewdness thwarted our

plan, and he stopped me by grabbing me by my cloak saying: “Where are you rushing

off to? I beg you to stay, as I would like to enter into a lasting pact of friendship with you.

I discovered from today’s discussion that you are not unfamiliar with literature.”

Grabbing my hand, he said: “When you get to know me, you will place me above other

learned men. If you were sworn to identify the best orator or the most learned

philosopher, you would not name anyone but me. I alone, therefore, am a teacher

130 These terms applied to style (in Latin nervi, sanguinis, flaccens oratio) are central to discussions on

style such as those in Cic. Brut. and Hor. Ars P.

385

above all the others. In fact, I do not teach students in the way that other scholars do,

who force their students to waste away in schools, but I lead them to the highest summit

of philosophy via a much shorter method and path. I was the first to discover this path

and, if it does not pain you to walk it, I will declare myself your companion and your

guide. But you will not be able to embark on this path until you have had a sampling of

my genius. Since I have noticed that you have more familiarity with historians and

orators than you do with the masters of other arts, I will present you with the model of

the whole art of rhetoric, which I have copied onto my writing tablets. Once you have

fixed these in your memory, as if on a wall, everything that rhetoric has to transmit will

be available to you at a glance.” “I beg you to go easy,” said Gallonius. “Don’t wear

yourself out and add more annoyance than this heat is already causing.” He replied:

“You will never master it without my advice today on the subject.” Since it was not going

to turn out any other way, I stretched out my neck and handed myself over to my

executioner.

Thus, he began: “The first panel begins with the definition of rhetoric, which is the

ability to see what in any matter might be persuasive.131 Next, I show what the function

of rhetoric is, namely to speak in a manner suitable for persuasion. Third, I explain the
