himself the “first to discover this path” to the mastery of rhetoric, lifts the definition, function, and causes of

rhetoric almost word for word from sections of Cicero’s De inventione and Rhetorica ad Herennium (the

latter once thought to be a work of Ciceronian iuvenilia but now considered spurious). Rossi knows his

readers would instantly recognize these references, since these two books were basic school texts for

anyone who received a humanistic education. Despite being best known today for his mature oratorical

and philosophical works, Cicero’s reputation in the middle ages and the Renaissance derived from these

early works (Ward 2013: 163-96). See also Ward 2006: 3-75; Juys, Ward, and Heyworth 2013. Cipriano

Suárez’s De arte rhetorica libri tres ex Aristotele, Cicerone & Quintiliano praecipue deprompti (first edition

Hispali: ex officina Alphonsi Escriuani, 1569) was a frequently used textbook for teaching rhetoric in

Jesuit institutions.

386

causes of rhetoric.132 First is the efficient cause, which consists of invention and

doctrine. Invention133 is the depiction and observation of one’s nature. One’s nature is

nothing other than an innate aptitude and talent for speaking. Doctrine, on the other

hand, includes theory and practice. Theory is a set of rules that provides a method for

speaking, while practice is the constant exercise and experience in speaking. Next

comes the final cause: to persuade by speaking. The third is the material cause, which

is defined as the issue involved with the circumstances of any matter. Finally, this panel

concludes with a description of the three types of cases: epideictic, judicial, and

deliberative. Epideictic rhetoric comprises praise and blame, namely the amplification of

the good or bad aspects that we assert are in a matter. Its end is to portray honor or

disgrace; its goal, the pleasure of the audience; its tense is present. Judicial rhetoric is

found within the context of forensic debate and it consists of a criminal charge with a

defense. The aim of judicial rhetoric is to determine right and wrong, its goal or end

being the clemency or severity of the judge. A judicial oration should be delivered in the

past tense. Moreover, all judicial oratory involves either a criminal case or a legal

controversy. There are two types of oratory related to a criminal case: an accusation,

which brings a formal charge, and a defense, which seeks to remove a charge. There

are also two types of oratory related to a legal controversy: a civil action, in which

someone is suing another party; or a counterplea, in which someone disputes that the

other party is owed anything. Deliberative oratory comes next, which is used in the

132 The four causes of rhetoric as defined by Aristotle are: efficient, final, material, and formal. Our

philosopher only discusses the first three.

133 Invention is one of the five canons of rhetoric (the others are arrangement, style, memory, and

delivery).

387

context of a general inquiry concerning advice or a recommendation, and it involves the

delivery of an opinion. The aim of deliberative oratory is to determine what is

advantageous and disadvantageous, and its goal is the hope or fear of the person

deliberating. Deliberative oratory should be delivered in the future tense. It is composed

of persuasion, which instructs as to what should be done, and objection, which supports

the opposite. That is the end of the first panel, in which I portray the arrangement of

rhetoric no less realistically than if it had been depicted by the hand of Apelles or

Zeuxis.134 Turn your attention now to the next panel, which places the parts and the

duties of the orator as if before your very eyes.”

At that point Gallonius lost his patience and said: “Hold on, I am thinking of

inviting you to dinner the day after tomorrow. Then, when I am at leisure, I want to see

these tablets you are telling us about. Their splendor demands not a brief sojourn, but

ample time to contemplate them, which today, being almost at an end, does not

accommodate. After all, you are familiar with my responsibilities.” The philosopher,

hearing talk of dinner, lit up and, with a joyful voice, said: “I agree. I will offer up the

wealth of my talents at your house, with the great advantage that it brings, and at the

same time, I will propose what I have said and will say written out on little cards or

panels. And if this man here entrusts himself to me for about a month, he will gain a

familiarity with logic, physics and metaphysics, not just by some birthmark or a rattle but

by their whole body.135 He will tack to the walls of his room the depictions of these fields

134 Two famous ancient Greek painters. Pliny the Elder dates Apelles of Kos to 332 BCE because he

painted a portrait of Alexander the Great. Zeuxis of Heraclea was active in the late fifth century BCE.

135 This is a quote from Cic. Brut. 313 and is a reference to the marks of identification or recognition (like a

birthmark or a child’s rattle) that serve to resolve the plots in ancient comic plays (see Cicero and G. L.

Hendrickson 1952: 271 n. b).

388

of study that I describe on my panels, as if he had created an art gallery, but one much

more elegant than the pictures in which we celebrate the hands of Polyclitus, Zeuxis,

Protogenes, and Parrhasius.”136

After I had praised the man’s learning, I followed after Gallonius as he was

leaving. Gallonius said: “If I had not brought up the topic of dinner, that leech would

never have let us go. For god’s sake, did you see how that inept man cleverly debates

very serious matters in whatever place and among whatever men he pleases?” Worn

out by visions of the insane, I said: “Please, Gallonius, let us get out of here quickly, in

case some other fool starts annoying us to death. We came here under a curse of the

gods.” Gallonius responded: “You’re one to talk! As if it weren’t possible to find a much

larger quantity of stupid people like this in Rome!” “True,” I said. “I don’t have anything

else to say, except that nobody is born without faults, and it is impossible to find any

place anywhere that is inhabited by perfect people.” Discussing these and other things

we returned home where we discovered that the servant, whom Gallonius had sent

ahead of us to the store, had not only returned from shopping but had already cooked

us dinner. After we had eaten it in good cheer, and after many and wide-ranging

conversations, we took ourselves off to bed and gave ourselves over completely to

stillness and sleep until dawn.

136 Famous ancient Greek sculptors and painters. Polyclitus, active between 450 and 420 BCE, was

probably a native of Argos (though Pliny says he was from Sicyon). Protogenes of Caunus (or Xanthus)

was a painter and a sculptor; he was active in the late fourth century BCE and had a friendly rivalry with

Apelles. Parrhasius of Ephesus, active in the later fifth century BCE, created such realistic images that,

according to an anecdote by Pliny the Elder, he tricked Zeuxis into believing that some curtains he

painted were real (Oxford Dicitonary of Art and Artists, 4th ed.).

389

Book Five

Because we had no obligations requiring us to get up early, we slept in very late

the following morning. When both the time of day and our empty, barking stomachs

started demanding food we called for our undershirts, waistcoats, trousers, and

leggings. When we were dressed Gallonius said: “After my dynast has finished eating I

think I’ll take you to the senate house. You will enjoy looking at the bronze and marble

statues there, as well as the paintings created by the hands of our best artists. It is

common practice to hold sessions of the senate, and to train and maintain magistrates,

in villas that are filled with such art objects. The senate is where the poliarchs137 (that is

what those particular magistrates are called) hear and adjudicate the cases of people

who appear before that court. A long time ago, before this Republic had come under the

power and guidance of the dynasts, the most important cases and policies fell to the

decision and judgment of the people, because it was in them that the supreme power

and authority was located. So as not to be completely stripped of their power after the

Republic’s wealth had been depleted by civil unrest, and after they had entrusted

themselves to the dynasts, the people retained control over the administration of certain

matters; namely, they made sure that fraud was removed from all transactions of buying

and selling, particularly of foodstuffs, and that there was a uniformity with regard to

measurements and weights.

The poliarchs set the prices for most goods, establishing quantities and weights,

and if some crime is committed—for example, if an item has been sold for a greater

137 Poliarchs are the equivalent of Roman senators. Poliarchus also happens to be the name of the

mysterious nobleman suitor (eventually revealed to be the King of France) of the princess Argenis in John

Barclay’s eponymous novel.

390

price or if an ounce or two ounces has been taken from the pound138—it is the poliarchs

who determine appropriate penalties and punishments. The poliarchs have appointed

certain people to keep an eye out for fraud. These people go around every morning to

the butcher shops, taverns, and marketplaces and, when they encounter anyone

carrying meat, wine, fish, bacon, or anything of that sort, they stop him, ask where he

bought it and for how much, and they weigh it with a scale that they carry with them for

that purpose, or they measure it with a half-pint measuring cup. If these monitors come

to discover that the purchased items do not correspond to the established measure and

weight, they force the seller to return what he has fraudulently acquired, and they report

his name to the poliarchs. Because the poliarchs trust the people reporting to them and

do not require further proof, they either levy a fine against the guilty party, or they make

him pay in the form of some sort of corporal punishment. It was for this reason that this

type of responsibility was once given to the best and the richest men, whose testimony

was credible, so there would be no suspicion that any money had changed hands. Now,

however, the dominant practice is that, among those who wield power in this Republic, it

is the ones with the least amount of money who are drawn to these positions. Because

of this, thieves who are caught red-handed often escape their just punishments for a

small fee, since the bonds of law and justice that used to keep them in check have been

severed.”

Then I (speaking also for Paulus) said: “Gallonius, there is nothing we would

rather see than this senate house you speak of.” He replied: “I will soon satisfy your

desire. Let’s be off.” We had only just set foot outside the house when we saw a man,

138 The Latin refers to Roman measurements: “if an ‘uncia’ or a ‘sextans’ has been taken from the ‘as.’”

391

with an honest face and elegant dress, knocking on someone’s front door. A woman

called out from the window: “Who is banging on my door?” “It’s me,” he replied.

“Somebody please open the door.” She answered: “You came just in time, sir; we don’t

have any vegetables in the house for lunch. Go buy an obol’s worth,139 if it’s not too

much trouble.” He replied: “Good thinking. I’ll go fetch some. Make sure lunch is ready

when I get back.” “Yes, sir,” she said. “Off you go with the gods’ blessing.” Gallonius

said: “How charmingly that maidservant has kept her master away from the house! If

you don’t mind hanging around here for a bit, you will witness some very delightful

shenanigans. The lady of the house is beautiful and in the bloom of youth. She is the

wife of that man who has just been sent off to buy vegetables. She is having an affair

with a wealthy tax collector, in cahoots with her husband. But in order to turn the tax

collector into Phryxus’s ram140 and fleece him out of his gold right down to his hide, she

has persuaded him that she is consenting without her husband’s knowledge. She said:

‘If he gets wind of any of this, even a little bit, we will all be done for. He is an angry,

violent, and savage man, and you will meet the usual fate of adulterers.’ In truth,

though, there is no gentler a fool than that billy goat, nor one who is more under the

thumb of his wife. Nevertheless, in order to provide a reason for the tax collector to be

afraid, the husband and wife decided that if, upon returning home (and after she had

given a signal), the husband was to discover that the adulterer was inside, he would find

some excuse to stay away from the house until the adulterer came running outside.”

139 An obol is a small Greek coin, the sixth part of a drachma, which is worth about the same as the

Roman denarius.

140 Phryxus was rescued from his stepmother by a ram with a golden fleece, who carried him to safety

over the Hellespont (named for his twin sister who fell from the ram and did not make it). This is the same

golden fleece that Jason later recovered with the aid of Medea.

392

Hardly had Gallonius recounted this than—you guessed it—the doors burst open and

spit the adulterer out. “What did I tell you?” said Gallonius. “How about that! If we had

time to hang around here longer, and I were not, as you know, being summoned

elsewhere, you would see porters flying over here with baskets carrying that stinking

goat a hot lunch. This land is filled with these sorts of people, and it is no wonder that

their number has greatly increased, for this business is by far the most profitable. This is

a way for a man to accrue riches, enjoyment, and offices, and to attract the delight and

devotion of the nobility. For this reason, if such a man chances upon a reasonably

attractive woman—and if she is for sale—gift bearers run to him in whole regiments141

with gold, clothing, and everything he needs. This practice thrives above all else

because, as I have said, wealth is held in high esteem, while poverty is thought to be for

the disgraced; leisure and luxury are sought after, while hard work and humility are

shunned.

“But there are different kinds of husbands. Some are not secretive and silent in

their shamelessness but are public and open about it. As far as they are concerned, so

long as they have something to eat and drink, they do not care what people say about

them on a daily basis. Other, slightly more honorable husbands want the public to think

they do not know what they know and do not see what they see, even though they have

the same desire to consume more than they can manage and indulge in clothes. In

order to grant adulterers freer access to their wives, they often ride out to the country,

and they sometimes remain away from their hometown, and from their homes, for

141 The Latin word is maniplatim (i.e., manipulatim), which means “in whole maniples.” “There were 120

men in each maniple of the velites, hastati, and principes of the Roman army, and 60 in each maniple of

the triarii. Four maniples made a cohort” (Plautus and Leo 1895: n. 6 to Pseud.).

393

months at a time. If one of these powerful men possesses an unrestrained spirit and

wants to keep the other men’s wives with him, it happens fairly often that the husbands

are put in charge of a trireme or of a town, so they not only stay away from home while

they are at sea or governing a town, but they do so gladly with honors and benefits.

When these men return home, their wives welcome them cheerfully and joyously and

wrap them up in an embrace. One wife pulls out a purple and gold necklace; another

shows off a canopy, a rug, and ivory couches; another opens the pantry, wine cellar,

and granary to show off the grain that will last their family a whole year. She says: ‘Look

what my mother and my sister gave me for my birthday, and what my in-laws sent me

for Quinquatria, Compitalia,142 and the Circus Games!’ These good men happily believe

their wives and do not think that the matter needs to be scrutinized more closely. They

even say that it is this great multitude of whores that has produced the huge expenses

we are laboring under nowadays. Don’t you see those women who command a retinue

of maidservants and go around adorned with gold and dressed like queens? In fact, if

these husbands are unable to provide for their wives’ expenses, they urge them to take

many lovers, who divvy up the terrain among themselves, so that one lover sees to her

headdress, another to adorning her neck, another to her hair, another to her pantry, and

another to her table.”

While Gallonius was telling us these things, we inadvertently walked right past

his dynast’s house. When we realized this, we turned back and went in at the very

moment he was ordering the master of the feast to prepare the dining couches for him.

142 The Quinquatria, or Quinquatrus, is a festival in honor of Minerva that falls on the fifth day after the

ides; the Compitalia is a festival in honor of the Lares, the gods of the hearth.

394

Without delay, Gallonius entered the kitchen, prepared and garnished the banquet, and

carried it out to the table. The dynast washed his hands, took his seat, ate lunch, and

once he had eaten he got up and withdrew to his room. We headed immediately to the

senate house on the Capitoline where we came across the poliarchs holding court and

immersed in the administration of justice. They were surrounded by fishmongers,

innkeepers, cooks, sausage makers, confectioners, fishermen, and poultry sellers.

There were so many of them that they would have overwhelmed the poliarchs had there

not been a barrier in the way to protect them. The place was filled with a foul stench

wafting from the tradespeople. Likewise, the din they made sounded like a stormy sea.

Each one was saying something different: “Don’t impose a fine on me! Remove me from

your register of offenders!” Another one was shouting: “Poliarchs, I will be distressed if

you don’t help me!” This one gave false information; another one reminded a poliarch of

their long-standing friendship; that one over there counted out money; and another one

implored the faith of gods and men. Since it was a day for hearings, and the senate had

to be called into session for the most important and serious matters, when the time

came that the poliarchs had deliberated enough they announced: “Court adjourned!” All

of the litigants left, having been released by the bailiff’s command.

The poliarchs left the senate house and arrived at the curia where they were

awaited by the buleutas (their word for senators) who were gathered in a big crowd. As

the poliarchs entered, everyone stood up out of respect. Gallonius in particular was

seized by a desire to know what important matter was driving this extraordinary session

of the senate. He asked: “Are there enemies at the gates?” They responded that they

needed to set the price of pickled salt fish because Fortune had carried a ship full of it to

395

their shores two days earlier.143 Next they had to decree how many pears and plums

should be sold for one obol. After the buleutas had taken their seats one of the

poliarchs, who was older than the others, moved the following resolution,144 that, if it

pleased the conscript fathers, a pound of pickled salt fish should not be sold for more

than one nummus. He declared that the price of fish had fallen, and he presented the

example of the fishmongers’ unreasonable demands, who sold at a very steep price

what they themselves purchased very cheaply. It was the greatest desire of the

senators to pass a senatusconsultum145 in response to the poliarch’s words. Thus, they

made an official declaration that a fishmonger, if he himself had purchased a pound of

salt fish for less than an as and a half, was not allowed to resell it for more than a

nummus. But they were not able to reach any decisions that day, both because it was

late and because those scoundrels had found people to run out the clock by orating.

While the poliarchs were talking among themselves after the senate had been

adjourned, a man rushed in announcing that their lunch was getting cold. He advised

them to hurry up and take their place at the table, because the day was already half

gone. “He’s right,” said one of the poliarchs. “Let’s go.” While he was hurrying off to

lunch he spotted Gallonius in the crowd. “Hello there!” he said. “I would like you, and

those two men with you, to join us today.” “No thank you,” replied Gallonius, using his

143 In this fictional account, these price-setting duties are being carried out in the senate, but in Rossi’s

time the standardization of prices, weights, and measures would have been performed by civic

Capitoline Hill. The civic government set and oversaw these standards to regulate the marketplace and

protect buyers from being taken advantage of (Nussdorfer 1992: 71-74; 119-127).

various responsibilities as an excuse. The poliarch replied: “Stop talking nonsense. If

you dare speak another word, by the authority of my office, I will order you to be

shackled and thrown in jail.” Gallonius looked at us smiling and said: “We must obey,

unless we’d rather be taken into custody.” I replied: “I will always prefer a dining couch

to jail and banquets to chains. Do as you please.” He said: “I also think it is preferable to

be tied to a full table with chains of food than to wear thick shackles in jail.”

We followed as he went ahead and were led into a room that was large and

bright with beautiful paneling, bedecked with tapestries, and decorated with images that

were hung around the room in a delightful and elegant manner. In the middle was an

amply and magnificently upholstered dining couch. Set apart from that stood a

sideboard full of objects. There was no pottery to be found; everything was made of

silver: wash-basins, flasks, dishes, vessels for wine and salt, and cups. Many servants

(they call them pistes146) dressed in purple and gold uniforms were running around

carrying ice water for our hands. We washed our hands and, when ordered to do so,

climbed up on our dining couches. The poliarchs were positioned at the head of the

table, we on the far end, and the rest of the diners in the middle. The table was kept

constantly filled with food. They brought in birds, sausages, fish, sweetbreads, and any

other luxury that was in season. When lunch was starting to wrap up, the oldest poliarch

said, almost angrily: “My mouth is watering with thirst. I’ve been sitting here parched for

too long. Someone bring me a glass, and quickly!” The servants ran and fetched him

one. When he brought the glass to his lips the poliarch exclaimed: “By god, this isn’t

wine, it’s the very nectar of Jove himself! Where did it come from? What god sent this

146 Pistes: “trusted ones,” from the Greek word πίστις.

397

wine down to us from the tables of the heaven dwellers?” The servant boy waiting on

him replied: “It was sent to you today as a gift.” “By whom? Who has the financial

wherewithal to send me such a gift?” “It was that tavern owner, the one who sank so

deep into fraud that he sold mixed wine in place of unmixed.” The poliarch replied:

“Such a great man. A man who produces an excellent drink like this, that could prolong

a man’s life, should be acquitted rather than charged on so insignificant an infraction!

Indeed, if this happiness could last forever, I should hope to prolong my life by two

hundred years with this here wine.” He immediately called for larger wine glasses and

ordered them to be distributed as soon as they were brought in.

Iberus the scholar was seated near me, who (as we said before) was a refined

and courteous man. While he was endlessly praising the unmixed wine and greedily

guzzling it down his capacious gullet, a portion of the catfish that was set before him on

a platter flew off, ran with its arms pumping, and took up a new residence. Coming to

his senses and thinking this had happened through a trick of the pistes (which was the

truth), Iberus exclaimed: “These types here deserve a beating. Where in the world are

we? Are we living among the Lacedaemonians or the Cilices?147 Return what you have

stolen from me! Bring back my piece of catfish!” The banqueters laughed, the poliarchs

consoled their friend, and, in order to prevent him from inciting a riot, they each gave

him their portion. He quieted down, his anger resolving into calm. Since they were

drinking so often, which happened almost between each bite, Iberus defended himself

against the dish thieves in the following way: He grabbed a tankard in one hand and

plundered a dish with the other. It was useless to mount a smaller defense against the

147 People from Sparta and Cilicia, respectively (i.e., barbarians).

398

ever-present tricks of so many vultures.148 You had to remain vigilant and keep your

guard up. Some appealing side dish would barely be placed on the table when it

disappeared from view; someone would take his eye or his hand off a dish for a second

when some kite or hawk would catch sight of the treat. As a result, you would have

thought that, instead of lunch, a feast in honor of Hecate was taking place.149

After the meal, ten musicians entered and began playing their flutes most

excellently. The entire hall resounded with the sound of beautiful music, and my ears

had never before heard anything sweeter. But Iberus, who was feeling duped on

account of the catfish, said: “These musicians are making us all go deaf. I’ve been

calling for a drink for ages, and no one can hear me. Get them out of here! We don’t

need any music.” “Agreed,” said the poliarchs. “Get out of our sight, fetch pitchers in

place of pipes, and quickly fill your cheeks with wine instead of with your breath, as you

have been doing up to now.” The musicians attacked, grabbed the wine bottles with no

less speed than when earth falls downward or flames rush upward, and tipped the

bottles upside down into their mouths, or rather, they poured them into an abyss.

When the musicians were out of sight, Iberus asked whether the innkeeper, who

had served them such good wine, frequently committed wrongdoing. “Very often,”

replied the poliarchs. “No hawk or kite has ever managed to free itself from a snare in

which it has become entangled more often than that innkeeper has been able to break

free of every judicial sentence and law. Even if we were to decide to give him the

maximum sentence, the dynasts would not allow us to do so because he has bound

most of them to himself through some favor or other. He stocked a wine cellar for some,

and for others he procures drink on a daily basis. Therefore, the dynasts compete with

each other, as necessary, over providing for his security and well-being, the same way

they would compete for their own glory, fortunes, and fame. But we benefit from his

dishonesty as well. We can always get something out of that innkeeper whether it’s

money, wine, or at least some delicate morsel.” There was some Greek man among

them, put ashore here in a shipwreck as we had been, who, after drinking his fill of wine,

tossed the remainder out of his glass so it made a splash. Iberus was indignant and

said: “Is it your view that this wine deserves to be tossed out? If I had any wine left over

to splash on the ground, it would be because someone was forcing me to drink an

inferior or insipid kind. But I wouldn’t tolerate even one drop of wine this sweet going to

waste.” And in one fell swoop, he filled an enormous bowl with unmixed wine just as

when it had come from the mother vine. When he had finished he proceeded to lick

whatever remained stuck to his scruffy mane with his tongue. On this account, the entire

dinner party overflowed with fun and games.

When the meal was over, the steward approached the poliarchs and asked if

they might give him their attention for a moment, if it was no bother, because he had a

very important matter he had to make them aware of as soon as possible. When asked

what he had to say, he told them, in front all of us, that there were no scrub brushes left

in the kitchen for washing the pots and pans. They had partly been consumed by use,

400

and partly been gnawed on by mice because they were so greasy. Then he wanted

them to give him some money to buy new ones. The poliarchs replied that the matter

was too important for them to make any decision, and also that a determination

regarding a withdrawal of funds from the public treasury was not up to them but to the

entire senate. They said that, out of regard for him, they would call a meeting of the

senate forthwith, and that they would see to it that such a pressing matter was brought

before that body as soon as possible.

When the banquet was finished, everyone went back to his room to get some

rest. We turned our eyes and our attention to viewing the paintings and the beautiful

statues. Because we could not get enough, we spent four hours contemplating them

and left when the day had turned into evening. While we were exiting, we grilled

Gallonius on why he had not immediately rushed to take part in such a splendid

luncheon, seeing as he had been invited to it, but had instead resorted to being dragged

to it with force and threats. “Because,” he replied, “I was ashamed to be seen dining

with men like that.” “What?” I said: “Isn’t that a respectable place of honor?” “The place

is respectable,” he said, “but sometimes the men who go there are not. These days

sculptors, painters, tailors, and (if it pleases the gods) common laborers come to the

luncheon after securing the right to attend by favors or for a price. Because of this, there

are hardly any noblemen who seek this office, except for a few who have been cleaned

out of their wealth. On the contrary, many willingly recuse themselves from it.”

While we were talking, the scholar Aridus bumped into us and we came to a stop.

He asked Gallonius where he was coming from and where he was heading. Gallonius

responded: “We have just left the senate house.” “What business did you have in the

401

senate? Were you called there on behalf of some innkeeper or confectioner?” “No,”

responded Gallonius, “we were invited there for lunch and forced to go by Poliarch

Euclio, the son of his fuller Megadorus.”150 “I understand,” Aridus answered. “Did you

enjoy good wine and fine food?” “Indeed,” replied Gallonius, “I have never had better in

my life.” “I am glad it turned out well for you,” said Aridus. “Where are you going?” asked

Gallonius. “I don’t know where I’m going, or what I’m doing,” said Aridus. “I could barely

tear myself away from a man who was clinging to my side and refused to let go. I was

leaving the Temple of Apollo, where I often go to pray, and this well-dressed old man

came across my path. He greeted me and I returned his greeting. Then he said:

‘Though you have not enjoyed my acquaintance before now, and perhaps you have

never met me, nevertheless I cherish your virtues and desire your friendship.’ I thanked

him and assured him that there was nothing in my mediocre intellect or fortune that he

should admire and look up to (and I did not even dare ask who he was). But he said: ‘If

you knew me, you would know that I am most certainly an upstanding man and, most

importantly, I value a good reputation. And you will not find anyone else of my station or

rank equally desirous of a good name, or who has a wife and children more renowned

for their reputation of modesty. What is more, you should know that I would rather

sacrifice my life and all of my money than allow any blemish, even a small one, to

tarnish my reputation. What need would I have for life, what need for riches and wealth,

if any part of my good name were lost? Besides, every eighth day I bathe myself in a

purifying river and sacrifice a lamb to the gods. But my son is confounding my plans,

150 Euclio and Megadorus are the names of the two fathers in Plaut. Aul. whose children are betrothed to

one another.

402

showing me less deference than is proper to show a father. A few days ago, in hand-to-

hand combat, he pierced his rival with a sword and sent him to Orcus. He is currently

living in exile, but he will soon be allowed to return; that’s what that man in charge of the

Republic promised. Though he is prone to anger, he excels in looks and in many

praiseworthy virtues. And since he is not more than twenty years old, he is thoroughly

charming and handsome from his hair down to his toenails. He fears no competitor his

same age in sword fighting or on horseback. Moreover, he sings in a manner that

makes even Apollo envious.’

“At that point I said: ‘Gosh, that is quite a fine young man you are describing.

What a happy mother is she who has given birth to such a son. What should I say the

boy’s name is?’ ‘Pusillus Pleurae,’151 he replied. ‘Can I ask, is he married?’ ‘May the

gods prevent it!’ he said. ‘At least that is one less worry he will burden me with. But he

does have a sister. She married a young man who, above all, is handsome and loved

by all of the leading men. Besides her appearance (you have likely heard of her beauty),

she plays the flute excellently and matches her voice to the sound of flutes so

beautifully that she could draw even Jove himself down from the heavens. Because of

this there were such throngs of important men coming to hear her that, since my house

could not accommodate their size and number, I needed to rent a much larger palace in

the most exclusive part of the city. Yesterday I paid eight minae for a six-month rental of

that house. Not surprisingly, everyone was eager to hear my daughter. They had not

heard her for a long time, since we had only just now returned from visiting King

151 This pseudonym derives from the Greek word πλευρά meaning rib, or costa in Latin. The Harvard

University Library manuscript key identifies this person as a certain Abbate Costa. See also Eud. 1998,

Lib. V n. 7.

403

Anthimus, who, after summoning us with the greatest enticements to his sister’s

wedding, hosted us for eight whole months. I love my daughter because she obeys me

and fears the gods. I care only for her because she takes care of me and clothes and

dresses me quite finely. But as to how her estate, which is very meager, can sustain

such expense, I do not think that is for an upstanding father to investigate.’ When I

heard this I finally understood this man to be the father of the famous courtesan

Pleura.152 Seized with a sense of shame greater than I could possibly describe—and

fearing that I would be seen walking with him on the street—I tore myself away from his

side by lying and making excuses, and I escaped from that disgrace.” “Well, what do

you know!” said Gallonius. “Yet another type of goat I had forgotten about; the kind who,

although he is the lowest of the low, strives to ingratiate himself into other people’s

esteem by feigning honor and virtue. But the impudence of such a man is even more

intolerable because he tries to obscure the most manifest and clear matters by insisting

152 Margherita Costa (1600-1664) was a virtuosa singer, performer, and writer who frequented the salons

of Urban VIII’s Rome. Her work Li buffoni (Florence: Massi e Landi, 1641) was the first printed comedy by

a woman (Cox 2011: 92). I translate the Latin word meretrix here as “courtesan,” whereas elsewhere I

translate it as “prostitute” or “whore” (for example in reference to the character Nanna in Book Two). The

courtesans (or virtuose) of early modern Italy, whose singing and recitations were an integral part of the

entertainment of courtly life, “persisted as one of the great tourist attractions” of urban centers such as

Rome and Venice (Cohen 1991: 201-2). The characterization of these female performers as prostitutes is

frequently found in the contemporary writings of men in elite academic circles where such descriptions

functioned as a “kind of ‘society game’ usefully facilitating relations among men” (Cox 2008: 193, as

quoted in Brosius 2009: 17). Rossi himself, for example, offers the following description of Margherita

Costa in his Pinacotheca (1729: 694): “Margarita Costa, non magis canendi artificio, quam turpi quaestu

famosa” (“Margherita Costa was famous not so much for her skill in singing as for her dishonorable

profession”). On the other hand, the virtuose performers of early modern courtly society were expected to

have sex with their elite patrons should they be asked to do so (Brosius 2009: 31-2). Cohen (1991: 201-2)

stresses that the rhetorical distinction between sophisticated “courtesans” and lowly “prostitutes” or

“whores” is one that has been retrospectively imposed by the prejudices of later scholars who, while

examining the status of the women who moved in the elite courtly circles of early modern Italy, “have tried

to deal with the ambiguity of the prostitute’s complex role by highlighting one dimension and implicitly

denying another.” Giachino (2002: 213, n. 76) identifies Pleura as either Francesca Caccini (known as “La

Cecchina”) or Leonora Baroni—both virtuose singers, instrumentalists, and composers—but the

identification as Margherita Costa is the most plausible one given pseudonym’s derivation from the Greek

word πλευρά (costa in Latin, or rib in English).

that it is dark at high noon. He was openly lying about his daughter being summoned to

loan, but she was tossed out as far as possible from the borders of his kingdom—on

account of the scandals and chaos she caused—and she made her way back to her

homeland.”

“But enough about that,” said Aridus. “Has any word reached you about Lyco153

the banker running away?” “Nothing,” replied Gallonius. “But what’s this I hear? Lyco

the banker did what wicked slaves are wont to do?154 If what you say is true, those ten

minae that I deposited at his bank yesterday have most certainly disappeared.” “Cheer

from sunup to sundown, he never stopped accepting deposits of silver that were

brought to him; paying out to everyone what he had taken on deposit; not recording

anyone’s account as paid; and making excuses to those who brought him promissory

notes for money that had been sent to them, saying he was too busy and asking them

to come back the next day. Flush with cash because of this, he fled in the dead of night,

or rather, he hid himself in the palace of some powerful man, whose protection he

enjoyed, in order to stash the money he had stolen in a safe place. Among the many

153 Lyco is the name of a banker (“Lyco trapezita”) in Plaut. Curc. This story about Lyco the banker, and

the following story about Harpax the cloth merchant, are replete with technical terminology about credit,

debt, collateral, and promissory documents, reflecting Rossi’s own early-career training in contract law

under the mentorship of the renowned Sienese lawyer Lepido Piccolomini. In a 1632 letter to Guilelmus

Moonsius he recounts that he trained in contract (i.e., private) law rather than criminal law: “reos autem

dico, non eos qui causam capitis dicunt, sed quorum res est unde et reus stipulandi et reus promettendi,

reus debendi, et reus credendi, reus satisdandi et reus accipiendi” (“I am not talking about those involved

in capital crimes but those whose cases have to do with creditors and debtors” (stipulandi/promettendi,

debendi/credendi, satisdandi/accipiendi are all different ways in Roman law of expressing creditors and

debtors).

154 The runaway slave is a frequent trope in ancient literature, and instances of fugitive slaves are well

attested in documentary evidence (Bradley 1994: 118-121).

people who had been dashed against this rock there were a great many honest

“Who is Harpax?” I asked. “He is that well-known cloth merchant who had that

draper’s shop at the bottom of Janus’s Exchange where he spent his youth. Four years

ago, when he got tired of working, he was overcome by a great desire to declare

bankruptcy, even though his business was still whole, indeed flourishing. He didn’t lose

anything in a shipwreck, none of his merchandise was destroyed in a fire, and there

were no extraordinary expenditures causing him to run up a large debt. On the contrary,

everything always proceeded according to plan and, thanks to a life lived with difficulty

and sparingly, his various business interests amassed money and resources. Do you

need proof of this man’s frugality? Here it is: He never threw away any used piece of

paper,156 but instead he diligently collected them and saved them to use as envelopes

for letters that he sent to others. He never cut the twine that bundles of letters sent to

him were bound with, but instead he untied them and put them to other uses. I could

155 Harpax is the name of a character in Plaut. Pseud.

156 The Latin word given here is opistographum, a parchment or papyrus that has text written on both

sides. The significance of that word choice in the context of the man’s parsimony is that, if a sheet of

paper or parchment is only written on one side, it could be reused to write something on the clean side. If

it is written on both sides, however, it is no longer useful, and therefore, presumably, most people would

throw it away. The pannarius is so cheap that he nonetheless succeeds in finding a use for it.

give you a million157 examples, if I had the time. One day, after lunch, this man, being so

showed him how wonderful it was to abound in riches and told him that loyalty, honesty,

and a good reputation were meaningless words. He informed his nephew that, to this

day, he had never been able to use good esteem or reputation in place of cash at the

bank or the butcher shop, and he had never seen anyone purchase fowl, fish, or any

other delicacies at the store with such currency, but only with ready cash. He told him

that he had sacrificed enough for his work and his business ventures; that he was now

ready to spend his subsequent working life and years more agreeably; and that he was

determined to lead a different sort of life that was, of course, charming, noble, pleasant,

and filled with delights. But their own business was unable to provide for such expenses

because it was not large enough. He informed his nephew that he had decided to seek

the help of other people’s money; that is to say, he decided to enrich himself via the

financial loss of others. He said: ‘It would be financially beneficial for us not to return the

money we owe. Therefore, while I spend the afternoon napping in peace, you run over

at full speed to the state treasurer’s office and, faking the loss of our merchandise and

our ruin, pry out of him—with entreaties and tears—an official document, or an order

that warns any creditors to leave us alone. I will take care of the rest. They shall sweat

it, god willing, and it will not be difficult to obtain what we want, since we hold a lot of

sway over the treasurer. This much I know: the theft will be manifest, odious, and

157 The Latin is sexcenta, which is literally six hundred but is used to mean an innumerable amount, which

is akin to “a million” in English.

shameful. Besides that, we will be the talk of the town. But what do I care? Do I have

“When he had finished speaking, he gave himself completely over to sleep, his

mind at ease. His nephew left to do as he had been instructed. He visited the treasurer

and recounted how Harpax had been cleaned clear out of his possessions, and how he

feared the savagery of his creditors. The wicked nephew carried out this deception with

tears and with a confounded look on his face. Finally, he begged the treasurer to help

his uncle. The treasurer, moved by the trust he had in the speaker, and also by a sense

of pity, granted the nephew more than he could have hoped for. After he had

successfully taken care of business, the nephew returned home rejoicing and found his

uncle still snoring. His uncle was sound asleep, and he did not wish to wake him up.

Instead, he placed the written order against his uncle’s pillow and left the room. Harpax

woke up, and, while he was yawning and stretching, he bumped his nose against the

document that had been placed near his head. He picked it up, looked at it, read it, and

exclaimed with joy: ‘I am rich!’ And to his sister’s son, who had come running when he

heard his voice, he said: ‘Well done, young man! Beautiful! Quick thinking! Nicely done!

Congratulations, now you are one of us! Because of your extraordinary sense of loyalty

toward me, your uncle, you deserve to enjoy my riches with me equally, and even more

so.’ Without delay, as is the way of those who squander other people’s money, he

closed up his shop and proceeded to act like someone who had declared bankruptcy.

“In the meantime, the rumor about Harpax’s bankruptcy started to spread.

Everyone thought it was astonishing, strange, and unbelievable that that man, who just

four hours earlier had been in such great shape in terms of his wealth and reputation,

408

had been cleaned out of everything in the blink of an eye and had fallen into ruin. But he

had no shortage of creditors. They rushed to the praetor’s office, told him what had

happened, and successfully pleaded for Harpax to be taken off to jail. Lictors hurried to

Harpax’s house, ran in, seized him, and tossed him into chains. He stuck the quaestor’s

written order in the lictors’ faces, fended off their attack, shook their confidence, and,

after mocking them shamelessly, told them and his creditors to go to hell. His creditors,

when they saw that their plan had been foiled, got together, complained, consulted with

each other, and sought the best course of action. But all of their plans fell flat and they

could not figure out what to do.

“While they were all in a rage, a man came forward who was in cahoots with

Harpax (and had been secretly dispatched by him), and he pretended to have a large

balance with Harpax. He said: ‘If you will permit me to give you advice, I will work out

some sort of terms of agreement with him. Although he has a great deal of wealth, his

mother nevertheless claims a significant part of it as her dowry, as does his sister’s son.

Each of them surpasses our claim, both in the amount of money and in the length of

time they have had a claim to it.’ None of the creditors doubted that this man would be

able to work out an agreement with Harpax. They said that a partial repayment would

be preferable to losing everything, and they assigned this man the task of going to

Harpax, taking up their cause, and settling the matter with him with as little damage to

themselves as possible. The man returned the next day and informed them that he had

just barely persuaded Harpax to pay half of what he owed to each creditor, within two

years, and that he had gotten him to agree, with the greatest force, to offer up his

mother and his sister’s son as collateral for what he had promised. They all cried out:

409

‘What audacity! What impertinence!’ What could be a more impudent proposal than

agreeing to have only half of what is owed to you returned, and, adding insult to injury,

to have to beg for that amount to be portioned out over two years? The man who had

reported back to them said: ‘Do as you please; his mother’s and his sister’s son’s debt

has surely depleted his resources. As far as I am concerned, I am definitely set on

coming to an agreement with him.’ After their anger had calmed down, the poor

creditors realized that they were caught between a rock and a hard place. They

unanimously decided to submit to Fortune and to accept the deal that was on the table.

They made their decision based on the word of the man who had proposed the

agreement, and to that end they all consented to it in writing.

“Harpax, who had just been enriched by such a recent windfall, rented a

magnificent villa on Janus Hill at great expense (a beautiful place far removed from

onlookers), along with its adjoining gardens.158 He acquired a carriage, servants for his

household, and he hosted sumptuous and splendid feasts on a daily basis. In order to

redeem himself in people’s estimation via some deception, and in order to make it

appear as if he had lost all of his possessions due not to his own mistakes but to

Fortune, he visited the temples of the immortal gods. Praying at all their altars on his

knees he cried”:

“Father Janus,” with loud voice “Apollo,” then moves his lips, fearing to be

heard: “Fair Laverna, grant me to escape detection; grant me to pass as

just and upright, shroud my sins in night, my lies in clouds!”159

When Aridus had finished speaking, everyone fell silent. After a short time

Gallonius, as if awakened out of a sleep, either shaken by the pain of his shipwrecked—

or rather his sunk-to-the-bottom—money, or driven mad with rage, said: “These thieves

and robbers who get caught red-handed, if it were up to me, they’d all be hanged! Why

is it my fate that, for the last three years, no one has gone bankrupt without throwing my

own fortunes into chaos? Did not Pleusides,160 who went into banking two years ago,

also pull a fast one on me? He robbed me of four minae.” “He didn’t fool me,” said

Aridus. “When you look at his face, his very head and eyebrows seem to reek of the

cross and cry out for the fork,161 don’t they?” Gallonius followed up: “But he did it with

such elegance! Before he laid a hand on anyone’s money, keeping it secret from

everyone, he had it recorded in the public record that he had no place on earth to call

his own; and that everything which was thought to be his actually belonged to his uncle

and his aunt. At that point, he began taking money from everyone and trading it. Finally,

loaded up with cash, he pulled up stakes and went to the next kingdom over from this

island, in order to swindle more people out of their money. I hear that he has

established a new bank there, that is to say, a new mechanism for plundering.”

Aridus said: “Why don’t you also tell this man about the theft of Septimus

Pleusippus, the most shameless of all of the thieves we have been discussing. Is it

perhaps because you managed to escape from him unharmed and didn’t lose your shirt

along with the others?” “My god, I had forgotten about him. There are so many of those

160 Name of a character in Plaut. Mil.

161 The cross (crux) and the fork (furca) are two forms of punishment for thieves and criminals. The former

is the most severe where the criminal is nailed to a wooden structure in the shape of a cross. The latter is

a piece of wood in the shape of a letter A, which was placed on the shoulders and around the neck of the

offender, whose hands were tied to it. (L&S; Smith’s Dictionary of Greek and Roman Antiquites).

thieves around that it’s no wonder the sheer number of them makes me unable to

his father as rightful payment of the notes he had bought. His father, after it seemed that

he had satisfactorily made his family estate whole, called his son and said: ‘Son, we

have done enough to satisfy our obligations. We have satisfactorily taken care of our

family estate, and Laverna has been sufficiently on our side. It did not make me happy

impose no limit on their thieving. For this reason, I think you should do what bankers

often do, which is to discharge your debt by fleeing; that is, to hide yourself away in the

house of some dynast, until such time as I am able satisfy your creditors with some sort

162 The Latin phrase is “quem maliciose emancipaverat.” According to Roman law, sons remained under

their father’s legal control (“patria potestas”) until their father’s death. This meant that a son did not exist

as an independent legal entity and could not, for example, own any property of his own. A son could

become independent while the father was still alive only via the legal process of emancipation

(emancipatio) at which point he became “sui iuris.” The sense here is that Septimus needs his son to

open his own bank in order to buy up his (the father’s) debts, so he schemes to emancipate him in order

to make that possible under the law.

412

of settlement. It will be just as much my responsibility to see that you are permitted to

show your face in public again as soon as possible.’

“Septimus did not delay but immediately dispatched several people to spread the

word that his son had become bankrupt. Hearing this news, the creditors rushed

forward, besieged his house, made a list of his possessions, and put a seal on the

records.163 Septimus came upon them while they were at this and said: ‘What does my

household owe you?’ ‘You’ll soon find out,’ they responded. ‘Walk to court!’164 Septimus

willingly obeyed, approached the praetor, demonstrated that his emancipated son was

responsible for managing his own affairs, and that the matter had nothing to do with

him. Thus, he was sent away a free man, and the creditors went away crestfallen. But

the beloved father, mindful of his promise, made a deal with the creditors regarding his

son’s return. He gathered them together and proposed taking steps by which the

majority of the debt that he owed the poor creditors would be dissolved. Those who

thought they had completely lost their money seized upon what little they were able to

walk away with, as if it had been sent down from heaven. But instances of good fortune

hardly ever occur alone, but they arise joined together in pairs. Septimus was so

successful in his thieving that he turned the unsecured notes, which he had sold to his

son, into good cash. From those who owed him, he exacted the entire amount. Many of

163 Placing a seal on the house or effects of someone accused of theft was a way for an accuser to

prevent the removal of the stolen goods, which he needed both as evidence of the theft and because he

wanted to get them back (Cicero and Yonge 1903).

164 The Latin is ambula in jus. That a defendant must go to court when called is the first law of the Twelve

Tables: “Si in ius vocat, ito, ni it, antestamino; igitur em capito” (“If a plaintiff summons a defendant to

court, he shall go. If he does not go, plaintiff shall call witness thereto. Then only shall he take defendant

by force”). An example of this in Roman literature can be found, among other examples, in Plaut. Pers.

IV.ix.745, in which Saturio orders the leno to walk to court.

his guarantors pleaded vigorously and swore oaths as to their insolvency to get him to
