“One difficulty remained that tormented Septimus’s son, who was desirous of a

good reputation, and that was the dishonor and disgrace that he had attached to

himself. He asked: ‘Will I ever be able to look my fellow citizens in the eye or show my

face to my people?’ To which the young man’s father responded: ‘Be quiet, you fool. In

this town it is money that is respected, not one’s reputation. As long as your funds are

intact, if you ever incur a stain on your reputation, it is easily washed away.’ But the son

immediately replied: ‘Father, I believe I have discovered a way to recover my lost good

name. There is a philosopher here from the Stoic school who enjoys a great reputation

and renown among the people. During the public assemblies he holds on feast days, he

inveighs against the luxury and greed of our citizens. Everyone admires him as if he

were descended from heaven. I am set on following this man and on joining myself to

him in close association. In this way, I can hide whatever wrongdoing I commit behind

his uprightness.’ His father approved of this plan, so the son devoted himself to this

philosopher, clung to his side, sat next to him while he was addressing the crowds,

guarded his cloak, and carried his handkerchief which he used to wipe away the

philosopher’s perspiration. While he wanted to hide, however, he ended up exposing

himself; while he strove to heal the wounds of his dishonor, he made them worse,

because people became irritated and offended by such a rotten deception.”

Following up on this story with sharp words, Aridus took his spectacles out of

their case, placed them on his nose, and directed his gaze toward the top of the town

square. Gallonius looked there as well and said: “Look, it’s Salvius Typhernas with

414

Lepidus Gallutius Sinister, son of Minutius. Aridus will immediately go over and praise

Lepidus, and he will encourage him in his pursuit of virtue with his extemporaneous

verses.” And Gallonius was not wrong; Aridus walked toward Lepidus and began thus:

Farewell, propitious light of the Muses, noble progeny of the Sinister line;

no lineage is more distinguished than yours, whether in regard to the piety

of its men or the sheer number of its ancestors. Aridus greets you,

burdened by old age, but burdened even more by the great weight of an

ancient fault that has driven his soul, which had been striving upward,

down toward the deepest depths. His persistent habit of sinning gives

weakens a man’s strength in battle, should a fierce army of sins take up

arms in combat. But even at your tender age you have a venerable mind

that is beyond your years, a steadfast love of probity, and a desire for

praise. Such beautiful wisdom feasts on its own nectar. What wonder is it

that mad pleasure cannot make sport of him with false makeup or smear

him with ugly mud? Hail to your soul! Hail to your mind! The lofty and

celebrated virtue of great Hercules shines similarly. He found narrow

paths preferable to wide ones and steep crags preferable to flowers and

beautiful fields. That is to say, he placed harsh labor and hazardous war

above wretched leisure and feather beds. Overcoming this, he struck

down the fierce hydra in combat and subdued the fabled monsters with his

fateful labor. He subdues and hobbles wild beasts with strong chains, and

his noble courage finds nothing to be insurmountable. Young man,

capable of a hundred noble arts and pliant as wet clay, you will imitate

anything as long as your fertile mind has access to frequent cultivation. Do

it quickly; do not delay. What joys will rise in you when your glory, with the

swift wings of a bird, smites the lofty air and places you among the highest

stars? In addition, what dire cohort, what savage troop of troubles may

pass you by, what sad cares can be scattered from your whole heart,

when you scorn and shrink from those things which lacerate the gloomy

mind with burning spurs and infect it with marks that can be blotted out

only with floods of tears? Oh, if only I—not slothful as I was before—were

permitted to live my youth over again, committing my path to your

footsteps. But, since the period of time past does not return, it remains for

me to see you forge ahead at an unhindered pace, through the liberal arts,

all the way to the heights of lofty renown; and, joined with a throng that

hangs on your every word, I would offer you effusive applause from my

joyful heart, whether a chorus of the Muses recites learned poems, or a

thousand eyes admire you as you speak, or whether anyone assumes you

as an advocate for their cases. In the meantime, pass on my greetings to

your father and your brother. So that lasting pride come to your father from

415

your accomplishments, may Lachesis165 spin out her gold thread and let

her not stop drawing out your distinguished life, with her fingers, in rich

thread before your father reaches Nestor’s166 ripe old age.

Aridus would never have stopped pouring forth verses into the wee hours if Gallutius,

who perhaps had somewhere to be in a hurry, had not said goodbye and left. Aridus

turned to Gallonius and said: “I am sorry I had to be the bearer of bad news.” “On the

contrary,” said Gallonius, “I am grateful that you kept me informed. I just have to ask my

dynast to send word to the praetor, for the sake of his reputation, that no injury befell me

during Lyco’s trial. I do not doubt that, in exchange for the service I faithfully render to

him, he will take up my protection.”

Iberus, the man who, in the academy gathering, had expressed in four verses his

method for maintaining his health throughout the summer, held us up as we were trying

to leave. He was on his way back from the senate house where, besides his luncheon,

he had extracted an afternoon snack from the poliarchs. I stayed willingly because I

desired to make the acquaintance of this most charming man. We saw that he had two

attendants dressed in black following him. Aridus asked which dearly departed he was

mourning, whether it was perhaps his brother, his sister, or his paternal or maternal

aunt. He responded: “I am mourning myself. I am dead.” “What are you talking about?”

said Aridus. “Are you quite well? If this is the state of all dead men, I will not put it off.”

Iberus responded: “I will tell you. I don’t have any family, either my own or by marriage,

who will arrange my funeral when I am gone, or who will place a black ribbon around his

165 Lachesis, one of the three Fates in Greek mythology, measures the thread spun on Clotho's spindle

determines the thread, or length, of life.

166 Nestor of Pylos was famous for having lived a long time (Horace, for example, calls him “ter aevo

functus” Hor. Carm. II.9.13).

416

arm, or around that of a family member, in memory of me. Therefore, I have taken this

responsibility upon myself, while I am still alive, that will not be done for me after I am

dead. If you know where I should arrange for my tomb to be built, please advise.” Aridus

said: “Perhaps in the Temple of Apollo, Minerva, or Mars?” “No,” he responded. “I will

place it near the city wall, at the part where it inclines and slopes downward, the place

they call the Crooked Wall.167 I believe I have found a way that no one has ever thought

of for fixing my name on men’s lips in future generations, or, at least, for flitting about

still living on the lips of men in a livelier fashion than Ennius. As you know, people play

there with a mallet and a wooden ball, and so my rock will serve as a permanent target,

a marker that every player will take aim at and where the words will forever be heard:

‘Let us aim our ball at Iberus’s Rock.’ It will not take much time before that place will

change its name to Iberus Rock. I have a few verses here that I will arrange to have

carved on it.” “By all means, read them, if you don’t mind,” said Aridus. “I confess, I

have never heard a more tasteful plan for propagating one’s name.” Iberus replied: “I

am unable to deny anything you ask”:

Here lies Iberus, who devoted the best years of his life to military service.

Then he served ten whole years at court, although it made him false

promises of great wealth. He barely managed to replenish his purse,

which had been plundered of money, or keep hunger at bay from his

parched lips. Now, where the wall descends from the sloping peak, and

where people are always playing ball with wooden mallets, that dead man

hopes that, if his name is placed as the target where everyone aims their

balls, it will remain eternal throughout the generations.

We all laughed at Iberus’s elegant and delightful talent. He then said: “That’s

enough. Aridus, tomorrow I want to visit your place in the country. Prepare breakfast for

167 The Crooked Wall is a reference to the Muro Torto, a steep stretch of the Aurelian Wall in Rome that

begins at the Porta Pinciana and descends toward Piazzale Flaminio, cutting through the Villa Borghese.

417

me, or better yet, put on a sumptuous meal. Most of all, make sure you don’t offer me

any insipid wine, but locate the most delightful wine available. If not, you are asking for

your vines to be cut down and to pay dearly with your life.” Aridus laughed and said:

“Please, this is not that story where you play the part of a braggart and ferocious

soldier.”168 Entering some pharmacy, Aridus wrote this letter to a friend of his:

Tomorrow, Iberus will dine with me as my guest in the country. He is hale

and hearty and loves good wine. If I am not able to offer it to him, after he

has stuffed himself full he will bring down many crimes of Laverna and

countless troubles on my head. Because, if you do not send me a

quadrantal of wine with which I once fended off a fever and a pestilential

thirst, the insane anger of this Iberus will snap the grapevines on my

country estate into pieces and break my head open with a stick.

When Aridus had finished reading the letter, we all thanked him, took our leave,

and made our way with Gallonius straight to his dynast’s villa. Gallonius was

immediately admitted in to see him. After a short while, he emerged despondent. I

asked him why he was so sad. He did not respond but, with his eyes raised skyward, he

said: “I have wasted five years in the service of that evil man! Gods, let me never be in

need of his aid.” I asked him again what had happened. He began: “After I went inside, I

found him taking a stroll by himself. He stopped when he saw me and waited to hear

what I wanted from him. I told him how Lyco had deceived me and I beseeched him to

write a letter recommending me to the praetor. He cut me off and, barking with laughter

and furrowing his brow, said: “Are you out of your mind to ask this of me? Don’t you

know that I am scrupulous in these matters? The praetor will either declare you to be in

the right, or he won’t. If you are in the right, you don’t need my recommendation

because you will be able to obtain what is rightfully yours from that impartial officer of

168 Reference to the braggart soldier in Plaut. Mil.

418

the court. If you are in the wrong, do you think it would be proper for me to do violence

to the law and subvert a judge’s scrupulousness with my recommendation?’ Unable to

contain my anger I said: ‘When exactly did this sense of obligation take hold of you?

You were not this scrupulous when you vouched (in a manner that could not have been

more enthusiastic, mind you) for that immoral and impious Toxillus.’ He responded

angrily: ‘Get a load of the arrogance and impudence of this man! I must have hired a

lord and master instead of a taster! I vouched for Toxillus because I wanted to. And now

I don’t want to. What is this? Did you hear me? Or aren’t you even listening?’ When I

heard these words, I figured that I shouldn’t wait around for him to fetch a stick and

crush me with blows.”

“What? Is this what has made you sad?” I responded. “Are you so in need of

friends that nobody but your dynast can come to your aid?” “Nothing can be bought

more cheaply around here than men who are willing to be in your debt. All of the

dynasts are inclined toward this practice to the point of fawning. But this goes very

much against my case. The praetor will think that, because my ship has broken apart,

so to speak, vis-à-vis my dynast, I have gotten my hands on some stranger or other’s

letter of recommendation. For this reason (and with this level of suspicion) not only will

the praetor not guide the outcome of my wish toward a safe harbor, as it were, but he

will even allow it to be tossed about and destroyed in a sudden storm.” Then I said:

“What can you do? You must bear the affronts of these first citizens in silence, and you

must soothe your pain with the gifts he lavishes on you daily.” “You must be joking!”

Gallonius said: “May god punish me if, in these five years that I’ve been gnawing at my

dynast’s daily rations, I have become even one gold coin richer from his gifts. But if you

419

had heard him when he first contracted my services, you would have immediately sworn

that all of his wealth and riches would be mine, just as much as his—such were the

promises that he held out in abundance. I especially remember that he promised me

this: ‘Gallonius, just find some way that my favor or help can benefit you and, in that

way, you will be compelled to recognize my favor and devotion toward you.’ You now

see, however, what those promises have amounted to.” Seized by a poetic frenzy, I

broke out into spontaneous song:

Why are you beating your master with an angry tongue-lashing because

he neglected to give you the support he promised? It is not right to resent

an individual for ridiculing you in this way, when so many things are

deceitful and fool you with their tricks. Your farm has a bad year; the sky,

so frequently serene, has tricked you; and your master has destroyed your

safe haven and your trust. You fool—either be harsh enough to include all

of these things in your hatred, or if you don’t wish to, why are you refusing

to pardon only him?

“But enough of this,” Gallonius said. “I don’t want anyone’s unkindness to detract

from my cheerfulness or my attention to dinner. Let’s go shopping. I want to receive you

this evening in a more sumptuous and splendid manner than before, so you will

understand that nobody’s affront can shake my mood.” We made our way to the

marketplace, we bought lamb fries,169 chickens, different kinds of fish, and many other

delicacies, and we went back to the house, dined, and went to bed right after dinner.

But the anger that had arisen from his master’s ungrateful spirit prevented

Gallonius from sleeping, and it continually elicited from him these utterances: “How

unfair so many things that happen to servants are! There is nothing worse than a man

who is both rich and unjust. There is nothing more expensive than an ungrateful man.

169 A culinary term for lamb testicles.

420

There is nothing more destructive to a nation than a ruler who is generous toward bad

men and stingy toward good ones. Honor falls to ruin in those communities where it

perishes if you treat people properly. If people don’t trust those who hold such rewards

in their hands, wicked men will always reap the benefits of honor. He who serves an

ungrateful man is fishing in the air and hunting boar with a net in the middle of the

ocean. A rich man who has exceedingly kind words toward the poor is like a clear sky in

winter and a cloud in summer: neither is to be trusted because it can change suddenly.

A man cannot stay good in a place where people are spiteful and envious of good men.

Nothing is more impossible to understand than the minds of powerful men, because

they highly resent things that you would not imagine. They interpret as anger what you

believe is calmness and interpret as malevolence what you see as love.”

Paulus Aemilius, desiring sleep more than debate, said: “What’s with you and

your wise sayings? Either be quiet or go to sleep. It is pointless to complain when you

are talking to a brick wall. When you go up against somebody more powerful than

yourself, it will always be an unfair fight. Any wrongdoing a master commits must be

thought of as right. If you turn your back on a rich man, you risk stirring up a hornet’s

nest. It is foolish for you to be angry with someone who is more powerful than you. It is

not appropriate for someone, who is dependent on others, to be arrogant.” “On the

contrary,” responded Gallonius. “If you have done him a service you must not back

down. It is wretched to realize that the services you have provided are not appreciated

by the other person. He who accepts favors, but does not return them, is immoral. He is

treacherous who is rich in talk, poor in action, and negligent with promises. It is better to

desert a malefactor than to dismiss a benefactor.” “Criticizing what an ingrate gives you

421

does not change him,” offered Aemilius, “it just makes him worse; it does not placate

him, it aggravates him; it doesn’t calm him, it exasperates him. Put your mind at ease, if

you are wise. A calm mind can never be brought low from its proper state. It is the

height of virtue to bear misfortune bravely, when necessary. Virtue is the highest prize.

Virtue surpasses everything. Virtue contains all that is good within itself. All good things

belong to the man who possesses virtue.” Gallonius replied: “We have already done

enough philosophizing. I will do what I can, since I cannot have what I want. Am I

opposing the gods? Am I as insane as the Titans? Standing up to more powerful people

means doing battle with the gods like the giants did.170 But before sleep creeps up on

us, let me tell you about another thing this man did, which, in my opinion, highlights the

vices of pride, cruelty, and greed.” “As long as you keep it short,” said Aemilius. “You

are aware of what time it is.” “You won’t be sorry,” said Gallonius. “My story will be

shorter than a dwarf.

“Among the members of my dynast’s household there is a certain Nicius Rufus171

who was born to a reputable social rank and was devoted to the study of letters.

Moreover, he was so well equipped with the benefits of Fortune that he didn’t need

anything from anyone. Fifteen years ago, he was enticed by my dynast into his

household, with large promises, to serve as his secretary of the records. My dynast had

started feeling ashamed that everything about himself was more brutish than human,

and therefore he wished to distance himself as much as possible, through the services

170 This is a reference to the Gigantomachia when the race of giants (gigantes) fought against the gods of

Olympus.

171 This is a reference to the author himself (rufus means “red,” i.e., Rossi) and is a fictionalized account

of his time in the service of Cardinal Peretti-Montalto from 1610 to 1623. See also Eud. 1998, Lib. V n. 14.

422

of a scholar like Rufus, from the company of beasts. Since Rufus didn’t fit in at all with

the dynast’s princely surroundings, he didn’t want to stay with the dynast under the

same roof. Instead, he rented another house which was attached to the back of the

dynast’s villa. Rufus had a hole cut through the wall, with the full knowledge of the

dynast, to create a passage to his house through the dynast’s kitchen. Since the

dynast’s house (which was as big as a city) extended a long way inside and was

hemmed in on all sides by countless private dwellings, it was hard to reach the front

door of Rufus’s house without going the long way around. This was a great

inconvenience for Rufus, especially in the winter when he spent many hours, almost

every night, at his master’s house. But within a few months after the dynast had broken

through the wall, the cook stole some worn-out and torn little blankets that were among

that barbaric dynast’s household furnishings. When this theft came to light, the dynast

reckoned that the thief had entered via that passageway and, moved by anger, he

ordered the hole in the wall to be closed up immediately. So that honorable man Rufus

(who, mind you, had been in the dynast’s household since he was a bright young boy)

was forced, after fifteen whole years, to make his way, every single day, to the dynast’s

house—outside, in the dead of night, and sometimes in freezing weather and giant

rainstorms—via a long, circuitous route. Under no circumstances would Rufus have

ever tolerated such indignity and disregard toward himself, had he not feared gaining

the reputation as an unreliable person in a city that is so prone to slander. But I think we

should go to sleep.”

Book Six

Since it was almost time to depart, we got up at daybreak and began preparing

for our journey. We bought clothes made of linen and wool. In addition to these clothes

423

we also packed the finest wines, bread, ham, bacon, sow’s udder, sausages, and other

foods of this sort, so we wouldn’t have to drink the same wine as the oarsmen or always

have to eat ship’s biscuit. Our purse was left almost emptied of money, something that

was a necessity for embarking on a voyage. So, in addition to everything else, we had

to turn our attention to replenishing it. For this reason we decided to sell our emeralds,

topaz, diamonds, pearls, and other gemstones of that sort, which we had brought with

us from Rome. When Gallonius saw our jewels he said: “I will assume responsibility for

making sure you get as much as much as possible for them. Extravagance and greed

have made the value of gemstones (which is perhaps stagnant in Rome because of

their sheer number) skyrocket here. As a matter of fact, this entire island, while it is rich

in wine, olive oil, wheat, gold, and silver, is almost devoid and empty of these luxuries,

and merchants rarely travel here with these sorts of goods. But we need a broker who

can find you a buyer. I will assign to you the same middleman whom everyone uses for

these kinds of transactions. We need to hurry so we can catch him at home.”

We listened to Gallonius and got a move on. A servant of the scholar Aridus met

us as we were rushing along and said: “Greetings, Gallonius! Where are you going?

And why are you in such an all-fired hurry?” Gallonius replied: “I am going to your

neighbor Zancha’s house (that was the name of the broker). I was handed some

business just now that requires me to meet with him.” The servant said: “He isn’t home,

so I’d hate for you to waste a trip. But if you really want a meeting with him, what would

be in it for me if I showed you where you could find him, with little effort and without

going out of your way?” “Tell us where he is,” replied Gallonius. “We are very busy, so

please don’t cause us any delay.” “I recently left him at Natalicius the goldsmith’s

424

workshop at the Middle Janus. But you would do well to walk slowly and not hurt

yourselves on his account. I heard him say he was going to be there for many hours,

and that he was going to be helping out Pamphilus who has gotten married.” “What is

that you say?” said Gallonius. “Pamphilus is married?” “Certainly,” he replied. “And

what’s even more surprising, he married a carpenter’s daughter. But you will learn the

whole story from him, since he talks about it openly with everyone.” “I thank you very

much,” said Gallonius. “But where are you heading with those papers you are carrying?”

“I am bringing them to Dynast Thersippus,172 whom my master has invited to his villa at

his country estate, which is called Cinnus. You may read them if you like. They are filled

with verses and they don’t contain anything private.” “I would love to,” replied Gallonius,

and he handed me the papers he had received from the servant. While I read the

verses over carefully, Aemilius was writing them down in the notebook he had at the

ready:

Thersippus, capable both in your studies and your talents, add power to

your unceasing wisdom and look after yourself by hurrying quickly to that

place where Cinnus lies wet with loud, flowing waters. Why should we

refrain from freeing our mind from worry? Just as birds are eager to play in

the treetops of the forest after they have finished laboring, the mind, after

being constrained for a long period, also loves flying about not entwined in

the arduous restraints of work. My tall house in the country is not built out

of stone, nor the walls out of gold, but it is solid, small, and manageable

where goodness flourishes even more. Virtue has made you courteous, so

you are able to patiently bear the luxuries of the powerful and suffer the

contemptible poverty of the destitute.

172 Scipione Cobelluzzi (1564-1626), Cardinal of Santa Susanna, was an Italian cardinal, librarian, and

archivist. As well as serving as the archivist for the Vatican Secret Archives, he was the parish priest of

Church of Saint Susanna at the Baths of Diocletian from 1616 until his death in 1626. Rossi devotes a

portrait to Cobelluzzi in his Pinacotheca.

425

After I had read the verses a couple of times, I handed them back to the servant who

had showed them to us. He bade us farewell and set off on the journey he had begun.

On his advice, we slowly and gradually began making our way toward Janus Gate.

As we were walking, I eagerly asked Gallonius what kind of person Thersippus

was, whether he was a literary man who corresponded with learned men, or whether he

was a lover of the countryside who sought the delights of his country estate. “By all

means,” said Gallonius, “he is quite a wise man in his own estimation; but in others’

judgment, he is not an idiot. He excels in intelligence, in his knowledge of antiquity, and

in his expertise in civil law. However, his estimation of his skills is much greater than the

level of skill he actually possesses. With his face and his expression, and by admiring

and scoffing, he tries to persuade the goddess of eloquence to cling to his lips and

jurisprudence to reign in his mind as if in a citadel. Nevertheless, he behaves in a

friendly and kind way toward those learned in the law, who seek him out on account of

his position. But his goodwill toward them is contained exclusively in words, which he

rarely, if ever, transforms into action. You can hardly find even a couple of people who

have achieved riches or public offices because of his influence. But look, here he is. He

is the one you see being carried inside that sedan chair.” It was the height of summer,

the temperatures were extreme, and, in spite of this, Thersippus was being carried

around enclosed on all sides, such that there was nobody more fortified or protected

against the elements, even the gentle assault of a breeze.173 The two little windows on

173 Rossi mentions this character, in a 1638 letter he wrote in defense of his satire, as an example of

something that he was being accused of criticizing but that, in fact, was perfectly normal (though it was

not, of course): “quisnam unquam notandum eum esse infamia existimavit, qui caloribus summis, vitandi

frigoris causa, gestatoria sella inclusum se per Urbem deferri jussisset?” (“Who would ever think that

someone should be given a bad name for insisting on being carried about the city enclosed in a sedan

chair in order to avoid the cold at the height of summer?” Ep. ad div. 1.VI.V).

either side of the carriage, as well as the one at the front, were covered in glass and

were opened for the sole purpose of letting in light. He had covered his head with many

scarves and had carefully wrapped his body in a cloak. We wondered at the man’s

studied determination in warding off the cold.

After passing through Middle Janus, we arrived in the place where we were told

the broker would be, and we found him sitting between two men who were laughing

uncontrollably. Gallonius got there first and greeted him. He showed the broker the

gemstones and asked him to find a buyer for them. The broker picked them up,

examined them, praised them, and said: “I have never seen anyone arrive at a more

opportune time. Today I have to fit out a woman’s toilet for Pamphilus to send to the

bride he married.” Gallonius replied: “I heard about that and was amazed that such a

rich and noble young man had stooped to such humbleness as to be willing to marry a

carpenter’s daughter. Does he have such a shortage of marriage prospects?” “Yes, that

is correct,” said Zancha. “It could not have turned out any other way. He was compelled

by force.” Gallonius asked: “What force compels you to have what you don’t want?”

Zancha replied: “The story is absurd, and I had just begun telling it to these men.” “Start

from the beginning, if you don’t mind,” said Gallonius. “I am dying to hear it.” “Then

listen up,” he said.

A young man suddenly burst in, cutting Zancha off as he was attempting to

speak, and came at Natalicius with these words: “Please, what kind of a woman did you

give me to marry? There is no woman more shameful and depraved than she. I just

caught her kissing some young man! If I ever see anything like that again, I’ll divorce

her, throw her out, and send her packing back to you, her father!” Natalicius was greatly

427

disturbed by this and said: “Does it strike you as so surprising for a young woman to be

so out of control? In fact, you would not find many young women who have not been

drawn to such delights and pleasures by the heat of adolescence. These things are part

and parcel of the experience of adolescence, but this heat dies down and comes to an

end at the same time adolescence itself does. In the meantime, let her devote some

time to youth’s flirtations. But, from what I hear, she is imitating her mother. Her mother

(who is my wife) used to flirt in such a way that her advances could have been

distributed among each and every man throughout the whole population. However, now

that she is older, she is so removed from these trifles that there exists no more virtuous

or better lady of the house.” The young man, not at all placated by this response,

muttered something under his breath and left. As he was leaving, Zancha began to

speak.

“In this city, next to the forum of Apollo, lives a certain carpenter named

Baldoccius, who, in his piety and simplicity, undoubtedly subscribes to those old

traditions of ancient men rather than to the customs that are currently in vogue. And

there is no fault to be found or uncovered in him, other than a fondness for wine. It has

such a hold on him that not an hour of the day goes by when, as he himself says, he is

not pouring at least half a liter of wine into his belly. For the rest, there is nothing

insincere or fake about him. On the contrary, everything is exposed and out in the open,

which is why he is considered an easy target for wrongdoing. Indeed, he is prone to

entrusting his counsel to everyone, keeping his word, returning a deposit without

witnesses, and he is often deceived and cheated by con men. This man took as his wife

Antina, a woman from his hometown, who is attached to him by a similarity of character

428

as much as by their association in life. She was no sharper than her husband and no

more skilled in looking out for herself. She hired out her services for reconciling kinfolk,

evaluating women’s ornaments, and adorning and accompanying new brides. As a

result, she happened to always be away from the house.

“She gave birth to a daughter by Baldoccius, named Tensa, who was more

beautiful than all of the Graces,174 but was easily on par with any con man in terms of

her dishonesty and wickedness. She was unbelievably crafty, bold, daring, deceitful,

and prating; she had a mouth on her, a tongue, duplicity, and wickedness. She was

quick to lie, dissemble, and deny everything, and through her fast-talking she convinced

people that they had not seen what they saw and had not done what they did. As I

described before, within the last few months both of her parents went out (which was

not a good idea) and left her, a maiden in full flower, at home alone. Her father thought

that she would be safe enough from anyone who wished to prey on her body if he threw

a bar, the diameter of one finger, across the entrance to their shop. But the facts

themselves showed that such a great and so secure a fortress was hardly safe against

the ambush of an enemy. Indeed, that most handsome Pamphilus, the young man you

just met, was able to penetrate it. During the following Saturnalia,175 when Baldoccius

had gone out earlier than usual to sample a friend’s wine, the enemy entered a

fortification that was cleared of all defenders, and, after engaging in battle, took

possession of his booty. What else is there to say? While Baldoccius spent a joyous day

174 In Greek mythology the three Graces, usually considered to be the daughters of Zeus and Eurynome

(and sometimes of Dionysus and Aphrodite), were Aglaea (splendor), Euphrosyne (mirth), and Thalia

(good cheer).

175 A festival in honor of Saturn that began on the 17th of December and lasted for several days.

drinking from broad and deep wine bowls, the lovers also satisfied themselves with

pleasures to the point of intoxication. And they did not only yield to their inclinations that

day but on every day after that, during the times when Baldoccius, after barricading the

door, as I said, was devoting himself to Liber in some tavern or other, such that there

was no more secure an approach inside that fortress than if it had been defended by a

rampart.

“On the first day of May, however, while the lovers were freely indulging their

appetites after Baldoccius and Antina had left the house, they were very nearly caught

red-handed in their shameful act. When evening was drawing near, and they had not

yet satisfied their desire for sport, Tensa’s parents came home unexpectedly. Because

of this a great fear took hold of the young man. The girl, not afraid of anything, said

‘Don’t be scared. I will give you a ready plan for escape. I’m only sorry that we will be

separated sooner than I’d like.’ Heading straight up from the ground floor, she arrived at

a terrace that was connected to a bedroom on the right side, and on the left side exited

to the kitchen where at that moment a large sack of wheat was being stored. She sliced

the sack open with a knife, opened the large window to let the wheat pour out, and

raising a shout she cried: ‘Help! Mice have been gnawing on our sack of wheat and all

the grain is pouring out!’ While her parents were running over and rushing to collect, in

little baskets, the wheat that was going to waste, the young man gathered his things and

left. Tensa, not interested in any pleasure that was associated with danger and dread,

began thinking to herself how she could engage in pleasure that was pure and

untarnished by fear.

430

“Tensa reached into her bag of tricks and began planning a ruse that would leave

her parents’ naiveté at a disadvantage. She was clever at devising and contriving, so

when her parents returned home at dusk—after Pamphilus had visited her and she had

satisfactorily fulfilled her desires—Tensa appeared before them dejected and run down.

When they asked her what was wrong, she did not dare speak and, instead of words,

she poured forth a large quantity of tears. When she finally felt compelled to speak, she

told them that there were certain ghosts who frequented the homes of virgins, in human

form and shape, and fell hopelessly in love with them. She told her parents that she had

seen one of these ghosts, and that he was so beautiful and so lovely that no being

could possibly surpass him. To which her mother replied: ‘What is this I hear? Watch

out that you have not let fear convince your eyes of this.’ Tensa replied: ‘You are wrong,

mother. I have never felt such joy as when I laid eyes on him.’ Antina said: ‘Cheer up

and cast off this grief that is tormenting you. I hope you never see that ghost again.’ ‘Ah,

but you don’t understand, mother, how firmly he sticks in my mind.’ When she had

finished speaking, she focused on getting food and rest, which was something she was

very much in need of. The next day, Pamphilus returned as a strange spirit, the sort that

people call “incubi.”176 In order to win over the woman’s parents, he left behind a pair of

earrings and a necklace for Tensa that were freshly made, which she showed to her

parents with a happy heart. They picked the items up, examined them, praised them,

and admired them as if they had come from the workshop of Vulcan himself. Even

though they hadn’t seen him yet, they already felt compelled to like such a

176 Incubus: from the verb incubo (“to lie upon”) denotes both the sender of the dream and the dream

itself. As the sender of a dream, the incubus is a demon in male form. Christian authors often stressed

discriminating and generous ghost. By continuing to give these gifts, Pamphilus

succeeded in making himself dearer than anything to Tensa’s parents.

“Antina, as women do, burned with an unbelievable desire to see the ghost, but

she was also terrified. Because Pamphilus had brought so many gifts, however, and

because of her daughter’s persuasive words when describing his form and beauty, she

decided to get a look at him with her own eyes. Pamphilus, as you saw for yourself, is

nineteen years old, has wavy hair, dark eyes, fair cheeks that were slightly blushing,

and no trace of a beard. Moreover, he always looked refined with regards to the way he

dressed and adorned himself, just as his riches (which were fairly ample) would allow.

For this reason, as soon as Antina caught sight of him she exclaimed: ‘Gosh, how

elegant he is! Who says that ghosts are monstrous? By god, if all of them had a face

like his, I wouldn’t mind if all the ghosts that ever existed moved into my house. That

way, I wouldn’t have to always look at Baldoccius’s ghastly mug.’

“But Baldoccius had already told the neighbors the whole story about the ghost’s

love and gifts, and his stupidity provided them glorious entertainment and fodder for

gossip. When asked whether the spirit had horns, he replied: ‘Damnit, why does it cross

your mind to think such a thing about this ghost? I cannot easily say I have ever seen a

more beautiful creature.’ ‘That’s absurd,’ responded another. ‘If he does not have horns,

it is surely because he has given them to you.’177 Baldoccius replied: ‘May the great

Jupiter damn you for thinking that ghosts made of air and wind have sexual relations

like humans do.’ The other man replied: ‘What if this virile wind has inflated your

177 The play on words here involves the Latin word for horns (cornua) and the expression “giving horns” to

someone (i.e., making someone a cuckold).

432

daughter’s womb? What would you say to that?’ Other neighbors, pitying Baldoccius’s

stupidity, advised him, on account of their friendship and affinity, to avoid a great

scandal and to drive that trickster as far as possible out of his house with a stick. He

responded that it was jealousy making them say these things, and that it was entirely

his own business if there was one ghost living in his house or a thousand of them. One

of the neighbors said: ‘Are you really inviting this level of damage to your reputation for

such meager financial gain? Watch out that this evil ghost doesn’t hurt your daughter

when it comes time to give her away in marriage. Don’t you know how valuable a girl’s

reputation is when brokering a good match?’ To which Baldoccius replied: ‘Be quiet, you

idiot. Don’t you see how people are nowadays?’

In this place a girl can get married with this type of reputation. So long as

she has a dowry, no one can find fault with her.178

“What more can I say? Baldoccius was sooner persuaded that there were flying

donkeys than that ghosts, consisting of air and wind, would bring any shame upon

himself and his daughter. But events thwarted his beliefs because that very air, forged

into thick and fleshy humors, caused Tensa’s belly to swell beyond measure. At first

Tensa convinced her parents that she was suffering from a skin condition, namely fluid

in her tissues, not from an illness of her insides. Later, when her due date was

approaching, she confided in her mother the true cause of her sickness, but she did not

blame it on her ghost companion, or any other man, but on a certain dream she had.

She reported dreaming, seven months ago, that she had sex with a certain young man,

and that from that day on her belly started swelling and, little by little, it grew to its

178 English translation from Plautus and de Melo (2011-13).

433

current size. Antina, although she was stupid (and a mother), did not immediately

believe this story, but whenever she encountered a doctor or a friend she would

immediately ask whether her daughter could have become pregnant without having

sexual intercourse. Different people gave her different answers. There was someone

who asked whether what the daughter experienced while awake should be attributed to

a dream. To which Antina responded: ‘Don’t think such a thing about my daughter. She

is even more pure and inviolable than any dove.’ ‘As if doves don’t have offspring!’ the

man replied.

“To make a long story short, Antina remained in a state of suspense and

uncertainty, until she finally saw that cock entering her dove. When she was keeping

watch through a crack in the door to see what was happening inside, she saw what she

(had she not been so foolish) should have already comprehended, and she finally

noticed what sort of Underworld that Erinys179 sprang from. Mad with grief, she began to

shout; to appeal to the goodwill of her fellow citizens; and to tell them she had caught

the filthy trickster, that blight upon her family and corruptor of their daughter. At this

point all of the neighbors ran to help her, and they scolded the young man for

shamelessly tricking honest people and for violating a tender maiden. They also

threatened that they would carry him off to jail, or before a judge, who, by, imposing a

punishment, would wash that indelible mark of shame off of those most upstanding

people. You can understand how that young man’s mind was tossed this way and that

for a few moments. But his love for Tensa and their relationship moved Pamphilus more

than the threats of those men did; and separation, discord, and destruction were

179 In Greek mythology the Erinyes, also known as the Furies, were the deities of vengeance.

434

imminent unless he paid attention to this love. For this reason the young man, who was

rich and held the highest rank among his own people, was deeply moved and deigned

to request this carpenter’s daughter’s hand in marriage. Baldoccius immediately

promised Tensa to him. But it seems the day has arrived that the young man is

regretting this marriage.”

Gallonius replied: “But it will not be difficult for him to abandon this marriage

whenever he wants to, and to join with another woman who is more suitable for him in

terms of social rank, wealth, and reputation.” Wondering at this I said: “I had heard that

marriages in Eudemia were everlasting and put asunder only by death. By what avenue

will he pursue this unholy action?” “By the avenue that lies open and is already well

trodden by the footsteps of many. The same one that Antiphila recently embarked on if

she can clearly prove, with witnesses, that her marriage was joined not solemnly and

legally but by force and fear. After all, a judge restores possession of that from which

one has been forcibly driven.” “What is this I hear?” said Natalitius, “Antiphila is a

divorcee with her husband still alive? That same Antiphila who married Demophon the

spice merchant?” “The very one,” said Gallonius. As a matter of fact, since she was

beaten by her husband after being caught (not infrequently) in the act of adultery, she

fabricated a story—four years after her husband had taken her hand—that her marriage

had been coerced by fear; and she therefore saw to it that it was dissolved and put

asunder. This was immediately executed by the work of some scribe, the recklessness

of which profession in perpetrating these and other abominable activities greatly

benefits the most immoral men.” Tensa’s expert tricks and her plans, so cleverly

devised in her heart to deceive, moved us with such delight that I exclaimed: “Zancha,

435

your amusing and enjoyable story is worth more than the gemstones that you are

tasked to sell for us.” Zancha replied: “If that is how it seems to you, hand over the

gemstones. What is more, you can declare them to be of diminished value. But I believe

you are making fun of me, and I don’t think you have come here to buy witty sayings at

such a great price. So follow me.” He grabbed our hands, led us into the forum, and

ordered the banker to count out three large silver talents for us. We headed home

happy because our merchandise had brought such a successful return and we were

flush with cash.

On our way back home, we happened upon a crowd of people. Dynast Orius,

who was also the priest of Ceres,180 was on his way to perform religious rites to the

goddess at her temple in a solemn ritual. His entire household was walking ahead of

him, and among them many other distinguished men were following him out of respect.

Next came his attendants, one of whom was carrying a ewer, another a bowl, and

another a box filled with frankincense. Flamen Orius was following them dressed in a

woolen cloak, and wherever he went noblemen and common people made way for him,

doffed their hats, and knelt before him. Among those making way for him, we

recognized some who had won great praise for their talents in that gathering of scholars

we had attended three days before. Flamen Orius, however, standing erect and tall, did

not give his attention to any one person but looked down his nose at everyone equally.

Among the commoners, who had rushed to see Flamen Orius, there was one man

dressed in a leather tunic with a belt around his waist from which many tools were

hanging such as a hammer, pincers, a hoof knife, and a sack full of nails. Flamen Orius

180 The ancient goddess of grain.

436

called this man over to him, dressed as he was, invited the man to walk alongside him,

and asked him how he was doing, whether he was in good health, whether the pain had

diminished on his horse’s hooves, which he had brought to him to be treated, and

whether there was any hope that his horse would recover.

Greatly astonished at this, I said: “Gallonius, why did this great man, who holds

such an important priesthood, show disregard and scorn to many honorable men (at the

very moment that he, adorned with pontifical emblems, was about to devote himself to

the most solemn matter of all) and instead choose this raggedy man to walk in the

procession with and strike up a conversation? What two people are more different than

a pontiff and a blacksmith? What things are more contrary and different than a pontifical

cloak and the tools of a farrier? I honestly don’t see how it’s possible to be amazed

enough at the flamen’s reasoning.” “It is foolish and stupid, by god,” said Gallonius. “But

what can you do? As you can guess from how he is dressed, this man shoes horses.

People conduct their lives in Eudemia in such a way that the leading men care more

about their pet horses, monkeys, or any other worthless animal than about any of the

literary and honest men. If one of these honest men finds himself lying sick in bed,

nobody ever comes to visit him or sends any word that his health is of any concern to

him.181 But if someone’s horse has a sore hoof, there are immediate cries and

complaints, people summon whoever is able to shoe the horse, they pray for its health,

they visit it, and they spare no effort, expense, or labor. This is because upstanding and

learned men are held in no regard and have no status, while beasts are highly

181 This complaint is reminiscent of Rossi’s own complaint against his erstwhile employer Alessandro

cherished. I can add to this that all of the positions in this republic, which should be

offered to a person on account of his hard work, are filled instead on the basis of

friendship and favors. For example, if someone needs to find someone to write his

letters or legal opinions, that person does not immediately go out and hire the most

eloquent or learned person. No, he hires the person recommended by his friends, or

who is useful or advantageous to him in some way. The result is that the letters or legal

opinions of these people, which they spend no effort on, are ridiculed by those who do

have skills in these areas.” Irritated, I then said: “Let’s go home and restore ourselves

with breakfast. I am embarrassed to stay any longer in this city. It’s worse than the one

we escaped from.” We arrived home, found our breakfast table prepared, and sat down.

A little while later, a messenger arrived from the ship’s captain, who strongly urged us to

get going (if we still intended to go), saying that the wind was favorable and that we

were holding everyone up. Therefore, we got up from the table, took off the clothes we

had gotten from Gallonius, changed into our own clothes, and hurried off with the

messenger toward the port. We boarded the ship and left Gallonius behind after

embracing him once and again, and after giving him a gift of a necklace and a ring set

with one of our gemstones.

Gallonius had barely taken his leave, when a certain painter arrived, whom they

called Ballio,182 who fervently begged us to have the ship take him on board as well,

along with a woman who he claimed was his wife. The captain, who knew this man and

enjoyed his artistic talent, did not rebuff him, even though the ship was full, and he

asked: “What’s this I hear about your wife? Isn’t this woman Nice the common whore?

182 Ballio is the name of a pimp in Plaut. Pseud. See also Eud. 1998, Lib. VI n. 4.

438

When did she become your wife?” “I will tell you,” said Ballio. “I was having relations

with this woman, along with many others. But ten days ago, when I had paid for a night

with her, I don’t know which god influenced me to whisk her away from the business of

prostitution and marry her. That same night, I took her back to my house, together with

all her things, and, at the same time, I listed her house for rent. The next morning her

lovers arrived. Callidius the grain merchant was the first to come and see that her house

was vacant and for rent. He made inquiries, asking those people who had been

witnesses to my shackling (for, truly, a wife is nothing other than a veritable ball and

chain), and he found out that I had married her. ‘My god,’ he said, ‘if that is the case, the

ten pecks of wheat I gave her, so her door would be open to me for a whole year, have

gone over to her husband’s granary.’ Creopolis lanius arrived next complaining that he

had been tricked out of two huge racks of meat. Thermopota the innkeeper arrived

grumbling that his wine, which would have been enough to last the woman a whole

year, had been stolen from him through Ballio’s plan. The bankrupt Harpax rushed over

and was indignant that he had been taken for fifteen minae of the money he had shaved

off his creditors. Other merchants showed up too. She had given her attention to each

of them (once she had accepted their goods), and each of them reproached the woman,

in her absence, as a manifest thief. A few days later, they all went to court before the

praetor, they attacked her in unison, and each one of them brought a suit against her.

Since she could not fend off so many men, and didn’t think she should have to worry

about coughing up what she had already swallowed, she decided to treat them like

enemy cities, that is to say, she left them pillaged and in ruins, and she went off with me

439

over to the kingdom of Geryon.”183 “Well played,” said the ship’s captain, “and you

should not have done otherwise. By god, those men can go hire professional mourners

to sing a dirge to the money they want returned.”

On board the same ship was a moneylender who held the highest rank among

his own people, and who was so uncivil and rude that he seemed to have been born of

incivility and annoyance itself. As if he himself had been among the lovers whom Nice

had robbed and deceived, he immediately started speaking harsh words, in the bitterest

of terms, against Nice and against the whole class of whores. “Why is it surprising,” he

said, “if a woman—whose life is all about cheating other people and expelling them from

their ancestral estates with flattery and enticements—acts treacherously, maliciously,

wickedly, and greedily. A whore is like a giant abyss and a whirlpool of vices. A whore is

a crop failure that robs a farm of its yield. She is a rock against which fortunes,

reputation, and prosperity are dashed and shattered, especially those of young men.

She is an abyss that seizes, exhausts, and devours farms and estates. She is a most

dangerous sea that is never satiated with gifts or has her fill. On the contrary, the sea is

hardly a whore’s equal in terms of greed. Things that flow into the sea stealthily retreat

and flow back again, whereas whatever finds its way into a whore’s house disappears

immediately, never to be seen again. Want to see for yourself? Throw this woman into

the sea. As soon as she comes in contact with it, the sea will be wiped clean of its

water, as if from its riches, and she will enrich herself with it; once she has depleted the

sea, she will escape from it; and—still not satisfied—she will be greedy for more.”

183 The kingdom of Spain. In Greek mythology Geryon was a three-headed giant who lived on the island

of Erytheia in the far west of the Mediterranean. He was the son of Chrysaor and Callirrhoe and grandson

of Medusa.

440

Ballio did not stand for this man’s arrogance and contempt. “What does this

woman owe you?” he asked. “What goes through your mind that you can’t address her

properly? Whoever accuses another of a shameful act needs to look at himself in the

mirror. For example, not only are these things you describe applicable to a

moneylender, but much more egregious things as well! If a whore is eager, you are

greedy; if she is impudent, you are perfidious; if she is disgraceful, you are detestable; if

she is a whirlpool, you are an abyss; if she is the sea, you are Orcus drawing everything

into itself and never giving it back. You say that whatever is given to whores disappears,

but your all-devouring money—money that you lend at crushing interest rates and that

devours whatever it touches—does this more thoroughly. For when age, illness, or

anything of this sort starts limiting a wretched whore’s earnings, the gold and silver that

her lovers had heaped on her flies to you instead, and with added interest. But when

someone doesn’t have sufficient means to pay back your crushing interest, what is paid

out as interest and principal is taken away and sunk in your deepest pit, never to

emerge again. Thus, if a whore is the sea, you are a whirlpool that swallows up the sea

itself; if she is the ruin of young men, you are a furiously raging pestilence, equally

dangerous to both.” The haughty and hot-tempered man did not stand for these fiery

words that Ballio was brandishing at him, and he flared up violently showering arrogant

and harsh insults on him. Ballio, who has never been afraid of anyone, along with his

wife tried to fly at the old man’s face, but we didn’t let them. Indeed, there was no more

difficult a task than keeping their hands off that most insolent moneylender.

Once their quarrel had subsided, however, lightheartedness and joking ensued.

The ship’s captain asked the painter if it would not be too much trouble to tell the story

441

of a certain foreign woman. The painter immediately said: “When I arrived at Aspis,184

having been hired by a gentleman of that town to cover the walls of some public

walkway with my paintings, Lyus that most famous Cynic philosopher—who holds

humanistic pursuits in the greatest contempt and is the most zealous persecutor of

vices—arrived at the same place. He proceeded to hold frequent assemblies before the

people and to speak frankly about their wickedness and evil ways. When a certain

nobleman of the town realized he was being especially singled out for reproach, he

arranged for the man to be placed on a litter and expelled from the territory which he

governed. The man departed that region in such a way, however, that he left behind a

feeling of high esteem among the people for his virtue and integrity.

“The following day, a foreign maiden entered the town dressed as a Vestal

Virgin. She was not the type of young woman who lives her life apart from the crowd,

pent up within the enclosure of common walls, but was the type who goes around freely

wherever she likes, so she can demonstrate, without a doubt, that her chastity and her

other praiseworthy habits can be maintained even during interactions with men. The

maiden had an image of Minerva hanging around her neck that was like an amulet

made of bronze. Because of this, she inspired high esteem in everyone for her chastity,

which she increased even more by pretending to be the sister of that philosopher Lyus

and telling everyone she had been on the worlds’ most famous pilgrimages. Indeed, she

said she had journeyed as far as the Temple of Ceres in Enna, the Temple of Apollo at

Delphi, the Temple of Artemis at Ephesus, the Temple of Jupiter at Amun, the Temple

of Zeus at Dodona, and, finally, that there was no place where the worship of any

184 The Latin is Aspim, which is an anagram of the accusative form of Pisa.

442

immortal god was practiced that she had not visited, surveyed, or venerated in person.

Therefore, because of the great esteem and reputation the philosopher Lyus enjoyed

among the people, and because of the pilgrimages the maiden had undertaken (which

we have no other acquaintance of except what we have gleaned from monuments of

Latin literature), it came about that she was greatly in demand. The noblewomen of the

town competed for which one of them would be the first to receive her as a guest, have

her over for dinner, invite her to sleep in her room—and even in her own bed—and they

reckoned that some element of the maiden’s purity would rub off on them through

contact with her body. What more can I say? It was considered the greatest

accomplishment to spend the night with the maiden at least once, such that even those

who did not succeed in doing so falsely boasted that they had. And (what will amaze

you even more) she stayed several nights among the cloistered Vestals, with the most

fervent blessing of their High Priestess. Finally, not wanting to ignore other cities, the

maiden began to prepare for her departure, because she thought it only right that, for

those women’s sake, they also got to share in her most chaste body. This caused a

wellspring of wailing and weeping among the women of Aspis, who complained that

their comfort was being taken away from them much sooner than seemed right. As a

matter of fact, they proclaimed that they had not gotten their fill of her most delightful

company.

“But their complaints fell on deaf ears, and the maiden made her way to the next

town over, called Basilicum, where a certain distinguished widow ordered the guards of

the city gates, if they saw a maiden set foot in the town dressed in foreign attire, to bring

her immediately to the widow’s house. This widow, easily the first among her fellow

443

citizens in terms of rank, wealth, and reputation, had various couches placed around her

house for offering hospitality to foreign women, and she arranged for their feet to be

washed, dinner to be served, and beds to be made up for them. The guards

immediately recognized this extraordinary prodigy of virtue and brought her to the

widow’s house. When the maiden recounted the kinship that bound her so closely with

Lyus and the most celebrated pilgrimages she had undertaken, she was led over into

the sight and company of that most pious widow. The widow was so delighted by the

maiden’s chastity and most saintly words that she locked her young servant girl (who

usually slept in a little cot at her feet) out that night, brought the foreign maiden into her

room, and settled her in the servant girl’s cot. Around midnight, when the foreign

maiden recognized, by the way the widow was clearing her throat (even though she

could not see her), that sleep was far from the widow’s eyes, she began pretending, by

making noises with her chattering teeth, that her whole body was shivering. When the

widow asked what was wrong, she responded that she had been seized by an

unexpected deadly fever and, because of that, a sudden chill had taken hold of her

entire body. The widow, taken with pity, ordered her to come into her bed and to bring

her blanket and other bedclothes with her. The maiden did not have to be asked twice;

she immediately obeyed and climbed into the widow’s bed.

“Before too long, sleep overcame the widow. Then an incredible thing happened.

That most virtuous maiden suddenly transformed from a chaste virgin into a lecherous

man, and, like a stud horse, tried to enter the sleeping widow. The widow was

awakened by his attempts and said: ‘What’s all this?’ To which the stranger replied: ‘Put

aside your fear immediately. As you can see, I am a man, and I go around cities

444

dressed like this in order to fulfill the inclinations of women, who are inflamed with desire

but kept on the straight and narrow by their anxiety about their neighbors and their

reputation.’ And what do you think that most excellent woman did, now that she was

caught between a rock and a hard place? What did she resolve to do? Did she perhaps

lose courage or do what might occur to some foolish women, that is, raise a shout or

ask for the protection of her fellow citizens, so that her neighbors would come running?

None of the above. Instead she laughed and said: ‘Good for you. May the gods bestow

many blessings on you in exchange for this compassion toward our fair sex. I hope you

do not mind waiting here for a bit while I go wash up. It has been a while since I have

had a bath, and even back in the old days I was not accustomed to give my attentions

to a man unless I had bathed. At the same time, I will send my servant girl as far away

from here as possible, so she doesn’t notice anything or tell on us. Then I will return to

you, so I can seize this most delightful opportunity that has fallen into my lap.’ She

jumped down from the bed, conferred with her maidservant, ordered her to go wake up

a member of her household who, dressed only in his underwear and slippers (so as not

lose any time putting on the rest of his clothes), ran to the judge and begged him, upon

his word, to send a cohort of lictors to his house, insisting that the matter was

scandalous, disgraceful, and merited his coming straightaway. The judge did not delay,

and he ordered the lictors to go to the widow’s house. They arrived and seized the

trickster and dragged him off to jail. To make a long story short, once the inquiry was

concluded, he was handed over, dressed in rags, to his punishment—that is to say, his

life was ended by hanging.

445

“When the news of this event reached us, in order to confirm it, I made my way

secretly to Basilicum. While returning from there to Aspis, whenever I saw any of those

men, whose wives were boasting that they had been worthy of receiving that pillar of

virtue and honor into their bed, of kissing her and caressing her, I would immediately

say: ‘Aren’t you lucky that so much good fortune entered your house?’ The man would

deny that it happened, and I would insist; but he would refuse to acknowledge it,

because he didn’t want to make me jealous. Keeping up the same pretense, I insisted

that I regretted nothing more than that I had not drawn her beautiful image on many

canvasses and sold them. For, I said, on account of the number of buyers, and on

account of your loyalty toward that most beautiful maiden, I would have enough work for

the entire year; and, because of that, I would have earned a huge amount of money in a

short period of time. In sum, nobody could be found who was willing to admit that the

trickster had set foot in his house.” That delightful story of the trickster was received as

attentively as it was cheerfully, because he had discovered how to possess women

(who are everywhere)—and everyone would have envied that man for his success, if it

could only have lasted longer.

Book Seven

The strong wind we had very much been hoping for was already carrying us off

to sea, and we were so enjoying the placid and tranquil water that, as Pacuvius once

said regarding the Greek army, we were happily observing the fish at play.185 Then,

suddenly, the weather turned foul and we were driven back to the same place we had

departed from. I believe that Neptune had churned up those waves because he could

185 Two lines of Pacuvius quoted in Cic. Div. I.XIV.24 (see Chapter 2, n. 429).

446

not tolerate the contempt and arrogance of a certain old man named Ligurinus186 who

was traveling with us. Peevish and fastidious beyond belief, every little thing bothered

this man: flying birds, the whistling wind, and the sound of oarsmen straining to catch

their breath. He even threatened to have the oarsmen crucified if they breathed in such

a way that any sound they made reached his ears. Ligurinus, together with his servant,

chased a fly throughout the entire ship because it had buzzed in his ear while he was

sleeping. I do not want to go on and on, so I am leaving out many other things that

caused us to feel such hatred for him that it just about did us in. Once we had been sent

back to shore, as I said, we got the ship’s captain to agree to let us go see Gallonius—

which he was reluctant to do, since he said he wanted to set sail as soon as the

contrary wind subsided and not wait until the following day. Because of this, he wanted

us to return quickly.

We arrived at Gallonius’s villa without delay via a narrow street that led straight

there. As soon as Gallonius saw us, he reckoned that there was some more serious

reason for our coming back and, after sending Plusius Accipiter away (whom we

mentioned above), he insisted on knowing the cause of our return. We told him about

the weather taking a turn for the worse as well as about Ligurinus’s annoying disregard

for others. I said to him: “If we have to sail with that man again, we won’t need an

executioner to finish us off. Ligurinus will just about deprive us of our lives by his

hatefulness before we are even able to see the port.” “Do not be astonished,” said

Gallonius. “He is equally offensive to everyone he lives with, both on land and on sea.

186 IJsewijn (Eud. 1998 Lib. VII, n. 2) suggests that this pseudonym was inspired by the Ligurinus

referenced in Hor. Carm. IV.10.5. Because Rossi’s Ligurinus is a peevish old man, it is fitting that the

poem from which his name derives is about the transience of youth and beauty.

447

Just so you know, the neighborhood where he recently lived has been praying for his

departure, or better yet, for his demise. He had all of the roosters around his house

captured and killed because they sometimes deafened him while he was trying to get

things done during the day. Moreover, he wounded a remarkable dog with a stone from

a catapult, whom everyone adored on account of its good nature, and who kept thieves

away by barking. He justified himself by saying that the dog had kept him awake while

he was trying to sleep.187 But the truth is that he is hateful, cruel, harsh, and a monster.

Did he not chase after a little owl, for many nights in a row, that was hooting at the

window of the room where he slept, because he said it was an omen-bringing bird that

was constantly foretelling an unhappy fate for him? So, after much effort, he caught the

owl in a trap and killed it, and he had its head mounted on a spear in his villa as a

trophy. But there is nothing to this man, as you know, besides his physical height, the

splendor of his lineage, and his supreme arrogance. He was even wealthy once upon a

time, but he was recently cleaned out of his possessions at sea and is now a worthless

man, or rather, a no-account brute. Let him go, let him sail away. I pray to the gods that

his voyage lasts forever!”

He continued: “I believe I have reconciled Plusius Accipiter with Offuscatus.”188

“What?” I said. “Was there hostility between them?” “A great deal,” he responded. “They

were mortal enemies. There are many twisting catacombs on the outskirts of Rome that

are like the mazy windings and curves of a labyrinth.189 The forefathers of these men,

very observant people, used to meet secretly in these subterranean tunnels to perform

sacred rites to Ceres and Liber because it was not permitted to do so openly. Even now

quite a few traces of their religious practices can be seen in these places. As you know,

Offuscatus is a scholar of these antiquities. He often puts his other responsibilities aside

and retreats underground where he spends entire days and nights joyfully examining

these most religious sites. Plusius, who has squandered his estate on drink, food, and

whores—and who wishes to find some way, if he can, by which he can be restored to

his previous lifestyle—has convinced himself that Offuscatus visits these sunken

underground places because of some great advantage, that is, that he is engaged in

digging up treasures and employing the magical arts in this quest. Thus, Plusius

reckoned that he could accumulate enormous wealth if Offuscatus took him on as a

partner. And he didn’t fail in this endeavor. One day he tracked Offuscatus down,

grabbed his hand, and took him aside saying: ‘Please tell me what business you have

underground. Why do you spend your life in the catacombs?’ Offuscatus replied: ‘Why

do you think? I enjoy becoming thoroughly acquainted with the religious rites of our

ancestors.’ Plusius replied: ‘Oh be quiet! It is as if we were meeting each other for the

first time. I have never known you to practice religious observance. No, you are getting

rich by treasure hunting.’ Offuscatus replied: ‘What is going through your mind that you

believe our ancestors, who embraced uprightness instead of opulence and duty instead

of Cat. 64.115 in Catullus and Cornish 1914.

449

of riches, had any treasure?’ ‘It’s no use,’ said Plusius. ‘I am not such a stranger to—or

to offer libations to the gods with golden goblets and use candles in silver candelabras

for their nocturnal orgies. Therefore, in the name of our friendship, take me on as a

partner. I am eager to claim for myself some part of this most attractive enterprise.’

“Offuscatus, familiar with Plusius’s capriciousness, believed that this delightful

pastime offered him every satisfaction and leisure, and he was determined not to give it

up for any reason. First, he began asking and imploring Plusius not to report him, since

the practice of magical arts was a capital offense. He said: ‘If you love me, if my well-

being is important to you, do not know what you know and do not see what you are

seeing. What you are asking for, to take you on as my partner, that role in this

enterprise is not mine. That belongs to our friend Stylius,190 who lives about one

hundred miles away. However, because of your station I will make sure he travels that

distance in less than three hours and meets us at the Temple of Janus Quadrifrons.191

By god, I am pleased that you have given me this opportunity. I want to pay him back

for dragging me, with his magic spells, from my hometown to this city in five hours.’ ‘Oh!’

exclaimed Plusius, ‘If you could make that happen, you are surely a great man.’ ‘I’m

begging you,’ replied Offuscatus, ‘keep your voice down! Do not shout. Go home and

make sure that you are waiting for me at the Temple of Janus Quadrifrons when I need

you. I will be there with a flattened nail’192 He had seen a very old copper nail in Aridus’s

dressed in leggings, as if he had just entered the city at that very moment. He would

“Plusius arrived at Offuscatus’s house earlier than had been asked of him, and

he urged and insisted that they get going, saying that nothing seemed to him more

tedious than waiting to dig up a room full of gold from some old tomb. They set off, and

they arrived. Offuscatus fixed the flattened nail in the ground inside the Temple of Janus

Quadrifrons, to the left of the right-hand corner, using certain solemn words that he had

just made up. Next, he hung a small piece of paper tied with yarn around Plusius’s

Offuscatus what the letters meant, and he said: ‘Plusius Perdidit Cerebrum Cum Re’

(‘Plusius has lost his mind together with his possessions’). He instructed Plusius that, if

he ever wanted to return home from the spirit world safely and with his head still

attached, he should never take the piece of paper off, but should let it hang around his

neck forever like an amulet. Then they started walking, and after they had traveled a

long distance Stylius appeared. Plusius saw him first and cheerfully called out to him:

extensively, Plusius and Offuscatus went to join Stylius. When Plusius saw in the street

die myself!’ To make a long story short, Plusius had so convinced himself that these

things were true, that he would not have traded the wealth of Croesus with the treasures

that the Manes had shown him.

“But Plusius was a gossip, and he could not stop himself from disclosing the

whole matter to a certain friend of his who knew Stylius very well (this man had, in fact,

seen Stylius the day before Plusius came to tell him everything he had seen). This

friend immediately realized that Plusius had been tricked, and he began to chide him

harshly that a man his age, endowed with his sharp intellect, had allowed himself to be

made a fool of by two young men. He said that, if Plusius insisted on believing them, he

would soon have boys chasing after him with rocks. When Plusius heard this, he

452

became so enraged that he almost spit flames out of his mouth. He grabbed a dagger,

threatened Offuscatus in absentia, and even claimed that he was going to kill him in the

middle of the forum. Because I had been appointed as a go-between, I went to placate

him, and I had barely begun speaking to him about his conditions for a peace accord

when he cut me off saying: ‘Silence! I should go back to being on good terms with that

man? May the gods destroy me if he is ever my friend again! Besides, he has already

broken off our friendship. Let him find someone else to deceive.’ When I saw that this

avenue was closed to me, I began to approach him via a different route saying: ‘Look,

this stubbornness of yours is harming you rather than your enemy. Don’t you know how

much drink, satiety, and happiness you are depriving yourself of? He promised that, if I

could reconcile you with him, he would throw you a sumptuous dinner today in whatever

locale you wish.’ And this plan did not fail. The mention of a restaurant and dinner had

barely been introduced when that man, desirous of dinner on someone else’s dime

(and, most of all, a glutton), did us the courtesy of ceasing his anger and promised to

yield to our wishes.

“But I must hurry over to the bookshop of Thaumantius,193 where the majority of

scholars gather. They say that a famous philosopher will be there, whom you have not

met. He has a remarkable mind, possesses the highest knowledge of human and divine

matters, an outstanding oratorical ability, and a clearly prodigious memory besides. He

acquired the sobriquet Teras194 and now that is what everyone calls him. He oversees

Then his friend, who was going to publish the book, said: “Now that you’ve

mentioned Plusius, if it does not cause offense, I want to tell you how he was recently

telling you about, they enlisted a boy of outstanding beauty, bent him to their will

through sex, and then they thoroughly trained him in every manner of deceit and trickery

for their own enrichment. They told him to walk ahead of them in the streets and in the

town squares, and they stealthily followed close behind him as he walked ahead. As he

had been instructed, the boy greeted any man he came across, who he judged from

appearances not to be averse to sleeping with boys. The boy would then ask this man

to point him toward someone who could take him into his service; and said that he

himself, who held the highest rank among his own people, had been humiliated by his

father’s brutality to the point that he had run away from home; that he was struggling

under the greatest poverty; and that he had already gone a whole day without food.

“Many men become caught up in this net, but there is one in particular, from

The man had to endure his soft cloak, linen clothes, and many gold coins besides,

to promise, if he did not want to be exposed, to toss six drachma coins at the tricksters’

While we were talking, we arrived at Thaumantius’s shop and saw many people

sitting around on chairs. One of them, who was a bit overweight and had a big head,

blonde hair, and a ruddy complexion, was reciting who-knows-what kind of verses to

another man sitting next to him. They said that the man’s name was Fuscus197 and that

he had recently published certain letters of Heroides after Ovid’s example. Two other

men were talking between themselves about a certain young man, named Pusillus

Caesar,198 who had died very recently from consumption, and they were comparing him

with another young man in terms of the magnitude of his intellect, his knowledge of the

greatest subjects, and his refinement in each course of study. That second young man,

learned to the point of being a miracle, rushed through his course of study and died

when he was just a little bit older, in the very flower of his youth. A certain Uranius199

was also sitting among them, who was awarded the highest praise by everyone for his

painting, and he was granted first place, by the consensus of all, especially in drawing.
