And he did not move in those circles of literary men solely by dint of his painting, but

because he was also gifted in letters. It was well known that he was an astronomer, a

mathematician, and a poet, and that he not only surpassed many of his contemporaries

in terms of his keenness of wit and inventiveness, but many men from previous eras as

well. (There were a few people who did try to detract from his praise because of certain

jealousies.) Letters were delivered to Uranius from Aridus, in which he complained of a

wrongdoing by a certain old man named Merlinus, who, without being asked or

compelled, had sent him vinegar on a whim instead of aged wine with a bouquet. They

said that he was a hateful old man, wicked, annoying, stingy, rude, filthy, and that he

returned home to his wife every day with his trousers soaked in urine and feces.

Uranius read these letters out loud over and over, in a clear and distinct voice, which

made it so that even I was able to memorize them. I recorded them in my notebook so

they wouldn’t be lost:

Farewell, nourishing light of artists, to whom sweet Phoebus granted

songs and on whom he bestowed Urania’s shining fame. Listen to how

Merlinus made fun of me, that rotten, evil, decrepit old man. He ran into

me on the Janiculum Hill and recounted the following in a trembling voice:

“In case you are unaware, I have some wine that could surpass the nectar

of the gods and draw Jove down from heaven above.” He asks, insists,

and calls upon me not to refuse his gift and to drink down the clear wine

from his full wine jugs. When that shameless man said those words to me,

harsh thirst happened to be burning my miserable throat. I do not delay

but send an empty bottle along with him, which he generously returns to

me full. Believe me, it was poison, not wine, there is any fouler wine on

earth. Having decided to entrust the wine to my empty veins, and

banishing the insatiable thirst from my dry mouth, a dreadful cold shot

immediately into my very bones, my throat closed up, and I almost died.

Nevertheless, his ghastly household restores itself with Merlin’s drink,

giving it pride of place above sweet ambrosia. You ask why his wife,

457

sister, servant, son, and nephew enjoy such cold vinegar.200 Because, of

course, it serves to fortify their stomachs so they don’t vomit their guts up

as soon as that Merlin, caked in snot and stinking feces, carries his dire

poison to their noses and stomachs.

When he had finished reading, everyone burst out laughing. Then another man

said: “Listen to another absurdity of this comic and silly old man, or rather, a disgraceful

act worthy of punishment. While he was in Dynast Bibulus’s antechamber a few days

ago—along with many other men who were waiting to be admitted in to see Bibulus—he

caught sight of an attractive and well-bred young man. Leaving everyone else behind,

he sought this young man out, approached him, asked how he was, if he was well, and

whether he often consorted with prostitutes. He said that now was the time of life for

that sort of activity, and he advised him to keep in mind that he would not always be as

young as he was then. The young man responded that he was doing well physically but

not so well financially, and because of that he was hardly able to afford a prostitute.

Merlinus said: ‘This is what is keeping you from the greatest pleasure of all? Take heart!

Find an object of your affection; as for the rest, I will assume responsibility for making

sure you have the money. I too was young once, so I know what it’s like to be bursting

with desire and not to have the means to pay for it. Because of this I am a pretty decent

judge when it comes to young men.’ The young man replied: ‘I think I have found

something to my liking, so make sure I have something to offer her. A young whore lives

here next door. She is not unattractive and not unsuitable, and I had my heart set on her

a long time ago. But she says that she will not rent herself out to me because she

knows that I don’t have even one penny to give her. If you like, I will show her to you

“They set off together and arrived at the house of a certain prostitute. They knock

on the door. The prostitute opens. They go in. The young man asks for sex, she

demands payment, and Merlinus acts as guarantor. While the boy is bedding the whore

inside, Merlinus stands guard at the door in the meantime. He takes three drachmas out

of his old purse and gives them to the whore as payment. The woman takes the money

forlornly, since she had much higher hopes for Merlinus’s generosity, seeing as he was

a rich man. However, when the young man came to her every day with three drachmas,

and there was never any increase in payment, she could no longer hide her pain. She

said to him: ‘As far as I can tell, you truly must think me a two-bit whore, because you

are paying me such a small amount. But now, so that you know what I think, I am telling

you that you won’t set foot in here anymore unless you add three more drachmas to

your daily amount.’ Merlinus became angry and said: ‘Tell me, you dregs of society,

how much time does it take to perform the service you are hiring yourself out to that

young man for? Surely it is so little that it can hardly be measured with money. You

can’t complain that three drachmas constitute poor compensation. As if I didn’t know

that you usually sell these same services to others for one penny, or as if the product

offered by whores is expensive. In fact, nothing is cheaper these days. We will go

elsewhere, and we’ll shift the profit that you’re turning down to that other venue. It’s you

who will truly be losing out.’”

459

There was nobody in that gathering who did not hear, without laughing, about the

generosity and pity of that smelly old man, who had one foot in the grave, toward that

son of a miserly and hard-hearted father. Since one man was laughing more effusively

than the others, this inspired the others to ask him what was so funny. When asked he

said: “The servant carrying that letter from Aridus has reminded me of a ridiculous act,

which I can easily say is the most delightful thing I have ever read or heard. At the time

that schemer was engaged in service to Rufus the clerk (who later went bankrupt) and

received ten drachmas from him every day for shopping expenses. But one day, while

he was heading to the shops with his ten drachmas, as he was wont to do, he saw a

man in the middle of the marketplace who, with the permission of the praetor, had an

urn full of lottery tickets. Whoever wanted to try his luck would pay this man three

drachmas to draw a ticket. The servant was seized with an enormous desire to test his

luck, and he tried his fortune by spending three drachmas from the amount that his

master had given him for the household errands. As it happened, he drew a winning

ticket, one that got him a silver basin with a jug that was valued at ten minae. He turned

down the basin and jug, and he accepted nine minae in cash instead (if you opt to take

cash over your prize you receive the value of your prize, minus one tenth). After he had

been given his money, he spent the remainder of the coins, which had been for the

household shopping, in the tavern next door, not concerning himself with returning

home.

“Because he had been waiting many hours, and because it was already close to

noon and his servant had not appeared, Rufus was angry since he had to pass the day

with no lunch. He ordered his lictors to find and seize his servant and drag him off to jail.

460

From the money the servant had received in lieu of his prize he rented expensive

clothing for himself from a costume designer,201 and he commanded two servants,

dressed in colorful clothing, to follow him. Decked out in this splendid and magnificent

manner, he took himself to Rufus’s chambers. But Rufus immediately saw through,

recognized, and identified him, and got up and rushed straight at him. The servant

strode toward Rufus at the same pace, came up close to him, and bid him good day.

When the servant was asked to explain his ensemble, he responded that he had

received an inheritance from a relative—a substantial one of forty talents, to be

precise—and that it had fallen to him to accrue dignity to himself on account of both the

windfall itself and the distinction of the amount.

“Rufus, whose estate had begun falling into ruin, was roused by hope of a better

fortune and said to himself quietly: ‘If this man is telling the truth, the gods are looking

out for me. But it has to be true, otherwise why would it occur to him to make all this up

when there is no profit in deceiving me?’ So he believed it, adopted new hope, and no

longer reprimanded the man as a servant, but treated him instead with honor similar to

how he would treat a master. Rufus walked on his left side in the street,202 put him up at

his house, and, since he didn’t have any expensive furnishings, he rented him an

embroidered silk bedspread and a silk canopy at very great expense. When Rufus

thought he had sufficiently buttered the man up with flattery and gifts, he asked to

201 The Latin word is choragus.

202 The Latin phrase for walking on someone’s left side is “comes exterior ire,” which, in this context,

“refers to the position of the sycophant or legacy-hunter, as protecting the rich individual, who in this

sense is interior; and the left side was the one protected or guarded on such occasions, because it was

considered the weaker of the two, and was also more exposed to injury or attack” (Horace, Anthon, and

Boyd 1837: 412 n. 17).

borrow four talents, which he promised to pay back soon. The very generous man said:

‘Why four? Ask for ten! I am happy to front you the money, and you can pay me back

whenever it’s convenient.’ Barely containing himself for happiness, Rufus rejoiced and

gave thanks to the gods for bringing such prompt aid to his hopeless and ruinous

estate.

“In order to keep the man more in his debt, and in order to compel him to keep

his promise regarding the ten talents, Rufus took out a loan in the amount of fifty minae,

with interest, and with it he put on an ample and magnificent feast. He invited Dynast

Eugenius to dinner, who at that time was prospering in wealth and influence, and under

whose patronage he received protection. He put on festive games and brought in comic

actors to perform mimes. That scoundrel could be observed dining next to, and sitting

by, that most important Dynast Eugenius and often whispering in his ear, as if he were

his equal in splendor, dignity, and power. Such is the power of money. Need I say it?

Rufus squandered the entirety of those fifty minae in less than five days. When that

joker had, for some days now, stuffed himself to his heart’s content at Rufus’s full and

abundant table, he steered his belly elsewhere, and on a certain day, stuffed from

lunch, he departed the house. Evening came and the servant still had not returned. First

one, then two, then three days passed, but he never appeared. Rufus—who was

assuming that his ten talents had already been located and solidly nailed down in his

house (and who would not have allowed a penny to be taken from him if a buyer

appeared to purchase his debt)—now complained and lamented his bad luck and kept

saying that it was because of his own stupidity that the ten talents had been snatched

away, since he had not kept a close eye on the man.

462

“After eight days had passed, while Rufus was taking the statements of certain

witnesses under oath in his chambers, the servant appeared alone, tattered, and filthy.

Someone recognized him and immediately pointed him out to Rufus as he was

occupied with questioning the witnesses. Dropping everything, Rufus came down from

his bench and asked the man where his colorfully dressed entourage was and where

his expensive trousers and silk cloak had gone to. The man responded that he had

given them back (as was proper) to the costume designer who had rented them to him.

At the same time he calmly and slowly told Rufus about his windfall from the winning

lottery ticket. He said that he was back now and could hire out his services at his usual

rate. Rufus said: ‘So, what you said about the forty talents coming to you from the death

of a relative, that was a lie?’ The joker said: ‘It is as true as if the sun shone at midnight

or if the dead were alive.’ ‘Why did you lie?’ asked Rufus. The servant responded:

‘Because it was a way for me to experience what life is like for the noble and fortunate. I

have indeed discovered that it is agreeable and pleasant. How much good there is in it!

I should have been born rich; I would know how to enjoy myself and have fun!’ Furious,

Rufus attacked the man head on and struck him with more than fifty blows and

punches. But the servant, in turn, blocked the man from hitting his face. After he saw

that Rufus had succumbed to fatigue with all of his yelling and beating he said: ‘Come

now, let us put aside these trifles. Command me to go back to the house. What things

do you need me to set out so that your lunch is ready for you?’ Feeling that he was

doing more harm to himself by beating his servant, Rufus ceased and said: ‘He who

beats a stone, loses his hand.’ At that point, he became more kindly disposed toward

his servant and handed him the keys along with some money to go shopping with.”

463

Everyone was marvelously delighted at the servant’s actions, and they concluded

that the man was an amusing storyteller and a skilled fabulist. Everyone had already

fallen silent when Uranius the painter said: “Since it has very opportunely come to pass

that I should come before this gathering of learned men, if it pleases you, I shall read

you a short Phalaecian poem203 that I composed at the command of Bibulus, high priest

of Father Liber. It praises a dove that the man loved and that died because of his kisses

and embraces.” Although everyone said they wanted him to read it, he said “I will read

the poem on one condition, that if it falters in any way, you let me know, or, better yet,

you correct it. It will be carved in a plaque, in large marble letters, and affixed on a wall

together with other epitaphs that can be seen there”:

O, evil and wicked deed! Cruel death seeks out, with its all-devouring

maw, anything anywhere that is pleasant and beautiful. It snatched my

beautiful dove away from me, like it once most wickedly carried off the

sweet sparrow from Catullus’s Lesbia and spoiled her bright cheeks with

wretched tears. Alas, where has my pain transported me in my grief? And

why do I protest the deeds of rapacious Orcus? He is not the one who

ordered that crime. It is not the dark realms of Dis that hold her but lovely

Venus, who now rejoices in yoking my beautiful dove to her own chariot.

Everyone cheered: “Splendid! Excellent! Well done!” Then a certain person was

asked—a person who, as was reported, was extremely witty, a very funny jokester with

a mind as sharp as vinegar so he would not bear any indignity if he were attacked—he

was asked, I say, to recite a poem that he had written against that ruined man

Tigellus.204 “I will recite it,” he said, “only if it doesn’t cause you annoyance.” We replied:

“Annoyance? We are the ones who asked you to recite it.” He said: “I got revenge on

203 The Latin is Phalaecium carmen, which is a poetic form named for the ancient Greek poet Φάλαικος; it

is hendecasyllabic consisting of a spondee, a dactyl, and three trochees.

204 The name of a first century CE lyric poet who flourished during the time of Julius Caesar. He most

famously appears in the first book of Hor. Sat. (I.II, I.III, I.IV, I.X).

464

the detestable greed of that horribly bankrupt Tigellus with this song. He treated his

creditors like Hercules treated his own, as you well know.205 He gave them a tenth part,

took a ninth part for himself, and, flush with the money he had taken from all quarters,

he refused to contribute, along with his other neighbors, even a few coins toward the

performance of a comic play”:

When Tigellus, with savagery and a harsh glance, refuses to contribute

two nummi for the play, do you marvel that such a stingy man once, as a

castaway, crashed his boat against Janus Gate?206 You are wrong! He did

not suffer the least bit of loss but committed huge crimes while feigning

insolvency. To the person he owed one hundred thousand sesterces to,

he said: “Either go hang yourself or accept ten!” And nobody dared utter a

word, but every creditor left after willingly agreeing to his terms. What

would you do if you had a sword hanging over your head? Would you

yourself, begging for mercy, not surrender to the victor? Is whatever the

thief leaves you with not a gain? Don’t you think that, in the end, even your

life is his gift? Tigellus was not so much a fellow citizen as a bandit, and

he considered whatever he did not steal from you to be a gift.

He had barely recited the final syllable of his verses when someone intervened

saying: “I am just coming from the forum where I was greatly astonished at the wisdom,

justice, and fairness of judge Coschinus. Indeed, I was present in his courtroom for his

ruling regarding a matter of private law. Neither Rhadamas nor Minos himself could

have made a ruling that was more serious, grave, or fair than his.” He did not wait to be

asked but, having gotten everyone’s attention, he began: “A widow was demanding

payment of seventy minae that she had loaned, after much pleading on his part, to a

neighbor of hers who was involved in purchasing certain merchandise. The neighbor

had promised to pay the money back after four months, and he had signed a contract

205 A reference to the practice of tithing to Hercules (see citation of Macrob. Sat. III.12 in Eud. 1998, Lib.

VII n. 16).

206 = lost everything; went bankrupt

465

by which, as she was declaring, he stipulated to this in writing. However, not only did

the day never arrive when he paid the money back, but many more days went by

without his making any further mention of it, as if he had never received it. The woman

began demanding her money back, but he put her off day after day saying: ‘I will give it

to you soon. In a little bit. Come back tomorrow. I don’t have time right now.’ When the

woman saw that she kept being put off longer and longer, she approached the man and

said: ‘Since you are playing games with me, I will claim the money you owe me via the

law and a court ruling.’ Angered, he then said: ‘Do as you wish, I owe you nothing.’ So

the woman hurried at full speed to the offices of a certain legal clerk where many

scribes were working. She related her case to one of them and showed him the

contract. After reading it he burst out laughing and told the woman to show it to his

colleagues, who also burst out laughing. Seeing this, the woman said: ‘What is the

meaning of this? Why are they laughing? In any case, if the seat and the province, so to

speak, of the laughable is ugliness, I don’t see that I am so repulsive as to be laughed

at.’ To make a long story short, she was sent in to see the clerk. After examining her

case he realized that the woman had been had. ‘Don’t be surprised that you are being

laughed at. You have been mightily deceived! That no-good debtor who gave you that

promissory note only wrote down that verse from Horace’s Carmen saeculare: “Sing,

young maidens, of Diana.”’207 At which point the woman cried, wailed, and implored the

faith of gods and men. But the clerk said: ‘Stop your crying and go before judge

207 This is not actually from the Carmen saeculare but is instead the first verse of Hor. Carm. I.21.1:

“Dianam tenerae dicite virgines.” See also Eud. 1998, Lib. VII n. 18.

466

Coschinus instead. He has the authority and wisdom to find a solution that will expose

that scoundrel’s fraud.’

“The woman hurried away and arrived, out of breath, at the judge’s house just as

he happened to be descending from the bench, after the court crier had dismissed the

litigants. She approached him, complained about the wrong done to her, explained how

she had been cleaned out of her dowry by that no-account debtor to whom she had

given a loan for purchasing merchandise. She also showed him the purchases that the

money had been used for, and she produced the promissory note that the fraudster had

signed in lieu of collateral. After examining the case, the judge opined that the woman

had most certainly been tricked. Truly moved, he told her to cheer up and to withdraw

for the time being into the next room, while he summoned before him the man who had

defrauded her. Accordingly, he sent someone to call him. When the man arrived the

judge received him cordially, took him aside, and asked him how he was and if he was

well, and he inquired whether he had made a profit off of the merchandise he had

recently purchased. The man confirmed that the business dealings had turned out well

in his hands. The judge then asked him whether he had repaid the loan he had taken

out for that purpose. The man responded that he did indeed know the woman, but that

he did not owe a penny either to her or to anyone else. The judge then produced the

promissory note and asked whether the man recognized his signature. The man did not

dare deny it but instead asked: ‘What does that pertain to?’ The judge replied: ‘To you

repaying seventy minae immediately. If anyone else had done business with you, I

would allow that person to act according to the rule and order of the law; and I would not

rule against you until everything had been carried out according to the letter of the law.

467

However, since you must reckon with Diana and Apollo, you will not set foot outside of

this chamber until you have sufficiently done right by them.’ While the man was shouting

and saying that he was being oppressed by an unjust ruling, the judge said: ‘Somebody

call the lictors to restrain this man, drag him off, and lock him up in a jail for religious

offenders. At the same time, hitch the horses to my carriage. I have to visit the Rex

Sacrorum208 to inform him about this man’s most wicked theft.’ The man was moved by

fear of chains, dreading at the same time the ire of the Rex Sacrorum if such a manifest

theft were to be brought before him. He successfully obtained, after much begging, that

the judge allow him to make the woman whole, and, after sending men to retrieve the

money, he paid back what he owed her.”

When he had finished speaking, someone in that gathering sighed deeply and

said: “If only I had been assigned such a judge! Indeed, I would not have fallen under

the ruling of a most unfair judge in my airtight case. I had a quarrel and a dispute

regarding a loan with a certain Laurens. The praetor assigned a certain judge Cratinus

to my case, a wicked and capricious man, who ordered that, if it was evident that

Laurens had received the money I loaned him and had not given it back, he would

convict him. I demonstrated clearly, with witnesses, that I had loaned him the money

and I showed the judge his signature. The judge said that the matter had been decided

and that it was clearer than the noonday sun. He earnestly begged me, however, to

assert that the court was biased. I responded: ‘What are you saying? I should criticize a

judge, who appears to be on my side, for treating me unfairly? By god, I will not do that.’

But he said: ‘That is what I am asking. But you do as you please.’ I had no cause for

208 Senatorial priesthood reserved for patricians.

468

fear or worry, so why was I hesitating? The matter was simple, and everything was in

my favor: justice, equity, and the will of the judge. All of a sudden it was announced that

the judge had ruled that Laurens didn’t owe me anything. I rushed in and asked the

judge why he had unjustly ruled against me when he had confirmed so many times that

I was the stronger party in the case. Listen to the impudence of that man: ‘You deserved

it. How many times did I order you to swear that I was biased against you? You have

another think coming if you think that I would risk my flourishing enterprise in order to

advance your failing ones.’ Afterward I found out, from those in the know, that the judge

had unfairly burdened me with that injustice in order to oblige a very powerful man who

strongly recommended my adversary’s case to him.”

He became very angry at the judge and was made even more furious with the

unexpected arrival of a certain man, who they were saying had recently published some

sort of book about famous writers of his age.209 The man said to him: “Were you not

ashamed to add the name of Janus the mattress maker to that company of illustrious

men?210 Did you have no scruples when you placed the common ditties of some idiot or

other, which are sung in taverns, gutters, and soup kitchens, or written on fans,211

Romae adfuerunt ac typis aliquid evulgarunt. See also Eud. 1998, Lib. VII n. 20.

alongside so many outstanding works of excellent men? Perhaps he seemed worthy of

being included in the ranks of learned men because he made you a mattress for free.

Go and strike my name from your list of learned men! I will search high and low for

every exemplar of the works I’ve published, and I will throw them all in the fire to be

destroyed. It’s better to endure a reputation as an uneducated and illiterate man than to

be recorded among the learned along with Janus and those of his ilk.”

While he was speaking we heard a loud noise outside that included the sound of

weapons. We ran out and saw two men, their swords drawn, attacking another man and

protesting that he had hit them. That man was protecting himself with a lance which he

had taken from a nearby tavern. While he was fighting, two silver plates that were

wrapped in a napkin and tied to his waist became untied and fell to the ground. By

chance, it happened that some unknown archer had arrived there and had been spurred

by the voices of the boys, who were giving the other man trouble, to use his arrows to

put a stop to their reckless behavior. Leaning down as if he were intending to bend his

bow, the man stealthily gathered the plates off the ground while everyone was watching

the fight, and, gripping them, extracted himself from the crowd. He has not been seen

anywhere since.

Once the fight had broken up, we decided to head to the port with Gallonius so

the captain would not have to go looking for us if the wind had died down. We went

there, but we found that the sea was not yet sufficiently seasonable for setting sail. For

that reason, on Gallonius’s urging, we climbed up to the nearest Temple of Ceres,

seventeenth centuries (Welch 2005: 12). Rossi is employing this image to signify literary trivia or

novelties.

470

where people were exorcising a young woman who they were saying was insane. She

was lying on the ground twisting every which way, and then she let out a wail, frothed at

the mouth, and performed many similar acts of madness. The doctor who was placed in

charge of her treatment said that she was possessed and being controlled by seven

legions of spirits. He was attempting to drive the spirits out of her possessed body with

certain specific incantations and drive them back to Orcus. The spirits struggled against

him, fought back, and resisted. Finally, unequal in strength (as it were) to those

incantations, they conceded defeat. But the spirits turned back around and asked for an

extra day to leave. The doctor denied them, scared them with threats, and stood firm on

this one point: that they had to leave. Finally, the spirits burst forth and flew out of the

young woman’s mouth causing her to vomit as they exited and to spew forth not black

or yellow bile, or anything like that, but needles, spoons, string, hair, nail clippings,

tacks, and—what is amazing to recount—an iron nail as thick as your thumb and the

length of your palm. The doctor carefully collected all of these items and positioned

them high up so people would be able to see them. He said that the items had been

placed inside a honey apple, by the handiwork of a witch, and given to the woman to

devour; and that in the end, after being cast out when she vomited, she was left carrying

only a single legion of spirits inside her. He said that the remaining legion of spirits had

pitched their camp inside the woman’s stomach with other equally monstrous items, but

that it would soon come to pass that they, too, would follow in the footsteps of their

fellow spirits, and that she would spew forth whatever monsters were inside her

stomach.

471

We were dumbstruck by the strangeness of this occurrence. We could not

properly grasp how a single honey apple could hold so many items or how a sensible

and knowledgeable woman could chew up and swallow them, and then throw them

back up a year after she had swallowed them whole. Indeed, how did the sharp end of

those needles and tacks not damage her throat and stomach? Did she ingest that fist-

sized nail into her stomach broken up into tiny bits and chewed up with her teeth, or did

she devour it whole? If it was broken up, how were her teeth strong enough to crush

iron? If it was whole, how did she not choke on it? But one man who had been present

at the scene solved this difficulty for us. He said: “How wittily that trickster thinks he is

pulling one over on us! Does that wicked man think we are asses, stupid people, or

wooden logs instead of men? As if it were not obvious where those monstrous items

were pouring forth from! If you had kept your eyes on her hands, you would not have

been deceived. Indeed, if you don’t pay close attention, those tricksters use sleight of

hand that escapes your sight.”

Then I said: “Do you believe that no women have ever been possessed, fanatic,

or frenzied?” “If only the gods would make them not so!” he said. “But very few of them

are seized with this affliction. These days, when a woman’s hatred for her husband sets

in and her desire for another takes hold (and when there is no possibility of her gaining

possession of him), she orders herself to be carried around as if she were insane. In the

case of more simple women, if their foot or head is hurting, if their leg, thigh, or arm

becomes swollen, if black bile has induced dark thoughts in them, these scheming men,

who support themselves with these deceits—or use them to satisfy their lust—

encourage such fear of demons and spirits in these women, and they take money to

472

invoke Hercules or placate Ceres or to buy herbs and other things for making fumigants.

Other, more libidinous men seize on similar opportunities to forge a path to intimacy

with women. Pretending to administer medical treatments, they grope the maidens and

noblewomen of the house and, if fortune or good luck favors their attempts, they strip

them of their virginity as well. In this way, they procure challenging and expensive love

affairs for themselves at no cost and without any trouble or expense.”

Another man said: “The man who chose this story for us to hear is telling the

truth. I will narrate what I saw, with my very own eyes, so the shamelessness of these

men will be better known to you. During the period when I was serving as the valet of

King Alectrius,212 the great and most renowned king of those vast regions, a few

scoundrels came to our city with a woman who (they were boasting) was possessed by

many thousands of spirits. They climbed up onto a platform that had been erected in the

forum, right below the windows of the royal place. At that moment, the woman began to

shout, wail, move her body back and forth, and throw herself into their arms. The

scoundrels held her, called upon Hercules, Ceres, Apollo, and Jove, praying for the

gods to be propitious. The spirits, despite the fear being instilled in them of so many

divinities, were not dislodged even the slightest bit, but they barricaded themselves

inside her possessed body with a fortification, as if they were inside a great citadel. The

woman, as if the spirits were responding through her very own mouth, spoke in various

languages and answered questions. Most importantly, the ghosts insisted that they

wouldn’t withdraw from the woman farther than even a finger’s breadth until she had

212 This pseudonym for the King of France derives from the Greek word ἀλεκτρυών meaning rooster, or

gallus in Latin (see also Eud. 1998, Lib. VII n. 21). The Gallic rooster (coq gaulois) is the unofficial symbol

of France.

visited the Temple of Diana Daphnitae;213 that Diana was the only one who could order

them to leave; and that, even if Jupiter himself were to come and bring with him twelve

more gods than there actually are in heaven, he would depart a frustrated

laughingstock. The Temple of Diana Daphnitae was located a thousand miles away.

The scoundrels then moved the populace to compassion with their skilled speechifying

by speaking of the woman’s poverty and of how she didn’t even have the few pennies

necessary to dine that day, let alone to take up such a long pilgrimage at her own

expense. They then appealed to the people’s aid. They begged and pleaded with them

to help the poor woman, ready her purse, and equip her with provisions for her voyage.

Greatly moved, the people showed compassion, rushed to help, and brought her

donations. The scoundrels thanked the people, praised their piety, and promised to

bring back many delightful things the next day and on following days, thanks to that mad

woman, and adding that the people should come watch the show bearing their usual

donations.

“The king, who was watching everything from his window (I was standing next to

him), assigned a man the task of going, inquiring, and investigating where these men

interacting with his people were from, who they were, and what their social standing and

profession was. The man obeyed, ran out, got close to the men, secretly followed them,

room where the men were staying, and went into another room adjacent to theirs. While

the scoundrels were out he took a drill and opened up a fairly wide hole in the wall,

and (as was the custom of those people) gave themselves over to lightheartedness and

sport. They sang, danced, grabbed the woman around her waist, laid her down on the

ground, took her in their arms, and had their way with her. After this, dinner arrived and

was placed on the table. They sat down, ate, drank, and did not hold back in any joy,

hilarity, or sport. After they had had enough of wine and feasting, they communicated to

nevertheless, because they feared that their fraud would be uncovered if she at all

they had taken pains to join together to create a single bed. They all lay down on the

bed at the same time.

“After they had done this, the spy who had been sent by the king reckoned that

the matter was clear enough, wrapped up his investigation, and left to report everything

he had seen to the king. The king was glad that he had not been misled in his hunch.

He therefore ordered all of them to be locked up in jail. After a formal complaint had

been lodged, everything the spy had seen was brought out in their own words and

214 Plaut. Mil. III.ii.887-8. Translation from Plautus and de Melo 2011-13.

475

entered into the official record. Because they had been caught red-handed, they did not

dare deny it. Learn the method of punishment and, at the same time, admire the king’s

wisdom. He ordered them to publicly sing a palinode215 in the forum from the same

platform where they had come to play their tricks on the people, like crows gouging out

the eyes of other crows. If they refused, they would immediately be sent to the cross. To

avoid having stones thrown at them, the king placed armed men all around to fend off

the force and attacks of the people. Fearing the cross, the tricksters did what they were

told. The following day they were forced by the king’s command into exile and they

retreated beyond the borders of the kingdom.

“But why did my story go farther afield and not contain itself within the boundaries

of our city? Don’t we also have greedy flamens of the immortal gods here among us,

who often bring some crazed person (either genuinely mad or pretending to be) into

their temples in order to draw people in for profit? The Temple of Mercury, located here

in our city, is the largest and most sumptuous of all the temples, and it once had a

certain Alexis as its sexton who was a filthy and shameful man. The wickedest of all

exaggerators, he was known for his loathsome love of boys and often showed himself

guilty of theft. Moreover, he always had some dedicated house upon which every pimp

and gambler, rounded up from all directions, would descend and where everyone’s

passions gravitated. No boy could set foot in that house and leave with his purity intact.

No chaste person who entered there could leave again without being tarnished by some

disgraceful act. With these enticements, it came about that the sacristan became

everybody’s favorite person. He was finally poisoned, in secret, by the head lictor

215 A poem in which the poet retracts a view or sentiment expressed in a former one.

476

because he had brought a false charge against someone. After the head lictor had

made the praetor and the Rex Sacrorum aware of this (both of whom agreed that the

charge was false), they considered the sacristan to be either spiteful because he had

brought false accusations, or negligent because he had presented accusations that

were not well investigated or scrutinized. Nevertheless, the head lictor admitted publicly,

before a large audience, that he had caused harm with the man’s untimely death, since

the office of the praetors had never had a better or keener spy than he.

“A most ancient shrine to Ceres was located in that temple, enclosed within iron

bars and imbued with the greatest and most ancient holiness. The shrine contained a

stone upon which (it was said) Ceres herself had sat down after being overcome with

exhaustion while searching for Proserpina.216 They said that this stone had great power

for expiating madness. The noble painter Uranius had undertaken, at that time, to paint

a certain picture in which he depicted the goddess Diana’s virgins bathing her, covered

in sweat and dust from hunting, in a sacred river. One day he heard a voice near him

crying out from morning to evening. After the sacred rites were finished and with night

coming on, the voice did not lose any of its strength but made its force felt even

stronger. Uranius realized that the voice was coming from the shrine. He went over to

the shrine and asked the man who was enclosed there why he was wailing. The man

replied: ‘Alexis hired me for fifteen obols today to pretend I was possessed and to fill the

temple with my cries and wails. I have been yelling myself hoarse but nobody has

showed up to pay me. What is even more bothersome, I am wracked with a need to

216 Proserpina (or Persephone) was abducted by Pluto and taken to his kingdom in the Underworld

leaving her mother Ceres (or Demeter) to search for her frantically.

477

defecate. If he does not come and unlock these bars, I will surely empty my bowels right

here.’ Then Uranius responded: ‘That’s exactly what you must do. Come on now, empty

your bowels and, when he comes back and cheats you out of your agreed-upon wages,

throw whatever comes out in his face.’” He finished speaking and fell silent. Paulus

Aemilius said: “Who are those people who say that tricksters and schemers are only

found in Rome? From what I hear, people live according to the same morals

everywhere.”

In the meantime, a young man had arrived from the ship’s captain and

announced that the waves had calmed down and that the captain had decided to set

sail and to travel, with all possible speed, to the next island over; and so we should

come quickly. We listened to the instruction, started running, and encountered the ship’s

captain fighting with a surgeon, who was very much pleading with him to take him on

board the ship with the other passengers. The captain was refusing because the ship

was full and could not accommodate anyone else. Gallonius asked the surgeon why he

had been seized by this great desire to set sail, since he had always avoided the sea.

The surgeon answered that it was his father’s cruelty that was making him move from

his native land into exile, because he had thrown him out of the house. “Yesterday, as I

think you know, those of us who heal wounds with our hands took in the body of a

servant who had been sent to the cross by the triumvirs on account of a capital crime.

We did this so we could cut him open for the benefit of finding cures for the living, and to

obtain a thorough knowledge of the position, color, shape, and size of his organs. I

plucked the liver from the remains of his body and brought it home so I could carefully

examine every part of it—the fibers and the little membranes that bind it to the

478

enclosure that separates the abdomen from the chest wall—and I placed the liver over a

rack that hangs on the wall in my room. Then I went out because I had some business

in the forum.

“A little while later, when lunchtime had already passed, I went home, entered my

room, looked around, and could not find the liver anywhere. I asked our maidservant

what had happened to it and why she had dared to touch it while I was out. A great

argument broke out between us over this. My father, roused by the noise, came over

and said: ‘What is the meaning of all this racket? Why are the two of you fighting?’ I

replied: ‘This villain here stole a liver from me that I had brought home to study—and I

can’t find out what happened to it.’ Then my father said: ‘Why do you need to be making

all this noise? Even if she did take it, what offense has the woman caused? Just to let

you know, a little while ago we cooked it up and devoured it for lunch. I have never

eaten a dish anywhere that my taste buds enjoyed more. Try it, and you too will say the

same thing. I saved some for you in the kitchen cupboard.’ Almost beside myself with

anger (it was not that easy to find another liver), I said: ‘That was a fine crime you

committed. You ate the liver of a crucified man!’ That is not what my father wanted to

hear and he became enraged shouting: ‘You are the worst! You made a cannibal out of

me today! Why didn’t you say anything before? Why did you store it out in the open?

Get out of here and go to hell—and make sure you don’t show your face around here

again! If I catch sight of you around these parts after tonight, I will scatter you about in

little pieces. I will rip out your liver with my teeth and see to it that I have a dinner that

matches my lunch!’ Fearing the sight of my father, I am going search of other provinces

479

and, although I do not have a lot of traveling money, I nevertheless hope to support

myself with my profession.”

We listened to the young man’s account with horror and disgust, but we laughed

anyway at the man who had stuffed himself with human flesh. We told the young man to

cheer up, and we begged the ship’s captain to let him aboard. The ship’s captain said

that it was not going to be possible if that disagreeable old man was also coming, who

was going to delay everyone on account of his arrogance. He was about to say more

regarding that man’s haughtiness and pride, but Plusius, who was reading some poem

or other to another man on the pier of the port, attracted our attention. He seemed to

applaud the poem with his look and expression. When Plusius saw us he called out and

said: “Listen to this charming poem that the young Aridus Virgilius217 sent along. He is

the son of Brother Ursatus,218 the great priest and dynast whom we recently mourned

upon his death”:

O Virgil—the rising new hope of the people, the delight and honor of the

house of Ursatus—appearing under good auspices, you arrive, a shining

star of heaven, bringing lights abounding with the gleaming rays of virtue!

Since nature, according to your merits, entrusted you with a talent that

was neither small nor confined within the limits of a single course of study,

like water being restrained within a small channel, but was instead strong

and able to break through barriers and extend through the various liberal

arts like a mighty river—made powerful with rainfall or by its own nature—

that overflows its banks and, meandering, traverses vast estates. Learned

in a hundred liberal arts, you, still a boy, hasten with great strides to aim

for the heights of genuine glory. Is there anyone who does not imbibe, with

avid ears, the speeches you pour forth from your fertile mind, which are

magnificent and glowing with rosy nectar, whether you are joining words in

217 Virgilio Orsini (1615-1676) was from the ducal family of Bracciano. Rossi originally published this

poem about the real Virgilio Orsini in 1627 when Orsini was twelve years old. Orsini’s youthful talent is

reflected in the description of him as “pene puer” (almost a boy). He was twenty-two years old when

Eudemia was first published in 1637 and would become a cardinal four years later, in 1641, at the age of

twenty-six.

218 Ferdinando Orsini.

480

the poetic meter or consenting to proceed in prose? Whom does your

honesty—ornamented with outstanding morals—and your pure integrity

not draw to itself and bind in pleasing fetters. Who does not feel wondrous

joy at those battles where you, at play, attack wild beats, whether you are

hunting a boar in the cold outdoors or slaying a deer with a powerful blow?

It is no wonder that you have been so strong from the time you were very

small. For in your home your father was illustrious, and so was your

grandfather219 who, playing sweetly on his Thracian harp, was able to halt

rivers and draw oak trees down from high mountains. These men

possessed the wisdom of powerful Laelius and the attractive strength of

the Scipios.220 But while you are forming and preparing yourself as a boy,

attentive to your ancestral customs, you demonstrate how—since it is right

for you to live your life of your own accord and holding fast to your

purpose—you resist with firm intention the carnal desires that lead wanton

men toward forbidden sin. In much the same way as the straight pine tree

strikes the air as it grows, or the tall ash with its tender bark, with its

leaves glowing far and wide, will not fear rain showers or raging North

winds and will not bow its head before the clouds.

The refinement and style of the poem pleased me exceedingly. I said: “Plusius, I would

gladly take it with me if I had time to copy it out, but we have to depart soon and are

pressed by lack of time.” Plusius said kindly: “Take this one. I can produce six hundred

copies where I transcribed that one from.” I accepted it and thanked him.

At that very same moment Plusius pointed out a philosopher from the religious

community that is bound by oath to the cult of Minerva.221 The most important aspect of

their vow is that they abstain from women and from any form of sexual intercourse.

Every year their leaders, on behalf of the rest, vote to select a single person whose

authority they stand at the ready to obey on command. They all wear similar clothing;

219 Virginio Orsini, second Duke of Bracciano (1572-1615).

220 Gaius Laelius (c.235-c.160 BCE) served under P. Cornelius Scipio Africanus the elder in Spain (209-

206 BCE) and in Africa (205-202 BCE), becoming his close friend and protégé. The Scipios are P.

Cornelius Scipio Africanus the elder (236-183 BCE), who conquered the Carthaginians in the Second

Punic War, and P. Cornelius Scipio Aemilianus Africanus the younger (185-129 BCE), who conquered the
