481

they eat their meals together; they never walk alone but always in pairs, in threes, or in

fours; they reject all pleasures; and they embrace all virtues, especially, of course,

chastity, which Minerva prides herself in. Their training is thought to have been devised

and advanced by Xenocrates,222 a disciple of Plato, so on account of this belief in their

virtue, and thanks to the regard in which they are held, everyone yields to them, makes

way for them, and their reputation is considered to be that of living gods. They are

permitted to enter into the homes of noblemen, without any suspicion of wrongdoing, to

penetrate their most intimate chambers, to visit their wives while the husbands are out,

to talk to them, console them, and to support them with their counsel, aid, and influence.

Plusius pointed one of them out to us and said: “That is the one who is held in

such contempt these days.” We asked why this was, and he responded: “He is an

associate of that philosopher, the one who used to go every day to visit Pamphila, wife

of the nobleman Lysimachus; and after getting rid of any eyewitnesses, he used to

spend many hours with her alone in her room. This associate would sit without food in a

second room with a chambermaid, a charming girl, and see to it that no one else

entered. One day he became tired of waiting and said to the girl: ‘Please tell me, what

business are those two conducting in the bedroom?’ The girl, laughing and joyful, said:

‘Do you think they are encouraging each other’s chastity? Are you chewing on

wormwood or so asleep that you can’t see the obvious? They are giving in to their

desires and, in my opinion, they are doing the right thing. We, on the other hand, are

idling, abstaining, and acting as their lookouts. Why don’t we also spend the day happily

222 Xenocrates of Chalcedon (c. 396/5-314/3 BCE) was a Greek philosopher, mathematician, and leader

of the Plato’s Academy from 339 to 314 BCE).

482

after their example?’ There was no need for many words to persuade the man, aroused

to wickedness by the heat of his age, the allurement of the opportunity, and the

woman’s words. He remembered the profession of faith and the vow that bound him to

Minerva but, believing that the virgin had a better idea, he said: ‘Let others maintain

their faith in their promise to Minerva. Far be it from me to waste such a good

opportunity. Let me sail where the wind is blowing!’ And he sank at once into the

maiden’s bosom.

“It didn’t only happen that day, but every day thereafter, as often as the

noblewoman’s companion was locked in her room performing his duties. Finally,

however, when some time had passed the maiden’s body began to swell, such that the

nobleman Lysimachus demanded to know, in the presence of his wife, what the cause

of the swelling was. Since the matter was clear and maiden could not lie, Lysimachus

sought to identify the person responsible for this shameful deed. The wife, whose heart

was full of tricks and deceit, and who knew that the maiden’s shame was connected to

her own disgrace, pretended to be angry and said: ‘Look at that man’s face! Look how

he pretends not to know what he knows and not to have done what he did—as if it is

any mystery whose fault this is! You wicked man, you are guilty of this crime. Poor me! I

am not able to defend anyone’s chastity from his assault in my own home, whether it be

a maidservant’s or a free woman’s! How can I tolerate being married to this man, who

keeps mistresses at home but neglects his wife’s interests? Did I enter into this

marriage, only to have to witness such things and tolerate such insults?’

“Her husband Lysimachus, conscious of the fact that he had committed no sin

against the maiden, was angered by his wife’s abuse. In order to prove that he was not

483

responsible for this crime, he attacked the maiden saying: ‘Tell me who got you

pregnant.’ Because the maiden was keeping their secret—so as not to reveal, out of a

hateful betrayal, the noblewoman’s indiscretion together with her own shame—the

husband became even more incensed saying: ‘Do you think I won’t be able to wring the

truth out of you today?’ He pulled out his dagger and brought it up to the maiden’s

throat, and he repeatedly threatened to slit it unless she told him who had taken away

her virginity earlier. Fearing for her life, the maiden at last revealed that she had been

violated by that most chaste man, while he was waiting on his companion who was

locked in the room with the noblewoman.

“Lysimachus, as if driven by the Furies, ran to the house of the philosophers,

summoned their leader, and related the crime that had been committed against the

maiden. He demanded that, unless the head philosopher wanted the entire city to be

filled with shouting and noise, the filthy man be handed over to him as a criminal, so

that, through his punishment and suffering, the husband could alleviate his pain and

assuage his mind. The head philosopher deflected the crime away from his protégé

saying that the real sinner was the woman, because she was conjuring up such

disgrace against the philosopher who was a most holy man. In fact, there was no one in

that household who was more honest or chaste than he. Lysimachus insisted that the

philosopher had done it, and the head philosopher denied it. But when the nobleman

raised his voice even more the head philosopher, fearing that the neighbors would

come running and that the crime would become public, gently approached the man and

asked him to go home. The head philosopher promised to investigate the matter and

not to dismiss it without punishment. Persuaded by these words, Lysimachus checked

484

his anger a bit, and he resolved to wait until the head philosopher had made good on

his promise.

“In the meantime, the philosopher, accused of having had sexual intercourse,

was thrown into jail on the head philosopher’s orders, and he was given a cup

containing hemlock diluted with wine. He was given the choice of either drinking it, after

which he would lose his life in the space of an hour, or he could consent to being

castrated. After deliberating, the philosopher—believing that living under any conditions

would be better than not living at all—gladly presented his testicles to be cut off.

Sometime later, when his wound had healed, the head philosopher met with

Lysimachus and asked whether he had come to believe in the innocence of his protégé.

Lysimachus said confidently that there was nothing he was more certain of than that the

maiden had been violated by that most wicked man, and that the matter could not be

ignored. Then the head philosopher said: ‘I will now get you to understand how

mistaken you are.’ He ordered the gelding223 to come take clothes off in front of

Lysimachus. In doing so, he exposed his groin with its missing testicles. Then the head

philosopher, as if moved, said: ‘How do you respond? Does this man, who was

castrated a long time ago when he was a boy and whom, on account of the manifest

integrity of his life, it was fitting to make a priest of the Great Mother, seem capable of

getting a woman pregnant? From now on, when the reputation of a good man is at

stake, please control yourself, if you know what’s good for you, and do not constantly fill

people’s ears with false rumors about him.’ Lysimachus was so cowed by this deception

223 The Latin word is vervex, a castrated sheep or a wether. I chose to use the word for a castrated horse,

gelding, as it is a more common and recognizable English word.

485

that he did not know where he was, and he did not have any ready response. Because

of this, fearing both his own judgment (because he had slandered a devotee of Minerva

with an odious crime) and his wife’s ire, he resolved to get back into her good graces

and not even believe himself.” The cunning means that the head philosopher had

employed in order to vindicate the reputation of his household in public opinion so

delighted me that nobody’s shrewdness and cleverness has ever persuaded me to

greater admiration.

Gallonius said: “If you like, I will show you that sniveling old man who sent

vinegar instead of wine.” We looked over and saw a skinny old man hunched over,

wrinkled, the color of a weasel, and with blackish hair that was not yet discolored with

any gray. He was being asked, from out of a whore’s window, what he wanted from that

house. Merlinus said: “Open up, I need to talk to you.” The whore replied: “I don’t have

time right now, I am busy with my lover.” But Merlinus continued to shout: “Give me

back the money you stole, you hag! I thought you were just shameless, not greedy as

well!” Taking no notice of him, the woman went away and left the man arguing in vain.

But the old man kept yelling anyway: “Give me back my money, you filthy woman! If you

don’t give it back, I will ruin your reputation by berating you right here in front of your

house.” Gallonius ran over and asked, in the name of their friendship, what happened

and why he was yelling like that. He replied: “I usually come to this wretched woman’s

house just for fun after lunch, and I spend my afternoon hours with her in bed. Today

while I was lying with her, per my usual routine, she secretly got out of bed, went

straight for my trousers, and (with me completely unsuspecting) she disemboweled the

wallet that was inside them. Afterward she came back, approached me, and insisted

486

that I get up and give my place to some lover of hers who was especially profitable for

her. I got up, obeyed, did what she wanted, and left. I arrived at Janus Gate to pay off a

little bit of the money I owed to a friend from a reckoning of accounts. I put my hand in

my wallet and found nothing left—that traitor had sucked all the life out of it.” While

Merlinus was sadly lamenting the fate of his wallet, someone came and told us that that

peevish old man, whom we had been waiting on to board the ship, had been struck by a

sudden fever, was bedridden, and, according to the opinion of the doctors, did not think

he would be able to set sail. The ship’s captain gave thanks to the goddess Febris224 for

removing that barf bag from his ship, and instead he brought on board that young doctor

we had been talking about. After embracing Gallonius once, again, and a third time, we

both said goodbye to him, and we entrusted our lives to Neptune.

Book Eight

Everyone in our entire group aboard the ship was approaching and standing

around this one man and asking him why Fortune had suddenly reduced a certain

soldier (whose name I don’t remember) to dire straits from a condition of greatest

wealth. He was from some order or other of voluntary soldiers—an order he had

founded himself. There were many of these sorts of military orders in these parts, who

wear a Greek Y (upsilon) sewn onto their cloaks with silk thread, either white or red, and

either simple or interlaid with silver and gold, as the rule of each order dictates. They

were asking what role this once lucky soldier played in his own reversal of fortune. The

man told us that Fortune had never looked out for the soldier, and had never enriched

him with estates and farms whose profits could support such great, and so many,

224 The patron goddess of fevers, invoked by the Romans to protect them from illness.

487

expenses. But it is amazing how skilled in vice he was that, with his clever stratagems

and tricks, he accrued to himself such a quantity of gold that it covered his unbridled

expenses for a long time.

When the soldier had first set foot on the island, he was poor, tattered, reliant on

others, and was surviving on bread that he had begged off of the kinds of people who

support the poor with leftovers from their own table. Then, all of a sudden, he obtained

mountains of gold and went from being like Irus to being like Croesus or Attalus.225 He

decorated his incredibly sumptuous villa, which he rented for a great sum, with rugs

worthy of Attalus; he constructed a storeroom, a granary, and a wine cellar; he

assembled a household staff of reputable people; he dressed his many servants in

colorful clothing; he supplied his dining room, on a daily basis, in an impressive and

splendid manner; he only set the table with silver dishes; and he put on meals worthy of

the festival of Ceres with leftovers that stuffed many a glutton. What more can I say? He

measured his gold coins by the peck and the triple peck, and you would have thought

he made daily sacrifices to Hercules.

The strangeness of his situation attracted everyone’s attention. Word spread

among the people that he was producing gold at his house. This rumor reached the

ears of the Rex Sacrorum, who, by virtue of his civil and military authority, gave the

quaestor the task of inquiring, investigating, and examining whether those gold coins,

with which the man abounded, were real or fake. The quaestor did not delay, but he

approached the man, along with his lictors, and ordered him to hand over his gold,

225 Irus is the pejorative nickname for the beggar Arnaeus in Homer’s Odyssey because he ran errands

for everyone (from the masculine form of Iris, messenger to the gods). The Lydian king Croesus and

Attalus I of Pergamon were both famous for their great wealth.

488

which the man promptly did. The quaestor picked up the coins, inspected them once,

again, and many times over, and did not find anything amiss. The soldier, to clear up

the matter and show solid evidence, cut quite a few of the coins with shears—many

times and each time in half—so it would be plainly evident if, by chance, something

fraudulent were concealed inside them; then, as if annoyed, he threw the coins on the

ground and made the lictors pick them up. The quaestor left believing that the soldier

was endowed with much wealth and was free from any suspicion of wrongdoing.

The quaestor’s judgment resulted in the soldier having such a reputation for

wealth that everyone flocked openly to him, as if to Midas, in order to enrich himself.

Whoever was able to entrust his gold to the soldier considered himself lucky because,

after a few days, he could say that he had received favorable interest. The soldier

bolstered this opinion of himself through his spending and generosity. He practiced this

to such an extent that, at certain times of the year, especially at the Aphrodisia Festival

held in honor of Venus (under whose banner the soldier marched), he would supply

clothing to several unmarried girls, and he would make every effort to have a banquet

set up and prepared, to which he invited not only the most eminent men and all his

friends, but whoever wished to attend. Through his generosity he convinced people to

believe, for absolute certain, that he alone held the method for making gold, which many

had attempted but, so far, no one had discovered. And he had nothing to hide, for he

often openly told anyone who would listen that, in his hands, they would have as many

lumps of gold as they wanted within a few hours and with almost no effort. And they

believed him. Although his endless outlay of funds frequently drained whatever

resources he had at home—so that in the evening he had not even one cent left over—

489

the next morning piles of gold coins could be seen on his table. His eloquence, along

with a certain natural virtuosity in speaking, won him a great deal of trust in the things

he said. Namely, there was a sort of power to his speech that seemed impossible to

resist. Moreover, he assumed an attitude that was so haughty and arrogant that he

insisted on being considered on par with princes; he held the orators of the greatest

kings in little esteem; and he sought alliances with the leading citizens of the city.

Persuaded by his reputation (since Jupiter was raining gold down on him from

the heavens), these leading citizens came to him of their own accord seeking to marry

their daughters to him. Out of all these marriage proposals he liked Via’s daughter the

best. She was a very beautiful maiden who was related by blood to more than one line

of kings. The marriage was set to take place (they had agreed that no dowry would be

paid) and everything needed for the marriage was at hand: canopies fit for a very king,

carriages lined with silk and covered in gold, colorful and luxurious clothing for dressing

her boy attendants and servants, and many other things of that sort. In purchasing

these items the soldier had run up a large debt. When the maiden’s mother got wind of

this (she had the sort of keenness that was impossible to deceive), his situation

suddenly caused suspicion. “Well now! The debts he’s run up, the money he’s borrowed

at interest, and the things he’s bought on credit don’t add up. If he knew where the

fountain of gold was, as he claims, he would not need to borrow anything to repay his

debts; he would already have the money at hand for purchasing those items. Unless I

am mistaken, his boastful words must surely be covering up some deceit.” With

suspicion as her entryway, she thus arrived at the lair of his trickery. She summoned the

soldier’s creditors and explained her suspicions about him. She advised them to make

490

sure, by decree of the praetor, that he was taken to jail by force and treated as a debt

defaulter and a flight risk. After all, if he brings this remarkable injury upon himself, and

then doesn’t produce the money to pay off his debts, the matter is crystal clear: he’s a

pure con man.

The creditors praised the woman’s advice, thanked her, ran at full speed to the

praetor, and communicated their request. The praetor, who found the soldier’s

arrogance detestable and had been suspicious of his unlimited wealth, did not dare

deny their request, and he ordered the man to be thrown in chains before nightfall

unless he paid off his entire debt or provided sufficient collateral. Thus the poor soldier

found himself surrounded by lictors before he was able to have the slightest inkling of

what was happening, or before the news was somehow able to reach him—especially

because he had turned his attention to being cautious. He did not surrender himself into

their custody like a timid coward, but drew his sword and attempted to effect his escape

with it. But it was all in vain. He was hit over the head by the chief lictor, was forced to

stop, and he handed himself over to be tied up and taken to jail by force, where he died

of grief a few months later. It later came to light, however, that he had never wanted to

get married. How would he have been able to support a wife with such a large

household, especially one born to such a lineage, since he himself had no place on

earth he could call his own; and since he wasn’t able to amass any gold or silver, except

for what he forged out of tricks, deceits, and the resources of others? I repeat, it was

only a plan to fleece others out of their gold, right down to their hides, through a

pretense of marriage; and, in particular, to trick that very rich merchant out of large

quantities of diamonds, each of them worth up to fifty gold coins. If the soldier had been

491

able to secretly take the diamonds from the merchant, either by entreaty or by

pretending to buy them, he had a boat waiting to take him back to his homeland and to

resolve the matter by fleeing.

Instead, he used the opportunity of his marriage and wedding for his principal

means of stealing them. He said that he really wanted to buy them so he could affix and

sew them onto his wife’s dress, which was worked in the Phrygian style.226 He therefore

stopped by the merchant’s house frequently, and, bringing along an embroiderer with a

small piece of his wife’s dress, he picked up each diamond, inspected it, and tested

whether it fit in the gaps of the embroidery pattern. He said that the day of his wedding

was drawing near but that he could not pay the cost—nor commit in advance to a

specific day when he could pay it—and he insisted, and vehemently demanded, that the

man hand over the diamonds. The merchant kept a firm grip on the diamonds saying:

“No one will take even a single diamond from me unless he has payment at the ready.”

The soldier responded loudly and proudly (as was his wont): “Are you afraid to trust

me? Other people have handed over to me a thousand times more, and they were not

cheated out of their money. There is no other person alive today who is considered

equally and properly credible as I. Don’t you know that I will soon be able to utterly

shower you with gold?” “Indeed, that’s how it stands,” said the merchant. “You won’t

have the diamonds from me any other way. Take your fancy words out of here. You will

never persuade me to trust you today with even one cent.” They say that the soldier

gave up immediately when he sensed that trust in him was collapsing.

226 A style of clothing that was embroidered and/or had precious stones sewn into it.

492

Then someone who was listening to the story said: “This soldier was defeated by

the cunning and wickedness of Geta, who arrived last year from the farthest and most

remote regions of the world at that island we just set sail from. He had fallen in love with

Philargyria, wife of Agathon the clockmaker, and he sent her gifts, bracelets, stockings,

necklaces, earrings, and rings. He took all these things out on loan from his friend the

goldsmith. But when Geta had satisfied his desire for her and had become weary of the

woman’s greed, he devised a plan by which the items he had given her would be

returned whence they had come. And the plan worked perfectly. One day he came to

the woman’s house pretending to be distraught. She immediately asked him why he

was so sad and agitated. ‘Because I got into a dispute with the goldsmith where I

purchased the gifts of gold I gave you. He has clearly gone mad with his prices and

feels no shame about it. Because he knows that the gold has flown off to you and that I

can’t return it, he’s trying to use the threat of a lawsuit to force me to accept his

demands. Sometimes he says he will bring legal action against me, and other times he

uses threats of lictors and jail. In sum, he is cruel and mean in many ways. Do you want

to play a funny trick on him that will make his eyes hurt? Bring him the gold I gave you

so he gets it back. In this way, if he can sell again what he thinks he has already sold,

we will indeed have exacted proper revenge. In the meantime, you take this promissory

note that a money changer recently brought to my house, and you will immediately get

two talents, which you can use to buy new jewelry or, if you prefer, you can loan it out at

interest.’ The woman, even though she leaves all other women in her wake, by a long

shot, in terms of her cleverness and wickedness, she was nevertheless won over by the

hope of greater gain and by the foreigner’s advice. She took the promissory note and

493

returned all the gifts to him. Geta took them, returned them to the goldsmith, who had

loaned them to him, and made for his fatherland with all possible speed. The woman

who had been deceived, on the other hand, counted her coins in her dreams.”

While we were laughing at the woman, whom the foreign man had so nicely

duped, a small boat powered by oars was swiftly approaching us. Indeed, neither birds

nor winds moved faster. When it got close to us, we caught sight of a man in chains

sitting in the midst of four lictors. The ship’s captain recognized him immediately and

said: “They are bringing in the sexton of the Temple of Apollo by force. He has been

brought back from his escape, or rather, he is being brought to sentencing and

punishment.” With the usual vice of the human race, we burned with desire to find out

from the ship’s captain what capital crime he was found guilty of being involved in. The

ship’s captain willingly complied with our wish and said: “This sexton loved, to the point

of insanity, a beautiful, freeborn boy (he has a penchant for such things) and after

pursuing him tirelessly, he painstakingly arranged to lure the boy to his bedroom. But he

was not able to succeed because the boy knew why he was being summoned and

continually invented new excuses for why he could not come. The sexton, driven by a

burning desire as if by the Furies, contrived the following plan to draw the boy to him,

albeit unwillingly.

“The boy had a pet falcon that he had trained so well that, when he sent it forth

into the air, it would come back to him with prey in its talons. While the boy was away

from his house, the sexton concerned himself with getting the falcon delivered to him,

so he sent men to insist, on the boy’s behalf, that the falcon be handed over to him. The

boy, he said, was intent on catching birds at a small country house near the city, and

494

that he very much desired to hunt prey with his falcon. Unsuspecting, his family handed

the falcon over without delay. When the boy came home to find his falcon missing, he

asked what had happened to it. His family said that they had given it to the man whom

he had sent from the nearby country house where he was hunting birds. The boy cried

and wailed and said that he had never set eyes on that country house, that he had not

organized any bird hunt, and that he had not sent anyone over. ‘But wherever it is, it

cannot be kept hidden for long. I will suss it out. I will break down everyone’s doors, and

I will search every corner of every house.’

“But the sexton happened upon the boy as he was searching and said: ‘I know

what you are looking for. Make your search worthwhile: your falcon is at my house, so

please come. I will not stand in the way of your getting it back forthwith.’ The boy, for

whom time had never seemed to pass so slowly as while he was waiting to have his

falcon returned,227 and not concerned with anything else, followed the sexton as he

went ahead and entered his bedroom. The sexton immediately bolted the door shut and

pitifully begged the boy, with many entreaties, compliments, and promises, to succumb

to his desires. Hearing these things, the poor boy at last realized that he had fallen into

a trap (he had never before feared anything quite so much as this), and he tearfully

began to implore the man to keep the falcon and to just let him go.

“The sexton, in order to render the boy obedient to his wishes, alternated

between mollifying him with promises and terrorizing him with threats. But when this

didn’t succeed, he resorted to force, and he pulled out two spears, one which was made

227 The translation of this sentence is based on a sentence with similar phrasing from the translation of

Cic. Verr. II.IV.XVIII.39 in Cicero and Greenwood 1928.

495

of iron and the other one (pardon the expression) extended out from between his legs, a

duplicate of—and very similar in size and shape to—the one that makes the god of

Lampsacus especially fierce and terrifying.228 He said: ‘Choose whichever one you

want. Whether you want to or not, you much choose one or the other.’ The appearance

of his terrifying member made the boy undecided as to which one he should surrender

to in meeting his death—the sword or that detestable rod. He was not sure which of the

two he would receive less injury from.

“While he was deliberating, the sexton received a message from the high priest

of the temple telling him to set aside all business and to hasten to him at full speed,

because the high priest needed to meet with him. Upon being summoned, the sexton

hurried off. The boy, freed from all fear, thanked the gods, arrived home without his

falcon, and, almost beside himself with fear, told his father everything that had

happened. He said: ‘Although he was unaware of his good deed, if that good priest had

not intervened, you would be arranging a funeral for your son today because at this very

moment I would be split in two and broken by that frightful spear.’ The father, incited by

rage, went to the high priest, told him about the sexton’s shameful act, and said that he

owed the boy’s life first to the gods and then to him, because he had summoned that

pervert away. Otherwise his son would have been killed by the greatest form of torture

and would now be dead. The high priest was greatly offended at the wickedness of his

sexton, and he dismissed the boy’s father with encouraging words and, at the same

time, promised he would see to it that no harm would ever come to his son in the future

228 = Priapus, whose cult started in the Greek colony of Lampsacus in Asia Minor before spreading to

mainland Greece and then to Italy. This part about the “second sword” (his penis), and the “terrifying

member” was removed from the 1645 edition likely because it was too salacious.

496

at the hands of that man. The high priest did not wait for his anger to subside, but he

immediately sent for the sexton and, as was fitting, scolded him and ordered him to

return the falcon to the boy immediately and to leave the city—and even the whole

island—before nightfall. The sexton heard this order, but, full of rage and malice, he

went to the boy’s home when the boy’s father was conveniently away and called for him

outside the gate. By chance, at that very moment, the boy was in the throes of colic and

confined to his bed, so he was unable to go outside. The sexton, while he was handing

the falcon over to a maidservant, pulled out a knife that he kept hidden under his cloak

and said: ‘If he had come out, the boy would have gotten this entire knife in his gut,

because it’s his fault that I’m being thrown out into exile.’ And he immediately packed up

all the silver bowls, dishes, jugs, drinking vessels, and the boxes for incense he used for

the sacred rites to Apollo, and he secretly fled to the adjacent island, which was under

our jurisdiction.

“When he got there, he broke the sacred vessels upon an iron plate that he had

begged off of the innkeeper where he was lodging, with the intention of refining them in

a fire and melting them into a single lump of silver. The items had barely touched the

fire when a din, a crash, a loud noise, and a crack of thunder rang out so suddenly, so

quickly and powerfully, that the house seemed to be caving in. The innkeeper and his

entire family rushed over and looked at the plate that had been placed on the fire,

together with the shards of the dishes, and they saw that the crashing noise had thrown

that sacrilegious man to the ground. They picked him up and handed him over to the

magistrates who put him in jail. He was ordered to plead his case before them in chains.

He is being sent to the high priest of the temple he plundered so he can be put on trial

497

according to law, or rather, so punishment can be exacted from the confessed criminal.”

A certain person was listening to this, who, from the way his eyebrows were knit

together like a cloud, his long beard, and his black teeth, we understood to be a wise

man. He drew a deep breath and poured forth these wise words against wanton love

affairs”:

Alas, who can count the things that an irrational lover endures? Ah,

sometimes not even grievous death is as dark! A lover often mourns the

joys that he has been deprived of—poor man—and often grieves and

laments his wounded faith. He asks: Do mortal minds engage only in false

oaths? Believe nothing, O trusting man. Does pleasure, that is so slow to

come, flee so quickly? Is this pain so firmly set in my mind? Indeed, this

statement is true: harmful things are made of hard marble, whereas (one

might say) good things are made of fragile clay. But if you enjoy steadfast

and simple pleasure, it can only be summoned from heavenly places. Or if

you seek a mate and a similar disposition in love, your mind must rest

wholly in God’s kindness; from this alone can mutual ardor take hold—the

rest is just deceit by secret tricks, and you will not draw true solace, or joy

untainted with impure stains, from anywhere except heaven. But as for the

things that shine brightly, as soon as you see them change appearance

(mark my words), you will wish you had never touched them. They

become unsettled and are similar to a clear sky that does not show its

lovely face forever. Oh, how many times did the day, which had been

cloudless, seem suddenly to become enveloped in a black fog! How many

people do you see, who are happy and confident in their prosperous

affairs, later wet their cheeks with tears! We are spun about in the quickly

whirling wheel of Fortune, like a ship on the open sea, while the South

Wind rages. For now, after leaping up and striking the wandering stars,

the ship heads down toward deepest Tartarus at a swift clip. How often

has a man just been seen in his gold-plated halls, only then to be forced to

depart, a pauper, for a lowly house! Therefore, no faith should be placed

in vain things, which cause harm when mixed with wicked shame. Safe

and secure, strive for the gifts of the mind; for these things remain firm

while everything else changes frequently. As long as you are able, fill your

mind with noble virtues and spend your days innocently and without

blemish. But waste no time, for the years will pass and somber death will

arrive quickly on dark feet; afterward your faults will strike you with belated

shame and with even more fear, if that shame hits a guilty heart. If the

hours of a misspent lifetime return through my devotions, with what

prayers would I wish to beg the gods, after being restored to myself, to

repay the damage I have done; and with what prayers could I strive to

have new hope in my heart? Are you without fault? If you think back, god

498

was always present to us and new labors remain to be performed, even in

the wake of misfortunes: infernal dwellings, fierce Tisiphone, savage

monsters horrifying with snakes, black rivers flowing with sulphurous

streams, and eternal tears flowing endlessly from your eyes. Prayers by

no means move their hard hearts, and any way out is closed to those poor

souls, as is the power of salvation; for the doors are firmly sealed shut with

hard iron. So do not let the eyes or hair of a young girl harm you, blunt

your keenness, or let your honor be undergirded by a misdeed. Truly, if

filthy love oppresses you, take the initiative of freeing your neck from the

yoke that is holding you captive, and when you have expelled that filthy

fire from your pure heart, such passion will no longer burn you with a

similar flame.

It seemed like he would have said more if a fight, which had broken out among

the sailors, had not called the entire group of people away from him. Everyone went

over to calm the fight down. And so, abandoned by his audience, he fell silent and did

not finish his poem, which he had begun and was taking pains to bring to a close. We,

on the other hand, were left on the deck of the ship and were pounced on by one of

those philosophers, who we said before had promised their chastity to Minerva. If you

had seen his face you would have thought him a worthy man. Indeed, there was such a

seriousness to his expression and gravity in his gait, that you would have said he was

Socrates or Xenocrates or one of the ancient philosophers who, on account of their

incredible will-power and innate tendency for self-control, had a direct path to virtue. He

approached us, wished us well, and then said: “I know you! I often saw you walking

along the street with Gallonius. What were you thinking leaving that city when it isn’t

easy to find another one in the entire world more charming or more filled with

pleasures? Every kind of love, desire, beauty, charm, delight, sport, and jest dwell there

and participate in its delights. The destructiveness, distraction, and discord of so many

pleasures the city has to offer came down on me (poor thing!), and I was violently

removed from it. When I tore myself away and set foot aboard this ship, I felt that a part

499

of my insides was being ripped out of me. But it couldn’t be any other way. I was being

pressured by the order of my superior and had to yield to his moral authority. He is

sending me to the neighboring island in order to propagate our religious order and, in

particular, to sow in men’s hearts a love of chastity by way of frequent sermons before

the people.

“But, as I understand it, you did not have a guide to help you seek out and

identify the city’s pleasures. If you had had me as your teacher, what realms of pleasure

and delight would I have led you to! But I can’t do more than point out the signs and

indications of the locales where, once you are familiar with them (if you ever find

yourselves in the city again), you can mine countless pleasures, as you would gold, and

find them without error. Make sure that my words remain fixed in your tenacious mind;

memory is fleeting unless it is retained by the aid of letters. Do you have writing tablets

and a pen on you?” “No,” I replied, “but we have notebooks.” “All right,” he replied, “Go

ahead and write this down: If you enjoy the cleanest prostitutes, go to madam Claereta

in the Vicus Tuscus. She will bring you a group of girls who are healthy, compliant, very

beautiful, very young, and (most importantly) barely passed around in public—and she

will bring so many of them that you can have a new lover every day. If you prefer

virgins, look for Phanostrata in the Forum Boarium. She always has some nice morsel

stashed away at her house that she can send your way when you arrive. Or if you find

something you love on your own, she will make you see how useful she can be in these

matters. She is so eloquent that she can draw even the Vestal Virgins out from their

enclosures. If noble married women are your cup of tea, for this you should look no

farther than Angellus of our religious order. He is the only one who has all of the

500

matrons in the city at his beck and call, and he can tell you how each one’s feet, thighs,

arms, and buttocks are. Although he is extremely dutiful, he is equally mindful of his

own needs, and he hardly ever presents any woman to someone else for enjoyment

whom he has not first tried himself. Therefore, on account of the regard he has for me,

he will provide you with matrons of the highest social rank and the greatest beauty with

whom you can derive the greatest pleasures. But our avowed worship of Minerva,

goddess of the greatest nations, is calling me away from you. We venerate her with

certain prayers, so that she will be propitious and not allow any blemish to stain the

chastity that we profess.” As he was leaving, Paulus Aemilius said: “We thank you, and

if we ever return to the city—to such a vast sea of pleasures as you describe—we, who

are inexperienced and unskilled, will stay afloat with the raft you have provided us.”

When he was out of sight, a man, who had secretly overheard his words, said: “O

tempora, o mores! Who can you trust your wife with? Who can you entrust your children

to for an education? That man would form their tender minds with the same precepts he

just tried to instill in you. And he, who is supposedly so reserved, is sent to foreign

countries to praise chastity! That man, whom his entire audience treats as if he has just

sprung forth from the very bosom of Minerva when he starts speaking, denounces

crimes of passion with vigor, intensity of conviction, and seriousness of words and

determination. As soon he has concluded his speech, however, if he comes across a

maiden or matron he can have sex with, he immediately demonstrates, in that situation,

what his own will and feelings are regarding that entire matter. Angellus, whom we

mentioned, is ashamed to talk about the abominable things he had a hand in. The

scandalous things he has done could be distributed, man by man, over the entire

501

population. He has ruined the purity of so many matrons! He has brought disgrace upon

many chaste women and dishonor upon many virgins!”

And the man would have dragged his speech out longer, had he not been

interrupted by the auspicious voices of people calling out: “Well done! Oh good! He’s

here, he’s here!” We looked up and saw about thirty triremes heading toward us at a

fast clip. They were said to be carrying Dynast Parthenius,229 a leading citizen

abounding in every advantage of nature and fortune, who had been admitted into that

religious order not long before and was now on his way to rule that republic230 along

with the other dynasts. The great virtues of that leading citizen—unanimously exalted to

the heavens by everyone, with the highest words of praise—infused in us a desire to get

to know him, not just by some birthmark, so to speak, but by his whole body. Each of us

eagerly tried to act on our desire, but in the end, the eloquence of a person more suited

to this task won out. He said: “If I wanted to relate everything that can be said about that

man, I would run out of days before I ran out of words. Elected to take the place of a

deceased dynast, he lends more grandeur to that position than he will receive from it.

Although the rank of dynast is equally available to the highest and lowest men (and a

dynast is not considered any greater because he comes to that rank from the highest or

lowest station), nevertheless some dynasts are greatly superior to others in praise and

glory. This man, born from a long and a clearly immeasurable line of great kings, in the

very flower of his youth, and at the point of greatest abundance in all of his attributes,

imposed a condition of abstinence and the highest virtue upon himself. If we are to

229 Giachino (2002: 200) identifies this person as Fabio Chigi, later Pope Alexander VII (1599-1667), but it

could also be Pope Urban VIII or Cardinal Francesco Barberini.

230 = Eudemia

502

imagine a dynast from whom every blemish has been removed, and who is rich in every

merit, this man was certainly the very model and character of a dynast. And just as

there is nothing of any sort so perfect that it is not excelled in perfection by the original

of which it is a copy—like a mask is a copy of a face—in the same way, if anyone

should form or fashion himself to imitate that dynast’s life, that person would be judged

far inferior to him in terms of excellence. That dynast has no hiding places lurking in his

mind and no recesses for concealing treachery. He has no plans for trickery drawn up in

his heart. He harbors a mindset that is not darkened by malevolence, not accustomed to

lies, not counterfeit, not deceitful, and not educated in the arts of pretense. Of his own

accord he cultivates piety, religion, and justice, and he does not do so for some profit or

advantage. Moreover, he excels in talent, education, and learning. Crowds of learned

men frequent his villa, so much so that it is considered a veritable workshop of wisdom

where an academy was immediately formed from the flowering of all the minds that

gather there.231 Those who are ruled by a zeal for the most refined arts are marvelously

delighted, and they profit from these men’s most learned orations.”

As we were listening intently, we were interrupted by the sudden boisterous

laughter and hissing of the sailors. The ship’s captain, a sensible man, knew why they

were laughing, and he put a stop to it with a harsh reprimand and ordered them to be

quiet. When they looked around they saw four triremes carrying a few dynasts back with

all possible speed to the kingdom of Geryon, whence they had come, to the assembly of

regards to Mancini. Perhaps the villa mentioned here is Palazzo Barberini, also a locus for many literary,

the Rex Sacrorum. They had been persuaded to go there by some mathematicians

who, from the position of the stars, had predicted that the king, who was in power at that

time, was destined for the Underworld within a few days.232 When they had seen that a

month had passed from the time of that prediction, and that there seemed to be no hope

that Minos had drawn the king’s lot from his urn in the Underworld, they were returning

back whence they had departed, despondent and devoid of laughter.

While everyone was engaging in delights, conviviality and joy, we saw one man

standing apart from the rest who was sad, kept his head lowered, and was gazing at the

floor. Paulus Aemilius, either out of pity or because of the flaw in men who, wasting

away with idleness, concern themselves with other people’s business, approached him

and asked why he was so forlorn. While the rest were giving themselves over to joy,

why was he furrowing his brow as if to mock the happiness of others? He replied: “My

charming neighbor, who arranged for me to marry his sister, is the cause of my misery.

After he had paid out her dowry at my house (namely fifty minae), he placed the maiden

under my legal control.233 Enflamed with the desire to have her as soon as possible

(she’s not bad looking), and also to consummate our nuptials, I withdrew with my new

bride to the bedroom and, not thinking, I left the silver that had been counted out there

on the table. While I was inside enjoying myself with her, that good man took the money

and secretly ran out of the house, leaving me with nothing but tears. I am now headed

232 Urban VIII believed in astrology and had horoscopes read that predicted the death of certain cardinals

in Rome. Beginning in 1626 astrologers predicted Urban VIII’s own death, and by 1628 these predictions

were talked about openly. In 1631 he published a bull against astrologers (Walker 2000: 205-6; Giachino

2002: 204).

233 “Manus” in juridical terms is a husband’s legal control over his wife in marriage. See Chapter 2, n. 517

for an explanation of the two kinds of marriage, “cum manu” and “sine manu.”

to the neighboring island where they say he has fled, so I can pursue what was taken

from me via the law and a legal judgment, or rather, so I can take that thief’s life.”

Paulus Aemilius responded: “Truly, you are shamefully stupid. You are seeking revenge

for something bad with something good, an injury with a benefit. You cannot thank him

enough for his kindness, because he gave you a wife who will be as gentle as a sheep.

She will not lean on her dowry to become emboldened in the future, but she will revere

you as a master, she will fear you, and she will be obliging in all things. Therefore,

banish that cloud from your brow and allow yourself to be happy with the others. Heed

my advice and go home; if your wife is as wonderful as you say, since there are so

many pleasure-seekers and rich people around, the gift bearers among them will be

gathering the troops at your house.”

While Paulus Aemilius was trying with all his might to console the poor man,

another one came forward who was just as forlorn, saying: “This man’s dowry may have

slipped out of his hands, but my wife slipped out of mine—and after she fled she was

nowhere to be found. Therefore, which one of us lives a more miserable life?” Paulus

Aemilius responded: “Really, she fled? Yours and your relatives’ watchfulness should

have guarded her more carefully. If you had done that, you would not now be

complaining that she got away.” Then he said: “I even had too tight a grip on her.

Because I loved her desperately, and because the frequent comings and goings of

young men past my house every day made me suspicious of her, I didn’t allow her to

set foot outside the house, even the width of a fingernail. Argus didn’t guard the cow

Juno, who was entrusted to him, as well as I made sure to keep a close eye on what

was mine. My trade gave me a talent in this area. I am the kind of chef who, unlike

505

others, never cooks outside my home, but I season what is brought to my house with

care and with such pleasantness that my food can please even the dead. For this

reason I am never lacking for work. However, during the most recent night festival in

honor of Ceres, my wife begged me, with all her heart, to take her to the Temple of

Ceres, and she spoke so sweetly that she talked me into it. I get up just before dawn,

enclose Vulcan in my horn,234 and order her to follow me as I walk ahead. We go there

and we enter a narrow lane that is filthy and muddy. Attentively, I caution her not to step

in the mud, and I say: ‘Leonica (that is her name), watch out for the mud! Watch out for

the mud, Leonica!’ I looked back, but Leonica had already flown out of my sight. Out of

breath, I ran and followed her as she was racing ahead—but it was no use! I wasn’t able

to keep up with her, since she was hidden by the advantage of night. Nonetheless, I

spared no labor or effort in searching—she is too dear to my heart—but I crawled

through the whole town, to the Temple of Ceres, to my friends’ houses—where did I not

go? Now I have decided to visit all of the islands surrounding this kingdom in search of

her, and I will not stop looking until I have found her. And when I have found her I will

bring her back home with me.” Then Paulus Aemilius said: “You fool. Are you

complaining that you have been freed from annoyance and expense? If you are so

troubled that your wife is gone, and if she is the source of your greatest joy, give the

dowry you received from your wife to this man, and you take his wife off of his hands. If

he is wise, he will restore your enjoyment to you, and he will manage without her. In this

way each of you gets what you want: he gets a dowry and you get a wife. Good day.”

234 Vulcan is the god of fire, who in this case stands for the flame in the lantern itself, which is made of

horn; in other words, he lit a lamp.

506

In the meantime, out to sea they saw the island in the distance from where, as

we said, the sexton had been brought back after his flight. The captain decided to put

the ship ashore on the island so he could purchase the superior wine that is produced

there and load it onto his ship. We approached and entered the port where we heard

about the death of a young man, whom Dynast Vius loved and considered his darling,

and who had driven himself (by his own stupidity) into a state of poverty and need after

having the greatest wealth, with which he had been enriched by Vius. They were

discussing the time when this young man was once employed as a page boy in the

dynast’s household. On account of his extreme arrogance and insolence, no one could

tolerate the young man and he was ordered to leave that house as soon as possible

and go to the devil. Deprived of any support, the young man took himself back to his

homeland. There, since he did not desist in his arrogance and insolence, but

perpetrated unheard-of acts on a daily basis, they say he was dragged off in chains.

Making use of his customary audacity, he broke free of the chains and came back from

his flight to his dynast, and he put his mind—through his friends and go-betweens, all of

whom were eminent men—to being reinstated to his former place of friendship and

favor with the dynast, thanks to his friends’ esteem. The dynast responded frankly that

he would put up with anything before he would host such a man at his house.

Finally, deprived of hope, the young man decided to try his hand at new fortunes

and to find new friendships, and he immediately boarded a small boat. It is important to

understand, however, how Neptune—who understood that the fortune the young man

was seeking was located in the country he was leaving—drove him back from the sea to

the shore. Because the winds were blowing hard, the small boat had already sped out

507

of sight when Neptune ordered Aeolus to signal a retreat; to check the winds that were

favorable to his voyage by confining them in chains; and instead to release winds that

were unfavorable for sailing, which would agitate the sea and drive the small boat back

to the same place whence it had set sail. Aeolus obeyed Neptune’s orders, released the

winds from their confinement, and sent them out to sea. The winds had barely broken

free when they assaulted and attacked the boat, turned it around, and forced it to return

whence it had left. Tossed out onto the beach, destitute, and just about in rags, the

young man had no hope, no resources, and no plan which he could adopt to help his

situation.

Dynast Vius was out of town during that time enjoying the delights of his country

estate. A young man named Styliolus was there, who at that time held a very strong

position with the dynast because of his influence and charm. (The dynast always chose

someone idle, weak, of low birth, and a no-name as his confidant, on whom he could

lavish great rewards of money; transform from a poor man into a rich one; and whom he

could render not obedient to his word so much as dominant over him.) The young man

was hoping, therefore, if he received letters of commendation from Styliolus addressed

to the dynast, that he would easily obtain what he wanted. Thus, he approached

Styliolus with cunning and wickedness and told him the following: “Rumor has it that I

committed an offense, and that I was thrown out of the dynast’s house because of it. In

addition, the matter also brought great disfavor and contempt upon me in everyone’s

eyes. I beg and plead with you to help me erase this blemish that has attached itself to

my name and has ruined my every thought, counsel, and hope. With you advocating on

my behalf, the dynast won’t dare refuse anyone anything. Write to him and tell him that

508

he should bring me, for a period of one month and no longer, into the position and rank

of attendant. When the month is up, I will consider myself as having fulfilled my

obligation; and, if you will allow it, as if discharged from his service, I will enter your

household as your servant, as though on a new tour of duty.” Styliolus, puffed up and

full of boasting, thought that it would be a mark of pride for him if it became public

knowledge that men were seeking close association with him and rejecting association

with dynasts—which is considered to be especially honorable among those sorts of

people—in order to gain benefits and influence. He therefore takes the prideful young

man on and passes a letter to the dynast in which he lays everything out. With all his

might, Styliolus begs the dynast to allow himself to be won over and to fulfill the wishes

of the young man. He said that nothing would please the young man more than if he

thought the dynast loved him as much as Styliolus felt he did. Styliolus signs and seals

the letter and gives it to the young man. The young man brings the letter immediately to

the dynast (who, as we said, was in the countryside at the time), not hesitating to make

the twelve-mile journey in the height of summer at high noon. After the dynast read the

letter he was persuaded by the enthusiastic commendation, exclaiming: “I’ll grant

Styliolus his wish, but he must understand that this man, whom he is so eager to

commend, will one day be the ruin of his fortunes.”

Soon, the dynast began to pay the young man every honor, that is to say, when

everyone was standing before him with their hats doffed out of respect (as was the

custom in those parts), he gave the nod to the young man alone to keep his head

covered; to him alone he entrusted his plans; to him alone he entrusted any affairs that

held any advantage or honor; he held him in great esteem; he summoned him as his

509

sole dinner guest, as his companion in his bedroom, and as the one who sits by his side

in his carriage. When Styliolus learned all of this from many people’s letters and from

everyone’s talk, he was, of course, understandably very perturbed. He wrote to the

dynast saying that he was greatly surprised that he had not yet sent the youth back to

him, and that a month had already gone by, at which point the young man had bound

himself to him (Styliolus) as if by a sort of oath. The dynast handed the letter to the

young man and commanded him to reply to Styliolus’s demands in whatever way he

deemed best. The young man immediately responded to Styliolus that he could not

wonder enough at his impudence, or rather his stupidity, because he was demanding

services from him—as if he were some hired hand—who employed many people in his

house, who were of more respectable origin and family than Styliolus himself was, and

who cleaned the latrines for him. For this reason, Styliolus should watch his back if he

knew what was good for him; and if he continued to pester him, he would come to

understand who he was dealing with; and that he would decide which of the two of them

was the fool.

When the dynast returned to the city from the countryside, he continued with—

and even increased—his gifts and, day by day, he offered ever greater tokens of his

great love toward the young man. He even ordered a bedroom be prepared for the

young man, decorated with all manner of accoutrements, and placed next to the room

where Styliolus usually slept. But get a load of that young man’s arrogance and

contempt. Driven wild by the favors shown by his master, and by dancing and running

around all day and night, the young man drove Styliolus to the point that he could not

sleep, and he was not able to give his attention to any other matter. The din, clatter, and

510

noise were so loud that the room seemed to be collapsing in on his head, along with

that entire wing of the house. Styliolus went often to the dynast to complain about these

offenses but did not get any response out of him, other than that the young man was

only a boy, and moreover that boys’ games had to be borne with laughter and good

humor because they were just letting off steam in a youthful way. When he had lost

hope, and also because he was jealous of the excessive love the dynast had for the

boy, Styliolus rented a house in the farthest and most remote part of the city and went

away to that place as if in exile. Styliolus had hardly set foot outside the dynast’s house

when the boy took over the rooms in the most important wing of the villa, which had

belonged to Styliolus, shutting the former occupant out of them forever.

But the more influence the young man gained day by day in authority and favor,

the more arrogantly and haughtily he behaved. He took his arrogance so far that once

during lunch, when he was lying next to the dynast and was not eating anything besides

fish (the practice from the ancient religion of those people held that meat was not to be

eaten that day), it came about, perhaps because the sea was greatly agitated, that

hardly any fish had been caught, and that any fish that had been caught were highly

prized. Utterly common types of seafood were therefore set before him, like sardines,

sole, and mussels. The master of the feast, however, saw to it that a pound of catfish,

purchased at a very dear price, was placed before the dynast. Once the dynast had

tasted it first and found it to have been agreeably and correctly prepared, he gave it to

the young man out of esteem and love. Get a load of the impertinence and impudence

of this man. Many distinguished noblemen were standing around the dining couch, hats

off, waiting for their chief’s command and ready to do his bidding. The young man,

511

puffed up with foolish and ignorant arrogance, threw that very expensive food to the

dogs, in front of everyone. Those who were present were amazed, turned white as a

sheet, and trembled with fear. The dynast fell silent and made no sign of

acknowledgment regarding the young man’s great offense. In response to the young

man’s having greatly insulted and disdained his gift, the dynast remarked that he had

behaved even more arrogantly that past summer.

In order to avoid the summer heat, the dynast had retreated to his country estate

near the city with his brother-in-law Megalobulus, who held many small towns under

monarchical rule, so they could be together there. He did not bring anyone with him,

except for a few servants and the young man, who slept in the anteroom at night like a

bodyguard. But, in the dead of night and unbeknownst to everyone, the young man got

up and galloped to the city on a horse. A short while later, the dynast woke up and

asked for his chamber pot, but nobody came. He called for the young man by name, but

no one responded. He called out a second and third time. Nothing. Then he jumped

down from his bed and woke up the servant, who was sleeping alone in the other room,

ordered him to carry a lamp, and together they searched, investigated, and found that

the house had opened its doors like jaws and disgorged the young man outside. The

house was not able contain him because he was enflamed by desire and eager to break

free. There was a din, and other people ran over to let them know that the young man

had mounted a horse and had raced to the city at a gallop to fulfill his desires. This

pained the dynast greatly because, when the young man left, he had not locked the

door but had left it wide open. It would have been within the power of any enemy or thief

to approach right up to his bed and to smother him in his sleep.

512

Furious, Vius summoned his brother-in-law Megalobulus and told him about the

young man’s wicked deed. Moreover, he said that this wasn’t to be tolerated and that

they must see to it that the young man fully comprehend the significance of making a

mockery of important men. Most of all, it bothered Megalobulus that his brother-in-law’s

reputation was being damaged by the spiteful talk of those who did not have his best

interest at heart, because the young men who basked in the dynast’s favor held too

much sway. Because of his brother-in-law’s superior position, Megalobulus had never

before dared to warn him about avoiding such disgrace, and he immediately seized this

opportunity that was presented to him, exhorting the dynast not to entrust his life and his

reputation to these immoral commoners. He said that he himself had three children,

outstanding in both beauty and age, whose active and faithful services the dynast could

benefit from, if he so desired. He said that they were devoted, beholden, and dedicated

to him. As for the rest, he said that he himself would take responsibility for making sure

that great insults such as these, and others, would not continue at this rate.

Megalobulus left the dynast’s side intent on locating four strong men skilled in striking

and beating; acting like purveyors,235 they would supply the young man with so much

wood when they caught up with him that he would not be able to get out of bed for three

months straight. Megalobulus did not have to look very far, since four members of the

dynast’s own household, whom the young man had cruelly ordered about, had taken

upon themselves this very task of beating him up. They knew he would be back, and so,

instead of a banquet, they concocted an unwelcome surprise for him upon his arrival.

235 The Latin is parochus (from the Greek πάροχος), a person who, for a certain sum, furnished traveling

magistrates with necessities such as wood, beds, hay, straw, salt, etc. Wood in this sense means the

instrument with which to beat someone, or, metonymically, a beating.

513

The young man returned with his mind very much at ease, entered the atrium of

the house, and went straight up to the dynast who was passing the afternoon hours with

Megalobulus in pleasant conversation. The men, with clubs at the ready, waited for the

signal to bludgeon the man’s head, shoulders, and arms. But what do you think

happened? Do you think the dynast ordered them to attack the young man, or at least

scold him severely and remove him from his sight? Or, if he chose not to get angry, to

nevertheless look disapprovingly upon him, so the young man would understand how

displeased he was? Of course not! Then what did he do? The dynast rushed headlong

into the young man’s arms, rejoiced at his arrival, and said: “Today we are having

watermelon for lunch. I do not recall ever having eaten a watermelon before today that

had a better shape or sweeter juices than this one. Do you want to try it?” “I don’t mind if

I do!” The dynast called the server over and said: “Bring me the part of the watermelon

that I had ordered to be served at dinner and bring back with you a jug of our very best

chilled wine.” “As you command,” said the server.” “Carefully,” the dynast said, “and

quickly. Have you understood your instructions?” The server did not delay. He brought

the watermelon to the table and, once he had set it down, the dynast cut it up with his

own hands and placed it before the young man. He then ladled out the wine, filled the

wine glasses himself, and bade the young man drink and restore his strength that he

had lost during his journey. Shaken by this, Megalobulus immediately got in his carriage

and returned to his castle.

In the meantime, while he was chatting like this, we walked up to a town situated

in an elevated and pretty place. It had a very large town square, beautiful fountains, and

many wide streets that continued throughout and were divided up by many streets

514

crossing it at right angles, and which contained a great many ornate private homes. But

while he was talking, time had never seemed to pass so slowly as it did while he was

finishing up his story. We were anxious to discover what the nature of that place was,

what its traditions were, and what kinds of people lived there, and we heard that the

land was extremely fertile for growing everything that was necessary to live, like wine,

oil, and wheat. We heard that the people were very peaceful and dutiful and were so

averse to thievery that, if any money accidentally falls out of anyone’s pocket, nobody

bends over to pick it up. Moreover, we heard that they are so fond of, and love guests

and foreigners so much, that it is considered akin to an inexpiable crime to dishonor or

to lay a hand on them. When we learned these things, the idea came to us (if what they

were saying was true) to remain there and not seek out any other regions or face the

dangers of the sea again (which we later learned, from their conversations, had grown

somewhat greater). We therefore decided to set up residence and establish our home

there and to spend our remaining years in that place, for however long that may be.

We were fortified in this new plan we had settled on by the words of that

philosopher, who condemned the crimes of desire with his verses. He said that

everyone was equal under the law there and that nobody was granted more than

anyone else; it was really the case that everyone was just about equal, and nobody

surpassed anyone else in position and wealth. This was something that the philosopher

identified as the most important ingredient for happiness, and he also affirmed that

arrogance and injustice on the part of more powerful people was intolerable. He knew

what he was talking about, because he had been caught up more than once in the

unjust actions of powerful people, and, most of all, because, although he deserved to be

515

treated well by several prominent men (whose names he did not conceal), he had been

very badly repaid. Thus, he began another song:

It is worthwhile learning the habits of the rich man, namely what vices

render his whole class weak. Sicknesses of the soul take hold of him and

ruin his mind with a shameful wound—and not one of them is exempt.

First, his puffed-up arrogance carries him off in a bronze carriage and

inflates him, vain as he is, with bellows. Thus inflated, he does not stoop

to show his arrogant face to a common man, one who is without wealth.

Already he does not believe he was created from human flesh and blood,

but that he is more akin to the gods in heaven; and he believes he has

touched the blessed throne of eternal Jove. Because of this, he insists that

near-divine honors be bestowed upon him, while he allows the poor man,

with bared head and on bended knee, to pray for aid with gifts and

entreaties. And not only does he rejoice in his reputation as a puffed-up,

arrogant man, but he is consumed by much worse vices. His love of

money grows, and his dark thirst for yellow metal236 rises up, attacks him,

and settles deep within his core. How this desire for shameful greed burns

his breast with fast-moving flames! How his desire for possessions blazes!

While he unjustly amasses money for himself, snatched with impunity from

a poor, trusting associate, and adding it to his own stockpile, he either

defrauds poor craftsmen of agreed-upon wages or refuses to pay for

things he has purchased. The complaints of the innocent cannot touch his

savage heart, nor the tears heard in his echoing atrium, which his cheated

creditor fills with mournful cries pleading: “Pay me what you owe me so I

can keep cold and hunger at bay from my children and from my dear wife,

lying ill in in tattered clothing, whom it often pains to make it through the

day.” The cruel, rich man is happy to recline at an abundant dinner table

surrounded by deep sighs and sorrowful complaints, and to compose

musical concerts out of tears. What disgraceful and detestable desire

does he not possess, which continuously swells his veins and, victorious

over him, fills them up with a fast-moving heat until they are distended!

Thus, no peace rests in his body or soul until he reaches his desired goal.

Raging desire, driven by the burning Furies, is often transformed into

anger, so long as he is aggrieved at not being able to get what he wants;

or perceiving, with a sidelong glance, that other men are demanding that

the loaf be divided in portions equal to his. Wherefore, a woman who does

not wish to sell her virtue for cash or hastily acquiesces to the insane

pleas of her lover, her windows are often spattered with a stinking mess,

and her doorposts are broken with a ferocious hailstorm of rocks. And

whoever goes forth boldly in search of the same sort of morsel, brings

back a face ugly with the marks of infamy or a head and shoulders beaten

with rigid sticks, or suffers an ugly death with savage wounds. Thus, love

236 = gold

516

is mingled with the sword, as long as the spiteful person wishes to

wantonly acquire what he desires without any competition.

When we had heard these verses and had finished exploring the entire city, we rented a

villa on a high hill,237 which, on one side, looked out onto the land, and, on the other

side, looked out on the sea. At last, from the money we had brought with us, we

purchased a farm to sustain ourselves.

237 There are two possible interpretations for this villa on a high hill. If we read it only in the context of the

1637 edition in eight books, it is plausible to see this as a reference Rossi’s own house on the Janiculum

Hill, which he frequently mentions in his body of work. If we read it in the context of the 1645 edition in ten

books, this could be a reference to Palazzo Barberini on the Quirinal. Book Nine opens with a long

description of a grand villa with a splendid garden, which seems to represent a noble palace with a vast

adjoining estate more than it does the simple farm described here.

BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH

Jennifer Karen Nelson was born in Chicago, Illinois, and grew up in Berkeley,

California, graduating from Berkeley High School in 1986. She received her BA in Italian

Literature from the University of California Santa Cruz (UCSC) in 1991 and her MA in

Italian Literature from the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) in 1997. While an

undergraduate at UCSC she studied abroad for a year in Padova, Italy, and she was a

Fulbright Scholar to Rome, Italy, in 1997-98. After working for a few years in the private

sector, she went to the University of Kentucky to pursue a master’s degree in Library

and Information Science (2004) and a concurrent MA in Classics (2005), also obtaining

a certificate from the Institute for Living Latin Studies. She has taken numerous courses

at Rare Book School, both in Charlottesville, Virginia, and through the California Rare

Book School at UCLA. Since 2005, she has been the Reference Librarian for the

Robbins Collection in Religious and Civil Law at the University of California, Berkeley,

School of Law. She received her PhD from the University of Florida in 2019.

536
